questions.text: What type of speech pathology will be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Rhinolalia aperta/hypernasality will be seen in this condition of cleft palate.

Rhinolalia aperta(hypernasality) is a condition in which words that have little resonance, are resonated in the nose. This occurs when the nasopharynx cannot be cut off from the oropharynx or when there is abnormal communication between the oral and nasal cavities

Rhinilalia clausa (OptionA) is the lack of nasal resonance for words that are normally resonated in the nasal cavity such as m, n, and ng. It occurs due to blockage of the nose or nasopharynx.

Rhinolalia clausa
(Hyponasality)		 Rhinolalia aperta
(Hypernasality)
Common cold Velopharyngeal insufficiency
Nasal allergy Congenitally short soft palate
Nasal polypi Submucous palate
Nasal growth Large nasopharynx
Adenoids Cleft of the soft palate
Nasopharyngeal mass Paralysis of the soft palate
Familial speech pattern Post adenoidectomy
Habitual Oronasal fistula
  Familial speech pattern
  Habitual

Other options:

Option C: Puberphonia is a condition seen in emotionally labile adolescent males. They continue to speak in the prepubertal high-pitched voice. Gutzmann's pressure test is positive when pressing the thyroid prominence in a backward and downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords and produces a low-tone voice. The treatment is speech therapy.

Option D: Androphonia is a voice disorder where a person’s voice sounds unnaturally deep, often resembling a male voice. It typically occurs due to hormonal imbalances, vocal cord abnormalities, or conditions like puberphonia in females.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to you with fatigue & palpitations. She gives a history of 4 spontaneous abortions early during pregnancy & provides a lab report showing very high titers of anti- beta2 glycoprotein 1. On cardiac auscultation, you hear a pansystolic murmur. Which of the following vegetations would you most likely find on Echocardiography?
questions.solution:
The h/o repeated, early spontaneous abortions & lab report showing high titers of anti beta2 glycoprotein1 are strongly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS). With this background, the given presentation of fatigue, palpitations, and finding of the pan-systolic murmur (most likely of MR) should raise a strong suspicion of Libman sack’s endocarditis. It is characterized by very small vegetations, on either or both sides of the valve as given in "Image D".

Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoantibody-mediated acquired thrombophilia characterized by recurrent arterial or venous thrombosis and/or pregnancy morbidity. It primarily affects females. APS may occur alone (primary) or in association with other autoimmune diseases, mainly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (secondary).

The diagnosis of APS should be seriously considered in cases of thrombosis, cerebral vascular accidents in individuals <55 years of age, or pregnancy morbidity in the presence of livedo reticularis or thrombocytopenia.
The presence of at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion is compatible with the diagnosis, in the absence of other thrombophilia causes.

  • Clinical criteria include: Vascular thrombosis defined as one or more clinical episodes of arterial, venous or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ
  • Pregnancy morbidity, defined as:
    • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond the tenth week of gestation
    • One or more premature births of a morphologically normal neonate before the thirty-fourth week of gestation because of eclampsia, severe preeclampsia, or placental insufficiency or
    • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before the tenth week of gestation
  • Laboratory criteria for APS include high titers of any 1 of the following three antiphospholipid antibodies on two occasions, 12 weeks apart.
    • Lupus anticoagulant (LA) - It is measured indirectly byDiluted Russell's viper venom time assay (most specific)
    • Kaolin coagulation time(KCT)
    • prolongation of aPTT
    • Anticardiolipin (aCL) antibody assay (most sensitive)
    • Anti-β2GPI (glycoprotein 1) antibodies assay

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with symptoms of food impaction, dysphagia, and a burning sensation in his chest. Based on the barium swallow image given below, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium swallow image showing the feline esophagus sign are suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Eosinophilic esophagitis is an idiopathic condition commonly affecting the proximal 1/3rd of the esophagus. Eosinophils migrate to the esophagus and contribute to extensive tissue damage and inflammation.  

Clinical features include difficulty in swallowing, food impaction, vomiting, heartburn, and symptoms similar to those of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Non-responsiveness to proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy is often seen. 

Barium swallow shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus. These rings appear similar to stripes on a cat, and the appearance is referred to as the feline esophagus sign. It is thought to be due to contraction of the muscularis mucosae, with the resultant shortening of the esophagus and bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen.

On endoscopy, the esophagus appears narrow and friable with transient or fixed mucosal rings, strictures, and linear furrows. 

The diagnosis requires a biopsy with a histologic finding of >15–20 eosinophils per high-power field. An exclusion diet and steroids help in the management of this condition.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings
Infectious esophagitis Diffuse and involve the proximal esophagus  
HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques, in advance form - adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes.

questions.text: A G3P2 female patient who is an agricultural laborer presents with complaints of fatigue at 36 weeks of gestation.  On examination, pallor and mild pedal edema are present.  Her hemoglobin is 6.7 g%.  What is the most appropriate treatment_____
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for severe anemia (< 7g/dL) in the third trimester (>34 weeks) is blood transfusion. Packed cell volume is used for transfusion to avoid volume overload. 

Indications of blood transfusion in pregnancy

  • Pregnancy <34 weeks
    • Hb <5 g/dL with or without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
    • Hb 5-7 g/dL – in presence of impending heart failure
  • Pregnancy >34 weeks
    • Hb <7 g/dL even without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
    • Severe anaemia with decompensation
  • Anaemia not due to hematinic deficiency
    • Hemoglobinopathy or bone marrow failure syndromes
    • Hematologist should always be consulted
  • Acute haemorrhage
    • Always indicated if Hb <6 g/dL
    • If the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable due to ongoing haemorrhage

Intrapartum Period

  • Hb <7 g/dL (in labor)
  • Decision of blood transfusion depends on medical history or symptoms

Postpartum Period

  • Anemia with signs of shock/acute hemorrhage with signs of hemodynamic instability. Hb <7g% (postpartum)
  • Decision of blood transfusion depends on medical history or symptoms

questions.text: What is the use of the following instrument ?
questions.solution:
The image shows a Placido or Keratoscopic disc which is used for corneal surface assessment. 

There are alternating black and white circles painted on it. The observer (the doctor) looks through a hole in the center at the corneal image reflected from a light behind the patient. Irregularities in the rings indicate irregularities on the corneal surface.

Option A: A pachymeter is used to measure corneal thickness.

Options C: A retinoscopy is used to measure refractive errors.

Option D: A Jackson cross-cylinder is used for the refinement of cylinders.

questions.text: A man presents with a progressive swelling over the past 2 years and the swelling is variable in consistency and appears as in the image. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing the swelling lifting the ear lobe, most likely depicts a case of pleomorphic adenoma.

The most common tumor of the parotid gland is a pleomorphic adenoma.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Slowly growing benign tumor
  • Unicentric in origin
  • Pseudo-capsule present
  • Potentially malignant
  • Possibility of protrusion of fringes of the tumor mass through the capsule
  • Radioresistant
  • Usually affects adults, females > males
  • Painless swelling
  • Well-defined margins
  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard consistency
  • Free from deeper structures
  • No facial nerve involvement
  • Deep lobe pushes tonsils and faucial pillars

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with gout complains of acute onset redness of the eye as given below which is not associated with pain. On further probing, she gives a history of multiple visits to the hospital with the same complaints. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly female with gout presenting with recurrent acute onset redness of the eye not associated with pain and the image showing a nodule away from the limbus surrounded by redness is suggestive of episcleritis.

Episcleritis is benign, recurrent, inflammation of the episclera, involving the overlying Tenon's capsule but not the underlying sclera. It is more common in women than in men. Causes include a hypersensitivity response to internal streptococcal or tubercular toxins. Syphilis, Tuberculosis, Lyme disease, and the herpes zoster virus can all lead to infectious episcleritis. It is also associated with systemic diseases like gout, rosacea, psoriasis and connective tissue diseases.

Episcleritis is characterized by redness, and mild ocular discomfort described as a gritty, burning, or foreign body sensation.

Clinically, two types of presentations may occur:

  • Simple episcleritis is characterized by sectorial or diffuse inflammation of the episclera. The image given below shows diffuse episcleritis:
  • Nodular episcleritis is characterized by a pink or purple flat nodule surrounded by erythema, usually situated 2-3 mm away from the limbus. The nodule is firm, and tender and can be moved separately from the sclera, and the overlying conjunctiva also moves freely.

Treatment includes topical NSAIDs, corticosteroid eye drops, cold compress, and artificial tears. In recurrent cases, systemic NSAIDs are used.

Other options:

Option A: Conjunctivitis is a refers to the inflammation of the conjunctival tissue, engorgement of the blood vessels, pain, and ocular discharge, and is classified as acute or chronic and infectious or noninfectious. Clinically it is associated with pain and discharge from eyes and other features based on etiology

Option B: Tenon's cyst or conjunctival inclusion cyst is a benign condition filled with serous fluid and slimy mucous secretions of congenital or acquired origin. The patient presents with swelling near the limbus with no pain or redness. The consistency is cystic to firm, non-tender with no mobility suggesting that the cyst is adherent to the underlying scleral tissue. The image of Tenon's cyst is given below:

Option D: Scleritis refers to an inflammation of the sclera proper. It usually occurs in elderly patients (40-70 years) involving females more than males. It is frequently associated with an underlying systemic inflammatory condition. The patient presents with moderate to severe pain, redness, lacrimation, photophobia, and diminution of vision.

questions.text: A  primigravida in her 10th week of gestation presents with spotting. On examination, the uterine size corresponds to 12 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound was done and is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with the image is suggestive of a hydatidiform mole. The ultrasonography (USG) image shows the characteristic snowstorm appearance seen in a complete mole. It refers to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces.

Hydatidiform mole is an abnormal condition of the placenta, characterized by partly degenerative and partly proliferative changes in the villi. It is a gestational trophoblastic disease. Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:

Classical clinical features of a complete mole:

  • Abnormal vaginal bleeding
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Features of early-onset preeclampsia
  • Uterus appears large for date
  • Absent fetal parts and FHS
  • Expulsion of vesicular tissues (grape-like vesicles)
  • Theca lutein cyst of ovaries of more than 6 cm
  • Hyperthyroidism (rare)
  • Serum hCG > 100,000 mIU/ml
  • USG - snowstorm appearance

The definitive management after diagnosis is suction and evacuation, after making the cervix favorable.

Other options:

Option A: Blighted ovum (silent miscarriage) occurs when a fertilized egg implants in the uterus but does not develop into an embryo. It is a sonographic diagnosis where there is an absence of a fetal pole in a gestational sac with a diameter of 3 cm or more.

Option B: Missed abortion is when the fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period. USG shows an empty sac early in the pregnancy or the absence of fetal cardiac activity and fetal movements.

Option C: Ectopic pregnancy is one in which the fertilized ovum is implanted and develops outside the normal endometrial cavity. The majority of ectopic pregnancies occur in the fallopian tube, the ampulla being the most common site.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XXX or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: The USG of the gall bladder of a forty-year-old obese female patient appears as below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ultrasonography of the gallbladder shows acoustic shadow, indicating the presence of stone in the gallbladder (cholelithiasis).

Cholelithiasis is commonly seen in women. Over 70% of the gallstones are composed of cholesterol, while the pigment gallstones composed of calcium carbonate constitute most of the remaining 30%.

Radiological features:

X-ray: Only calcified stones are visible.

Ultrasonography:

  • The gallstones appear as echogenic foci, which cast acoustic shadow. Stone mobility may be demonstrated, if it is not impacted.
  • In contrast, a gallbladder polyp is fixed, and does not cast any acoustic shadow.
  • In gallbladder full of stones, there is a dense acoustic shadowing with the presence of two parallel curved echogenic lines separated by a thin anechoic space. This characteristic appearance is referred to as ‘Double-arc shadow sign’, or wall-echo-shadow sign.

The image-below shows wall-echo-shadow sign due to the presence of a large gall stone.

Other options:

Option A: Porcelain gallbladder refers to calcification of the gallbladder wall. The image below shows calcification in the gall bladder wall(on CT) suggestive of a porcelain gall bladder.

Option B: On USG, a gallbladder polyp is fixed, and does not cast any acoustic shadow. The image below shows a gallbladder polyp on USG:

Option C: In emphysematous cholecystitis, intraluminal gas appears as a bright curvilinear echogenic band with ‘dirty’ shadowing. CT scan shows gas within the wall of the gallbladder (shown below).

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was asked to blow-off a paper repeatedly while doing an EEG. The recording shows symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges that begins and ends suddenly, superimposed on a normal EEG background. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a child with a 3Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG, which was provoked by hyperventilation, suggests a diagnosis of absence seizures.

Absence seizures are the most common seizures in children. The electrophysiologic hallmark of typical absence seizures is a generalized, symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharge pattern.

These seizures are characterized by a sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and without post-ictal confusion. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds. The patient presents with subtle, bilateral motor signs such as rapid blinking of the eyelids, chewing movements, or small-amplitude, clonic movements of the hands. These can occur hundreds of times in a day. The child is often misunderstood to be 'daydreaming' and parents are often told that there is a decline in the child's performance at school.

The first line treatment drugs for absent seizures include valproic acid, ethosuximide and lamotrigine. 

Other options:

Option A: Generalised tonic-clonic seizure is characterized by tonic contractions of muscles followed by periods of muscle relaxation (clonic phase). It is associated with unresponsiveness, muscular flaccidity, excessive salivation, and incontinence. The EEG is characterized by an increase in generalized low-voltage fast waves after which generalized high-amplitude, polyspike discharges in the tonic phase. In the clonic phase, a spike and slow-wave pattern are observed. 

Option B: Atonic seizures are characterized by sudden loss of postural muscle tone. Consciousness may not be impaired and postictal confusion is not usually present. The EEG shows generalized spike-wave discharge followed by diffuse slow waves which correspond to the muscle tone. 

Option D: Myoclonic seizures are characterized by sudden and brief contraction of part of or the entire body. The EEG shows synchronous spike-and-slow-wave discharges just before the onset of myoclonic movements.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man sustained a spinal cord injury as a result of a road traffic accident. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg. The patient most likely suffered from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the presence of hypotension associated with the spinal cord injury is suggestive of neurogenic shock.

Neurogenic shock refers to reduced tissue perfusion due to loss of vasomotor tone to peripheral arterial beds. Neurogenic shock is usually secondary to spinal cord injuries due to vertebral body fractures of the cervical or high thoracic region that disrupts the sympathetic regulation of peripheral vascular tone. Loss of vasoconstrictor impulses results in increased vascular capacitance, decreased venous return and decreased cardiac output.

Primary injury in neurogenic shock occurs due to damage to axons and the membrane of neurons. Secondary injury occurs doe to vascular damage hours to days after the primary insult.

The clinical features are bradycardia, temperature dysregulation, hypotension and autonomic dysreflexia. The skin often appears warm and flushed and there is also presence of radiological evidence of vertebral fracture.

Treatment involves securing of airways, adequate ventilation and perfusion with fluids and blood products followed by administration of vasoconstrictors to improve vascular tone. 

Other options:

Option A: Cardiogenic shock is caused due to the failure of the myocardial pump.

Option B: Septic shock is not likely in this clinical scenario, as there is no evidence of any infection.

Option D: Hypovolemic shock is caused due to a significant decrease in blood or plasma volume, caused by the loss of fluid from the vascular compartment. Haemorrhage, fluid loss from severe burns, diarrhea, excessive urine formation, perspiration, and trauma are some of the major mechanisms of fluid loss that can lead to hypovolemic shock.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Doyen’s mouth gag is used to keep the mouth open for intraoral surgery when retraction of the tongue is not required or desirable. Mostly used for tongue surgery. It is applied on one side of the mouth on molar teeth.

Option A: Doyen’s retractor is used to retract abdominal wall in abdominal and pelvic surgeries to expose field of operation.

Option C: Doyen’s intestinal occlusion clamp is used to for resection and anastomosis of intestine in case of

  • Strangulated hernia
  • Accidental injuries to the gut
  • Intestinal growths
  • Gastric/intestinal bypass surgeries

Option D: Joll’s thyroid retractor is a self-retaining retractor used in thyroid surgeries to retract skin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final-year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube?
questions.solution:
The best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube is the end-tidal CO2 concentration assessed by capnography. 

Capnography is a non-invasive method of measurement and graphical display of partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled breath or the end-tidal CO2. Capnograph is the device used for measurement and capnogram is the CO2 waveform that is displayed. It is the most reliable indicator of endotracheal tube placement.

The proper placement of the endotracheal tube is indicated by a normal CO2 waveform for at least three breaths.

Other signs to confirm proper endotracheal intubation are:

Symmetrical chest rise, presence of equal bilateral breath sounds, absent breath sounds over the epigastrium, visible condensation in the ETT, large exhaled tidal volume, and appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation.

Absent CO2 waveform tracing despite correct ETT intubation is seen in the following conditions:

  • Severe bronchospasm,
  • Equipment malfunction,
  • Cardiac arrest, or hemodynamic collapse 

Clinical relevance:

  • Capnography does not differentiate endotracheal from endobronchial intubation. Signs of endobronchial intubation include increased peak expiratory pressure, hypoxemia, increased airway pressures, asymmetric chest expansion and the absence of breath sounds over one lung, generally the left.  
  • In esophageal intubation, the capnograph can initially detect some CO2 in the stomach from swallowing expired air. But after a few breaths, this CO2  will be washed out and ETCO2 will become zero. 
  • The most sensitive and earliest indicator of malignant hyperthermia is a persistent increase in ETCO2.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

questions.text: Given below are the four causes of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) with the corresponding class of a PALM-COEIN classification. Which is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The polycystic ovarian disease is an ovarian cause of abnormal uterine bleeding which comes under AUB-O, in the PALM-COEIN classification.

AUB in the reproductive age group was previously known as dysfunctional uterine bleeding, however, that term is now obsolete. AUB can be acute or chronic:

  • Acute AUB - it can start sporadically or be superimposed on chronic AUB.
  • Chronic AUB - it lasts for 6 months (3 months minimum).

PALM-COEIN classification of AUB:

  • Polyp (AUB-P):
    • Endometrial polyps
    • Endocervical polyps
  • Adenomyosis (AUB-A)
  • Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as:
    • Submucosal (SM)
    • Other (O)
  • Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M) 
    • Endometrial hyperplasia 
    • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Coagulopathy (AUB-C)
    • von Willebrand's disease
    • Hemophilias
  • Ovarian causes (AUB-O)
    • PCOD
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hyperprolactinemia.  
  • Endometrial causes (AUB-E)
    • Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis 
  • Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I)
    • Intrauterine contraceptive devices
    • Anticoagulants
    • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as
    • Arteriovenous malformations 
    • Myometrial hypertrophy

questions.text:
A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next?

Dichorionic Diamniotic (DCDA) twins

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Immediate caesarean section is done as the first twin is in breech presentation. Uncomplicated dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies are terminated at 38 weeks of gestation.

Timing of delivery depends on the type of twin pregnancy:

Type of twin pregnancy Timing of delivery
Dichorionic diamniotic 38 weeks
Monochorionic diamniotic 34 - 37 weeks + 6 days
Monochorionic monoamniotic 32 - 34 weeks by Caesarean section

 Mode of delivery depends on the 1st twin:

1st twin presentation Mode of delivery
Vertex Vaginal
Breech Caesarean section
Transverse Caesarean section

After delivery of 1st twin, if the 2nd twin is in breech, assisted breech delivery is done. If the 2nd twin is in transverse lie, internal podalic version is done under GA in the OT followed by breech extraction.

Complications in attempting vaginal delivery in non-vertex presentation (i.e) transverse and breech:

  • Interlocking of twins
  • Fetal head trapping above the cervix
  • Umbilical cord prolapse

According to ACOG criteria (2019), preeclampsia requires proteinuria of grade 2+ or more. In a case of pre-eclampsia, termination of pregnancy must be done at 37 weeks.

According to the updated criteria, this patient does not have pre-eclampsia. Hence, Caesarean section can be done at 38 weeks as for any uncomplicated DCDA twin pregnancy.

questions.text: A  male patient presented with a femur fracture following a road traffic accident. After 2 days he developed dyspnea, petechiae involving the whole body, and a fall in oxygen saturation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a road traffic accident patient developing dyspnea, petechiae, and drop in saturation following femur fracture is likely suggestive of fat embolism. 

Fat embolism is caused by the fat globules originating from the bone marrow following the fracture of long bones. Clinical features of fat embolism are usually seen within 72 hours. They include tachycardia, fever, breathlessness, petechiae, confusion, and restlessness.

There is no specific test for diagnosis. However, urine analysis was done to look for fat globules and monitor blood pO2. Management of fat embolism is mostly supportive, with oxygen therapy. 

Other options:

Option B: Air embolism occurs when air bubbles entering the pulmonary circulation get absorbed in large quantities. Severe hypotension and hypoxemia are seen in this condition. The patient is placed in Trendelenburg's left lateral decubitus position. 

Option C: Venous thromboembolism consists of pulmonary embolism (PE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Bedridden patients and patients with chronic systemic diseases are more prone to thromboembolism. Clinical features of PE include dyspnea, syncope, cyanosis, hypotension, etc. DVT is presented as leg cramps, erythema, and tenderness. Heparin, LMWH, or fondaparinux are used for the treatment. 

Option D: Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period (e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or machinery). This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites get released to cause reperfusion injury. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. The procoagulants that escaped into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. 

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Axillary or subconjunctival petechiae
  • Hypoxemia with PaO2 <60 mmHg, FIO2 < 0.4
  • CNS depression disproportionate to the hypoxemia
  • Pulmonary edema

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia (HR >110 beats per minute)
  • Pyrexia (temp >38.50C)
  • Emboli visible in retina
  • Fat globules in urine
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Unexplanied drop in hematocrit or platelet count 
  • Increased ESR

 At least one major criterion and four minor criteria are required to make a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: An obese man was posted for bariatric surgery. Which of the following is the inhalational agent of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Desflurane is the inhalational anesthetic agent of choice for this patient.

In obese individuals, the increased fat stores increase the volume of distribution for lipid-soluble drugs when compared to a lean individual of the same body weight. This increases the peripheral distribution of the lipid-soluble agents thus resulting in increased recovery time. There is an increase in the cardiac output in obese individuals that increases the early distribution of the drugs. Hence fat-soluble drugs should be administered based on the total body weight. Water-soluble agents like neuromuscular blockers have a smaller peripheral distribution that is minimally increased by body fat. Therefore, water-soluble agents are dosed based on the ideal body weight.

Among the commonly used inhalational anesthetics, desflurane is the least fat-soluble which leads to a faster recovery. Desflurane is also minimally metabolized by the liver, thereby reducing hepatotoxicity. 

Inhalational agent Blood-gas partition coefficient
Halothane 2.5
Isoflurane 1.4
Sevoflurane 0.65
Desflurane 0.45

Blood-gas partition co-efficient determines the solubility of the anesthetic agent in the blood. The higher the blood-gas partition coefficient, the higher will be the solubility of the anesthetic agent. This leads to its greater uptake by pulmonary circulation. The higher the uptake of the anesthetic agent, the higher the difference between the inspired and alveolar concentrations, which leads to a slower rate of induction and recovery. Desflurane has a very low blood:gas partition coefficient (0.42). Thus, the alveolar and blood concentrations rapidly rise to the level of inspired concentration, providing rapid induction of anesthesia and rapid recovery.

Other options:

Option A- Halothane is a high fat-soluble agent and can result in halothane hepatitis due to increased metabolism in obese individuals. Hence it is avoided.

Option C- Sevoflurane has a relatively higher fat solubility compared to desflurane.

Option D- Isoflurane has a higher fat-gas partition co-efficient resulting in increased recovery time from anesthesia.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice  
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Day care surgery Sevoflurane(preferred)/Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac disease Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane(preferred)/Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

Most potent      

 Methoxyflurane>Halothane 

Least potent     

 Nitrous oxide>Desflurane 

Most epileptogenic  

 Enflurane

Most nephrotoxic  

 Methoxyflurane 

Most hepatotoxic 

 Halothane

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and fever. Examination of the affected breast reveals the findings shown in the image below. Which of the following statements about this condition is incorrect?

choices.text: It is a sequelae of untreated bacterial mastitis
Repeated aspirations may be carried out under antibiotics cover if needed
The earliest sign is the positive fluctuation test
The initial treatment should involve providing pain relief with analgesics

questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, a lactating female presents with fever and pain in the left breast, with examination showing erythema and skin induration, as seen in the image, which is suggestive of a breast abscess. A positive fluctuation test is a late sign of a breast abscess, not an early one

Breast abscess is a sequela of untreated bacterial mastitis (Option A), which occurs due to the growth of staphylococcus or streptococcus due to breast milk stasis. Patients usually present with fever and malaise, localised pain and tenderness, redness and swelling of the affected breast and fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess, which is a late sign of breast abscess.

The initial treatment should involve providing pain relief with analgesics (Option D). The abscess should then be localized preferably under USG guidance and percutaneous aspiration carried out. The pus should be sent for microbiological examination to find the organism and antibiotic sensitivity. Repeated aspirations may be carried out under antibiotics cover if needed(Option B).

In some conditions mentioned below, the breast abscess may be unresponsive to repeated aspiration and antibiotic cover. In such cases, incision and drainage are performed. The conditions include the presence of thick pus, and bacteria resistant to antibiotics. If just a superficial part has been aspirated in the presence of a multiloculated abscess. A non-healing breast abscess due to tuberculosis of the breast, inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, or an immunocompromised host.

The below table summarises likely features to differentiate Bacterial mastitis from a Breast abscess:

  Bacterial mastitis Breast abscess
Condition Localized inflammation
due to an ascending infection 
or infection due to milk stasis 		 Occurs as a complication of mastitis
Pus formation
Symptoms Dull pain Throbbing pain
Signs (if any) Tenderness
Erythema		 Point tenderness
Erythema
Induration of skin(if chronic)
Lymphadenopathy
Fluctuation test +ve
Management Analgesics
Antibiotics		 Analgesic
Aspiration of Pus
Antibiotics

The image below shows mastitis of the breast.

questions.text: A patient was asked to copy the face of a clock and his drawing is shown below. What is the correct term to be used here?
questions.solution:
Hemispatial neglect is the inability to report, respond, or orient to stimuli in one-half of the space despite having no motor or sensory deficits. 

A patient with neglect is asked to draw a clock, their drawing might show only the numbers 12 to 6, or all 12 numbers might be on one half of the clock face with the other half distorted or blank, like the image shown in the image below.

  

Neglect patients may also ignore the contralesional side of their body; for instance, they might only shave, or apply makeup to, the non-neglected side. These patients may frequently collide with objects or structures such as door frames on the side being neglected.

Other options:

Option A: Confabulation is a phenomenon in which the patient fills in memory gaps with inaccurate information. Further investigating the statement made by the patients may reflect past experiences or bizarre, fantastic stories.  This fabrication of false information is not done on purpose.

Option C: Apraxia: Inability to perform a movement or task when asked despite having the desire and physical capability to carry it out.

Types of apraxia:

  1. Kinetic: Inability to execute the fine acquired motor movement, the lesion is in the precentral cortex.
  2. Ideomotor: Fails to perform on command. The lesion is in the parietal lobe.
  3. Constructional: liability to reproduce simple geometric figures by drawing. The lesion is in the pathway between the occipital or parietal area.
  4. Ideational: Loss of ability to formulate an ideational plan for the execution of the complex act. The lesion is in the dominant parietal lobe.

Option D: Astrexis/Flapping tremor is a type of negative myoclonus characterized by irregular lapses of the posture of various body parts. Mostly associated with hepatic encephalopathy.

questions.text: A young male who is a professional trumpet blower presented with a swelling on the left side of the neck. On examination, there is a gurgling sound while compressing the swelling. X-ray of the neck is seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image along with the examination finding of Bryce's sign is suggestive of laryngocoele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling in the neck due to dilatation of the saccule. It is more commonly seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to a raised transglottic air pressure in these people. It can be classified into internal, external, or combined types of laryngocele.

  • Internal laryngocele is limited within the larynx and appears as a distension of the false cord and aryepiglottic fold.
  • External laryngocele has a distended saccule that herniates through the thyrohyoid membrane and appears as a swelling in the neck.
  • Combined or mixed laryngocele has both internal and external laryngoceles as its components where the air-filled sac extends both within the larynx and externally through the thyrohyoid membrane into the neck, and potentially into the mediastinum.

It presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and airway obstruction (if large). External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck that increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the neck swelling, a gurgling sound is heard, indicating a positive Bryce's sign. Adult laryngoceles can be associated with carcinoma.

Diagnosis is based on an indirect laryngoscopy and CT scan. Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and external laryngocele is managed by a surgical excision through an external neck incision.

Other options:

Option A: The pharyngeal pouch(Zenker diverticulum) is a pulsion-pseudodiverticulum and results from herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle (or dehiscence of Killian). Killian's triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibres of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibres of the thyropharyngeus.

Option C: A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal fistula communication between the oesophagus and the trachea. Type C lesion is associated with proximal oesophagal atresia and distal TEF, the proximal blind pouch ends approximately at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF.

Option D: The tonsillar cyst is due to blockage of a tonsillar crypt and appears as a yellowish swelling over the tonsil. Very often it is symptomless. It can be easily drained.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient, an accident victim started developing difficulty in breathing. On examination, his BP was 80/40mmHg, pulses were feeble. JVP was found to be elevated with an absent 'y descent', and heart sounds were muffled. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with Beck's triad including hypotension, muffled heart sounds and elevated JVP suggests a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. 

Symptoms of cardiac tamponade include dyspnea, chest discomfort or fullness, peripheral edema, and fatigue. Examination findings are:

  • Tachycardia and hypotension
  • Jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent
  • Pericardial rub
  • Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration
  • Beck's triad: Distended neck veins, muffled heart sounds and hypotension.

An eFAST is reliable and will show fluid in the pericardial space. A chest X-ray will show an enlarged heart shadow. ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electric alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction.

Management of cardiac tamponade:

  • Emergency management - ultrasound-guided needle pericardiocentesis via subxiphoid route 
  • Definitive management - emergency thoracotomy or sternotomy

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following routes of administration in the descending order of systemic absorption of local anesthetic.
  1. Subcutaneous injection
  2. Injection into brachial plexus
  3. Intercostal nerve blockade 
  4. Injection into lumbar epidural space
questions.solution:
Routes of administration in the descending order of systemic absorption of local anesthetic:

  1. Intercostal nerve blockade 
  2. Injection into the caudal epidural space
  3. Injection into lumbar epidural space
  4. Injection into brachial plexus
  5. Subcutaneous injection

Systemic absorption of local anesthetic is determined by the

  • Site of injection and its tissue blood perfusion
  • Dosage and volume of drug administered
  • Vasoconstrictor agent addition
  • The pharmacologic properties of the agent itself

Exposure to an area of greater vascularity would result in a greater rate and degree of absorption of local anesthetic. The clinical significance of this is that the use of a fixed dose of a local anesthetic agent can be potentially toxic in one area of administration but not in others.

Ex:- Lidocaine without epinephrine for an intercostal nerve block results in average peak venous plasma levels that are sufficiently high to cause symptoms of CNS toxicity. But the same dose of lidocaine when used for a brachial plexus block results in blood levels that are rarely associated with toxicity.

 

Related Pearl: Systemic Absorbtion of Local Anaesthetic in the Order of Occurrence

Systemic absorption of a local anesthetic depends on vascularity.

And thereby highest blood concentrations are seen following

  • Intravenous (intraarterial) injection, followed by
  • Tracheal injection
  • Intercostal nerve blockade
  • Paracervical
  • Caudal epidural block
  • Lumbar epidural block
  • Brachial plexus block
  • Sciatic block
  • and is least with subcutaneous injection

questions.text: Patients with chronic rhinosinusitis are more prone to develop mucoceles. Which of the following sinuses is commonly involved in this complication?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and findings are suggestive of a mucocele secondary to frontal sinusitis.

The frontal sinus is most commonly involved in mucocele formation. The sinuses commonly affected by mucocele in the order of frequency are the frontal>ethmoidal>maxillary>sphenoid.

Mucoceles are slow-growing, mucous-filled benign masses that can develop years after head injury. Post-traumatic mucocele formation occurs due to chronic obstruction of the sinus ostium. The frontal sinus is most commonly involved in mucocele formation. Frontal mucocele presents with headache, diplopia, and proptosis. A cystic non-tender swelling is noticed with eggshell crackling.

The image given below shows a coronal MRI demonstrating a frontal mucocele and an orbital cystic mass.

questions.text: The following triangle is related to _____.
questions.solution:
The image depicts Passaro’s triangle. Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this region.

Related Pearl: Passaro’s Triangle

Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this triangle.

Its boundaries are as follows:

  • Cystic duct
  • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum
  • Junction of the body and neck of the pancreas

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with gout is asked to undergo the radiological test shown below. What is this imaging modality called?
questions.solution:
The above imaging modality is dual-energy CT (DECT).

Dual-energy CT allows for the analysis of energy-dependent variations in the attenuation of various materials by using two distinct X-ray spectra to obtain two image datasets of the same anatomic region. 

It enables material separation to distinguish uric acid crystals from calcium to determine the composition of urinary calculi and diagnose gout.

With the help of a DECT scan, the calcium crystals are coloured blue, while the uric acid crystals are coloured green, making gout diagnosis simple and non-invasive. DECT can also be used to quantify the overall tophus burden or volume of urate deposition without any user variability. This makes DECT an ideal tool for assessing any variation in tophus burden and enables follow-up to record treatment response.

Uses of DECT include:

  • Detection and quantification of urate crystals in gout
  • Characterization of renal stones, cysts and masses 
  • Identification of silicone leaks from breast implants.
  • Detection of bone marrow edema
  • Detection of pulmonary embolism
  • Detection of myocardial ischemia 

Gout is characterized by an inflammatory reaction that results in the formation of gouty tophi and arthropathy when monosodium urate (MSU) crystals are deposited in the soft tissue and joints. A definitive diagnosis necessitates the microscopic identification of MSU crystals through joint fluid aspiration, an invasive procedure that could yield false negative results.

Other options

Option B: Dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI refers to the serial MRI acquisitions following IV contrast agents.

Option C: Single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) is a nuclear medicine imaging technique that uses gamma-emitting radioisotopes(tracers) like technetium-99(99mTc) -hexamethylpropyleneamine oxime (HMPAO). These radiotracers are used to investigate cerebrovascular diseases and epilepsy. 

The image below shows a SPECT CT depicting hyperactivity of tibial physis in a growing child:


Option D: Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) is a variation of diffusion-weighted imaging, where the diffusion of the fluid, is assessed in six or more directions. It helps to identify the location, orientation, and anisotropy of the white matter tracts of the brain.

questions.text: A middle-aged man came to the casualty with a history of pelvic trauma following a road traffic accident. You are asked to apply a pelvic binder to this patient. At what level is the pelvic binder applied?
questions.solution:
The pelvic binder should be applied at the level of greater trochanters of the hip.

The pelvic binder is routinely used as the initial management of pelvic injuries especially if associated with polytrauma, external bleeding, or hemodynamic instability. The use of a pelvic binder has almost eliminated the use of external fixators on the pelvis.

The pelvic binder acts by closing the pelvis volume and thereby providing temporary hemodynamic stability to the patient. Nonetheless, further assessment through radiological investigations such as x-ray pelvis AP view and CT pelvis 3-D reconstruction is important for further definitive management of pelvic injuries.

Ideally binders should not be left for more than 24 hours in view of pressure sores , but if there is no availability of an emergency facility to stabilize the hemodynamic compromise then it can be momentarily released to check for pressure sores and then reapplied if necessary. During radiological assessments like X-ray or CT scan, the pelvic binder is released after positioning the patient in order to assess the extent of pelvic injury as the pelvic binder might falsely underestimate the severity of the injury.

questions.text: In the gynaecology operation theater, preparation for a female sterilization procedure is being made. You notice the instrument in the image below placed on the table. What procedure is going to be performed?
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a falope ring applicator. It is used in laparoscopic tubal ligation. 

Falope ring sterilization is accomplished by applying elastic bands or a falope ring to the fallopian tubes.

The falope ring applicator’s tongs are opened and positioned around the tube approximately 3cm away from the cornu, where the silastic falope ring is applied. It draws up a portion of the tube and then pushes the ring onto the loop of the fallopian tube.

The major advantage is the elimination of thermocoagulation, as the Silastic ring controls most of the bleeding associated with the procedure. The occlusion is complete in a short segment and offers theoretical possibilities of tubal reconstruction. Other methods of laparoscopic tube sterilization include filshie clip sterilization and hulka clip sterilization.

Other options:

Option B: Madlener operation: A loop of the tube is crushed and ligated with a nonabsorbable suture.

Option C: Uchida method: The serosa is stripped off the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube, and then is excised. The proximal end is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. The minimal excision of the tube preserves the potential for tuboplasty.

Option D: Pomeroy technique: It is the most popular technique of tubal ligation. The fallopian tube is identified, exposed through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop, tied at the base with catgut and excised. Failure of the procedure may later occur due to spontaneous canalization. The operation is simple, requires short hospitalization, and can be performed in a primary health centre. It is surgically reversible.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the hospital with fever, malaise, and arthralgia for a 1-month duration. She also complains of pain, numbness, and weakness in her right arm which has been increasing over the past 1 week. Clinical examination reveals weak radial pulses and her lab investigations show elevated ESR. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features with marked weakening of pulse in the upper extremities and laboratory findings of elevated ESR are suggestive of Takayasu arteritis. It is also known as pulseless disease. 

Takayasu arteritis is a systemic disease and may present with generalised and vascular symptoms. It commonly affects adolescents or young females. Generalised symptoms like fever, night sweats, weight loss, malaise, arthralgias, and anorexia, may occur long before vascular symptoms.

Vascular symptoms depend on the vessel involved:

  • Arch of the aorta and its branches:
    • Subclavian artery (most commonly affected) - leads to weak pulses in the upper extremities. Hence it is also known as pulseless disease. May also lead to Raynaud’s phenomenon.
    • Carotid arteries- leads to weak pulses, blindness, and neurological deficits.
    • Aortic arch- may lead to congestive heart failure
  • Abdominal aorta, celiac axis and superior mesenteric artery- leads to abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting
  • Iliac vessels- leads to claudication of the legs
  • Renal arteries- leads to systemic hypertension
  • Pulmonary artery- leads to pulmonary hypertension
  • Coronary arteries (least commonly affected) - lead to myocardial infarction

Investigations:

  • Lab reports reveal an elevated ESR level, anemia, and elevated immunoglobulin levels.
  • Arteriography is done as a confirmatory test.

Treatment includes glucocorticoid therapy, methotrexate, immunotherapy with anti-TNF agents, and surgery. 

Other options:

Option A: Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital narrowing of the aorta, leading to upper limb hypertension and weak or delayed femoral pulses (radio-femoral delay). Patients may also present with headaches, nosebleeds, and claudication in the lower limbs.

Option B: Giant cell arteritis is a vasculitis affecting large arteries, commonly presenting with temporal headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, and vision loss. It is often associated with elevated ESR and systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue.

Option D: Syphilitic aortitis, a complication of tertiary syphilis, involves inflammation of the aorta, leading to aortic aneurysm, aortic regurgitation, or narrowing of the coronary ostia. Clinical features include chest pain, dyspnea, and signs of heart failure.

Related Pearl: Important Vasculitis with Features

Vasculitis

Predominant vessel involved

Inflammatory cells

Other features

Temporal arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

Temporal, vertebral and ophthalmic arteries, aorta

Lymphocytes, and macrophages

>40 years old, polymyalgia rheumatica, granulomas, giant cells

Takayasu Arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Medium-sized and large arteries) Aortic arch, great vessels, pulmonary artery, coronary and renal arteries

Lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, granulomas, giant cells

Pulseless disease

 

Polyarteritis Nodosa

Small or medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Spares pulmonary vessels, 30% of patients with  chronic hepatitis B

Microscopic polyangiitis

Capillaries, small arterioles, venules

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Necrotizing glomerulonephritism (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis leukocytoclastic vasculitis

Churg-Strauss Syndrome

Medium and small arteries

 

Eosinophils (required), lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils

Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

questions.text: An abdominal X-ray of a baby presenting with abdominal distension and hematochezia reveals air in the bowel wall. What is the greatest risk factor for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a baby presenting with abdominal distension and hematochezia, with X-ray findings of pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall) is suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Prematurity is the greatest risk factor for developing NEC.

NEC is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in newborns. It is characterized by mucosal or transmural inflammation resulting in necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. Three major risk factors implicated are prematurity (the greatest risk factor), formula feeding, and bacterial colonization of the intestine.

Babies usually present within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal X-ray. The important signs are pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall), portal vein gas, and pneumoperitoneum (indicates perforation).

The given X-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis (black arrows).

Management of NEC includes supportive measures like keeping the baby nil per oral (NPO), nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication for surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G2P1L1 woman is 18 weeks pregnant. She mentions that her previous labor was prolonged and tedious and eventually the doctor used an instrument to deliver her first child. Which of the following measurements would point towards the diagnosis of cephalo-pelvic disproportion at the pelvic inlet?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis as cephalo-pelvic disproportion (CPD). Cephalo-pelvic disproportion at the pelvic inlet is diagnosed when the diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm.

Disproportion with respect to the maternal pelvis is a state where the normal proportion between the size of the fetus to the size of the pelvis is disturbed. The disparity in the relation between the head and the pelvis is called cephalopelvic disproportion.

It can either occur due to an average size baby with a small pelvis or a relatively large baby with a normal pelvis. A history of prolonged or tedious labor, followed by either spontaneous or difficult instrumental delivery is suggestive of pelvic contraction. Difficult vaginal delivery ending in a stillborn or neonatal death without any etiological factor also suggests a contracted pelvis. Past history of fracture, rickets, osteomalacia, tuberculosis of the pelvic joints or spines, and poliomyelitis is elicited.

CPD can occur at the inlet, mid pelvis, or at the pelvic outlet. It is diagnosed at these levels by the following measurements.

  • Inlet CPD
    • Anteroposterior diameter < 10 cm
    • Diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm
    • Transverse diameter < 12 cm.
  • Midpelvis CPD
    • Sum of the interspinous and posterior sagittal diameters of the mid pelvis </= 13.5 cm
    • Interspinous diameter < 8 cm
  • Outlet CPD
    • Interischial diameter </= 8 cm.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presented with nausea, vomiting, and constipation. He also has excess thirst and polyuria. On examination, he has an altered mental state. His past medical history is significant for lung cancer, which is now in remission.  His blood reports reveal elevated serum calcium levels and low serum parathyroid hormone. What is the most common type of underlying lung cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts the symptoms of hypercalcemia as a paraneoplastic syndrome in association with underlying squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

Hypercalcemia results from ectopic production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) or PTH-related peptides. It is the most common life-threatening metabolic complication of malignancy, primarily occurring with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

Clinical manifestation of hypercalcemia:

  • Renal - polyuria, polydipsia, nephrolithiasis
  • Central nervous system - lethargy, altered mental status, stupor, coma
  • Gastrointestinal - Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, abdominal pain, constipation, peptic ulcer disease, pancreatitis
  • Cardiac - bradycardia, AV block, short QT interval
  • Skeletal - bone pain, pathological fractures

Treatment:

  1. Volume expansion by intravenous normal saline (4-6L)
  2. Intravenous Bisphosphonates (Zoledronic acid, pamidronate)
  3. Others - Denosumab, gallium nitrate, steroids.

Paraneoplastic syndromes - may be the presenting finding or the first sign of recurrence of malignancy.

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with Lung cancer:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)
  • Hypercalcemia
Small cell lung cancer (SCLC)
  • Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) 
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Eaton- Lambert syndrome
  • Retinal blindness
Adenocarcinoma 
  • Hypertrophic primary osteoarthropathy
Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)
  •  Clubbing

questions.text: Identify the incision for appendicectomy.
questions.solution:
The given incision is the Lanz incision is a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centred on the midclavicular–mid inguinal line

Other options:

Option A: Gridiron incision: Oblique muscle splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. Also called as Mc Burney incision.

Option C: Rutherford–Morrison incision: oblique muscle cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary(Shown on the left side in the image for the sake of clarity)

Option D: Rockey–Davis incision: Transverse right lower quadrant incision.

questions.text: A man presents to the ER with a gunshot wound to the abdomen as shown below. On examination, the peritoneum is breached. BP is 114/78 mmHg and HR is 80 bpm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for a patient with a gunshot wound to the anterior abdominal wall with a breach of the peritoneum is laparotomy.

The incidence of significant injury to the intraperitoneal organs increases manifold when there is a breach of the peritoneum due to any penetrating trauma injury. The indications for doing laparotomy in patients with penetrating abdominal wounds include:

  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Gunshot wound which breaches the peritoneum
  • Evisceration
  • Bleeding from the stomach, rectum, or genitourinary tract following penetrating trauma
  • Peritonitis
  • Free air in the peritoneal cavity
  • Diagnostic peritoneal lavage has bile, gastrointestinal contents or ≥10 cc of blood

CT scan of the abdomen (option B) should be performed in patients with blunt or penetrating abdominal trauma, provided they are hemodynamically stable and have no indication for immediate laparotomy. The patient in question has a gunshot wound to the anterior abdominal wall with a peritoneal breach, which is an indication for exploratory laparotomy as it carries a high risk of organ injury. FAST (option C) is primarily indicated in patients with blunt abdominal trauma with or without hemodynamic instability. It is not a sensitive investigation to detect hollow visceral injury in patients with penetrating abdominal trauma. There is no role for observation (option D) in this patient.

questions.text: You are on duty in the Gastroenterology department for super specialty rotations as a second-year resident, evaluating patients for upper and lower gastrointestinal lesions. What will be your diagnosis of the endoscopic images given below?

choices.text: A- Barrett's esophagus, B- Mallory Weiss tear
A- Mallory Weiss tear, B- Barrett's esophagus
A- Crohn’s Disease, B- Ulcerative Colitis
A- Ulcerative Colitis, B- Crohn’s Disease

questions.solution:
Image A is of ulcerative colitis and image B is of Crohn's disease.

The given image A shows continuous involvement of mucosa with no normal mucosa in between which indicates ulcerative colitis. Fistula is not a complication of ulcerative colitis. 

Image B shows a cobblestone appearance seen in Crohn's disease. Normal mucosa in between the ulcers leads to this appearance. Fine granular mucosa is the earliest barium enema finding in Ulcerative colitis. Fistula is seen with Crohn’s disease.

Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the mucosal lining of the swallowing tube that connects the mouth to the stomach (esophagus) becomes damaged by acid reflux, which causes the lining to thicken and become red. It is associated with an increased risk of developing esophageal cancer.

A Mallory-Weiss tear is a tear of the tissue of your lower esophagus most often caused by violent coughing or vomiting.

questions.text: A child presents with pinpoint ecchymoses around the hair follicles and painful swelling of the knee joint. He also has tender nodules on the rib as seen in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing scorbutic rosary are suggestive of scurvy.

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C. Vitamin C is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline that are used in the synthesis of collagen. Hence, a deficiency of vitamin C leads to the formation of defective collagen. 

Defective collagen causes vascular fragility leading to capillary haemorrhages. This can manifest as painful hemarthrosis, subperiosteal haemorrhage and pinpoint ecchymoses around the hair follicles called perifollicular haemorrhages. It also results in defective osteoid formation.

Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, also known as a scorbutic rosary. Rickets also presents with similar nodules at the costochondral junctions known as a rachitic rosary. They can be differentiated as the scorbutic rosary is more sharply angulated and rickets do not have bleeding manifestions seen in scurvy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: You notice the senior resident in the surgery outpatient department advising a patient to use the following treatment option for his condition. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given image shows elastic compression stockings. Among the given options, varicose veins is the condition the patient is most likely to have. 

Elastic compression stockings are commonly prescribed for the treatment of chronic venous insufficiency manifesting as venous ulcers or varicose veins. The principal cause of venous insufficiency is venous hypertension. This venous hypertension can be decreased by compression stockings. It helps to push the blood from superficial engorged veins into the deep veins, thus improving the blood-pumping function of the calf muscle. Hence, it decreases edema and improves tissue oxygenation. 

Complications of this therapy include skin excoriation, dryness, skin maceration, and infection. 

Varicose veins are tortuous dilatation of veins due to venous insufficiency. It commonly presents as lower limb swelling with a sensation of heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb. Diagnosis is majorly done using duplex ultrasound and very rarely involves MR venography or intravenous ultrasound (IVUS). 

Treatment is achieved using modalities such as compression, laser ablation, endothermal ablation, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous glue, ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, and open surgery.

The image attached below sums up the therapeutic principle behind compression therapy for venous insufficiency.

Other options-

Option A: Raynaud's disease refers to an abnormal sensitivity in the arteriolar response to cold. These vessels constrict and the digits (usually the fingers) turn white and become incapable of fine movements. The capillaries then dilate and fill with slowly flowing deoxygenated blood. Compression will have no effect on these symptoms. Protection from cold can help. 

An image of Raynaud's phenomenon is shown below.

Option B: Diabetic foot also occurs as a result of peripheral neuropathy and atherosclerosis of small arteries in the legs and feet. Hence, improving venous circulation with compression stockings will have no benefit in this condition. 

Option C: Buerger's disease or thromboangiitis obliterans involves occlusive disease of small- and medium-sized arteries, thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins, and Raynaud’s syndrome. It occurs in male smokers, usually under the age of 30 years. It is an arterial occlusive disorder, so compression stockings will have no therapeutic effect.

The image showing gangrene of the first three toes points toward the diagnosis of thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease). Vasodilators have no role in improving circulation in the affected limb in this condition.

Related Pearl: Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease
