Telangiectases are less than 1 mm, reticular veins are between 1 and 3 mm, and varicose veins are greater than 3 mm measured in the upright position.

questions.text: A patient at 34 weeks of gestation is brought with decreased attention, clumsiness while walking, and headache since 12 hours. BP is found to be 190/110 mmHg. MRI of the brain shows areas of hypointensity on T1 flair in the occipital region. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient at 34 weeks of gestation now presents with altered sensorium and high blood pressure. The presence of hypointensities on T1 weighted MRIs in the occipital region makes posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome the likely diagnosis. 

PRES (Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome)can occur with head injury, migraine, seizures, eclampsia and in the postpartum period. It is a hyperperfusion state with widespread segmental vasoconstriction and cerebral edema. Patients present with headaches and fluctuating neurologic signs and symptoms, especially visual symptoms.

MRI shows edema predominantly in the occipital lobes, seen as hypointensities on T1 flair. It can be generalized, but it is not confined to any single vascular territory. Ischaemia reverses completely.

Treatment is by slowly reducing the high blood pressure with IV drugs.

Other options: 

Option A: A Cerebrovascular accident can present with loss of function or weakness of limbs, signs of ataxia, or loss of sensory signaling based on the region affected due to ischemia or bleeding. However, this patient has no history of weakness, and the findings of the MRI make PRES more likely. 

Option C: Cerebral venous thrombosis presents with similar symptoms however, MRI will show a clot visible. Hypointensities in the posterior lobe is characteristic of PRES.

Option D: Subarachnoid hemorrhage can present with similar features but MRI will show a hyperintensity in the subarachnoid region on T1 flair

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with the following finding. The discharge from the affected site was positive for Nagler's reaction. Which of the following is not true regarding the tests used for detecting the causative organisms?

choices.text: Shows stormy fermentation on litmus milk test
Shows target hemolysis on blood agar
Elek’s gel precipitation test is positive

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens. Elek’s gel precipitation test is an immunodiffusion test used to check the toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, not Clostridium perfringens.

Gas gangrene is caused most often by Clostridium perfringens species. Microscopically it is a gram-positive bacteria without spores (sporulates only outside the human body). Naegler's test is a quick test to show the presence of Clostridium. Sample collection and transport are to be done in Robertson's cooked meat medium.

It is an anaerobe and grows well on Blood agar showing target hemolysis (Option B). A narrow zone of complete hemolysis due to θ-toxin and a wider zone of incomplete hemolysis due to α-toxin results in the development of target hemolysis on blood agar by C. perfringens.

In the reverse CAMP test (Option C), C.perfringens is streaked over the center of the plate and Streptococcus agalactiae is streaked at right angles to it. A positive reverse CAMP test shows the presence of an arrow-shaped zone of enhanced hemolysis pointing towards C.perfringens. α-toxin produced by C.perfringens interacts with the CAMP factor and produces synergistic hemolysis. 

In the litmus milk test fermentation of lactose by Clostridium leads to the formation of acid which coagulates the casein in litmus milk. The clotted milk is disrupted due to vigorous gas production and this characteristic finding is obtained that is called stormy fermentation.

Nagler's test is a quick test to show the presence of Clostridium. The α-toxin of C. perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C. perfringens is grown on a media containing egg yolk with the α-antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of α-toxin. This is known as Nagler's reaction.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident.  He is tachypneic and uses accessory neck muscles for respiration. His BP is 90/60 mm Hg. On percussion, the right chest is hyper-resonant. On auscultation, breath sounds could not be heard on the right chest. An urgent chest X-ray is done. What is the definitive management?

choices.text: Chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety
Needle decompression at 5th intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line

questions.solution:
The above patient with hemodynamic instability, tachypnea and hyper-resonant sounds on percussion with absent breath sounds on auscultation along with the radiolucency and mediastinal shift on X-ray is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. Definitive management is chest tube insertion or tube thoracostomy in the 5th  intercostal space(ICS)in the triangle of safety.

Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening emergency when air leaks from the lungs into the pleural cavity and cannot escape. This leads to compression of the lung field with mediastinal shift and collapse of lung parenchyma.

Management of tension pneumothorax:

  • Immediate management with needle decompression (Option C) or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line.
  • Definitive management includes tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety, identified as a triangle that lies anterior to the mid-axillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

The boundaries of the triangle of safety are:

  • Anteriorly - lateral border of the pectoralis major.
  • Posteriorly- latissimus dorsi.
  • Inferiorly- a line perpendicular to the nipple going to the back.

Note: According to ATLS 10th edition,

  • For adults, the location of needle thoracostomy or needle decompression has been changed to the 5th ICS, anterior to the midaxillary line from the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • For the pediatric age group, the location of needle thoracostomy remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
The images below show the triangle of safety and technique of chest drain insertion.

Other options:

Option A: Endotracheal intubation is an invasive procedure done in patients who are unable to maintain their airways. 

Option D: Pericardiocentesis is done in cases of cardiac tamponade which is characterized by the presence of hypotension, distended jugular veins, and muffled heart sounds (Beck's triad). The breath sounds are absent in tension pneumothorax while they are present in cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. On examination, there is a firm purplish mass on the left posterior choanae. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma and the most appropriate step in its management is surgical excision.

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma(JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumour seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality. 

Patients usually present with, profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis (most common presentation). A mass may be present in either the postnatal space, resulting in progressive nasal obstruction, or nasopharynx, where it may obstruct both choanae. The mass is firm in consistency, but digital palpation of the same should not be done. If the mass obstructs the eustachian tube, conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion may be observed. Proptosis, swelling of the cheeks, broadening of the nasal bridge, and involvement of 2nd, 3rd, 4th and 6th cranial nerves may occur.

JNA can be diagnosed using CT, MRI, and carotid angiography. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus due to the presence of a mass in the pterygomaxillary space is a characteristic CT finding of JNA. This is known as the Holman-Miller sign or antral sign, as shown in the image below.

Surgical excision is the treatment of choice though radiotherapy and chemotherapy monotherapy or in combination have also been used. Radiotherapy(Option C) is considered for recurrent inaccessible tumours. Chemotherapy with doxorubicin, vincristine, and dacarbazine is used in the case of very aggressive recurrent tumours and residual tumours. Hormonal therapy can be used as a primary or adjunctive treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not likely to cause an abnormal sign pertaining to the clinical finding being tested in the image below?
questions.solution:
By asking the patient to keep the dorsal surfaces of his fingers opposed (Schamroth sign), the finding being elicited is clubbing. Clubbing is seen in conditions like lung abscess, cystic fibrosis, and aortic aneurysm, but not in irritable bowel syndrome.

Digital clubbing is a focal bulbous enlargement of the terminal segments of the fingers and/or toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue between the nail matrix and the distal phalanx. Clubbed fingers are also known as watch-glass nails, drumstick fingers, and Hippocratic fingers/nails.

Hypoxia causes increased release of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). This leads to increased vascularity, permeability, and connective tissue changes.

The image below shows clubbing.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: It is performed by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, but this window is obliterated in clubbed fingers. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: It is the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, this angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.
  • Hyponychial angle: This is constructed by drawing a line from the distal digital crease to the cuticle and another line from the cuticle to the hyponychium (the thickened stratum corneum of the epidermis under the free edge of the nail). The normal angle is less than 192°.
  • Phalangeal depth ratio: This is defined by the ratio of the digit's depth measured at the nail bed and distal interphalangeal joint. Normally, the depth at the distal interphalangeal joint is more than that at the nail bed. A phalangeal depth ratio of more than 1 is indicative of clubbing.
  • Digital index: This is the sum of the phalangeal depth ratios for all 10 fingers. A digital index of 10.2 or more is indicative of clubbing. This is more specific for clubbing than pharyngeal depth ratio.

The causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Diffuse pulmonary disease - pulmonary fibrosis, asbestosis
  • GI
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • CNS
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient who is known to have Bell's palsy presented with dryness in her left eye. Ocular examination reveals mild punctate epithelial defects and dryness of the cornea. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with clinical features of dry eye and unilateral facial nerve palsy (Bell's palsy) likely has a diagnosis of exposure keratopathy. 

Exposure keratopathy is the drying of the cornea despite normally produced tears. It occurs due to incomplete eyelid closure, also known as lagophthalmos.

Lagophthalmos can be caused by conditions such as facial nerve palsy, parkinsonism (reduced muscle tone), lid scarring, and proptosis. 

Clinical features include dry eyes, symptoms, and signs of mild punctate epithelial changes and epithelial breakdown. 

Treatment depends on whether the exposure is reversible or permanent. Reversible exposure can be treated with artificial tears and eye ointments. The eyelid can be taped closed at night or external barriers like bandage silicone hydrogel or scleral contact lenses can be used. Permanent exposure requires permanent tarsorrhaphy.

Other options: 

Option B - Neurotrophic keratopathy is the loss/reduction of corneal sensation that occurs due to loss of innervation by the trigeminal nerve. It may be due to stroke, trigeminal ganglion ablation for neuralgia, diabetes, etc. 

Option C - Mooren ulcer is an autoimmune disorder that results in progressive peripheral corneal ulceration. This is characterized by severe pain and the involvement of the superficial one-third of the corneal stroma.

Option D - Herpes simplex keratitis is caused by the Herpes simplex virus (HSV). The patient complains of ocular discomfort, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity. HSV can cause characteristic epithelial (dendritic/geographic) keratitis or disciform keratitis. 

The below image shows the characteristic dendritic ulcers of herpes simplex keratitis-

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents with the features shown in the image below. Brain MRI revealed pedunculated hypothalamic hamartoma. All of the following statements regarding this condition are true except:

choices.text: Hypothalamic hamartomas are nonneoplastic developmental lesions
Premature activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis
GnRH antagonist is used in the treatment of this condition
Induce early bone maturation and reduce eventual adult height

questions.solution:
A 4-year-old girl exhibiting breast development, as shown in the image, presented with precocious puberty. GnRH agonists are used in the treatment of this condition 

Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years.

GnRH agonists are the treatment of choice for precocious puberty.

  • Hypothalamic hamartomas are nonneoplastic developmental lesions that are usually histologically normal in appearance, but ectopic in position (Option A)
  • These lesions are believed to cause precocious puberty through the endogenous pulsatile release of GnRH, either independently or in concert with the GnRH-secreting neurons of the hypothalamus.
  • Premature activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis (Option B) manifests as gonadotropin-dependent precocious puberty.
  • Early sexual development in children warrants evaluation because it may:
    • Induce early bone maturation and reduce eventual adult height, (Option D)
    • Indicate the presence of a tumor or other serious problem
  • One possible treatment is with anastrozole. Histrelin acetate (Supprelin LA), triptorelin or leuprolide, any GnRH agonists, may be used.

Understanding the rationale behind the use of GnRH agonist in the treatment of precocious puberty:

The normal:

  • GnRH neurons are normally inhibited by the CNS until puberty.
  • At the time of puberty (7-8 years for girls, and 9 years for boys), the GnRH neurons escape the inhibition and starts releasing the GnRH in a pulsatile manner.

Effect of pulsatile vs non-pulsatile secretion

  • Pulsatile secretion of GnRH causes stimulation of FSH and LH production.
  • On the other hand, if there is continuous, non-pulsatile release of GnRH, it has the opposite effect, which causes inhibition of FSH and LH, and may cause hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Uses of GnRH agonist :

  • Continuous administration of GnRH is indicated in the treatment of central precocious puberty. The GnRH agonists are continued until 11 years of age in females and 12 years of age in males. 
  • GnRH agonists are also used in the management of advanced breast and ovarian carcinomas and to induce gonadal suppression in men with prostate cancer.

questions.text: A primigravida woman underwent a normal vaginal delivery at her home following which she presented with a perineal tear as shown below. Identify the grade of perineal tear:
questions.solution:
The image showing a tear in the vaginal mucosa, perineal muscles, and more than 50% of the external anal sphincter is suggestive of a grade 3b perineal tear.

Perineal tears are common in primigravida women undergoing vaginal delivery.

The first-degree tears do not require repairs but suturing of laceration prevents the vaginal orifice from becoming patulous. Second-degree tears must be immediately sutured after the delivery of the placenta to prevent the weakening of the pelvic floor and genital prolapse. 

Third and fourth-degree tears must be efficiently repaired to prevent flatus and faecal incontinence. Such tears are common in median episiotomies, incorrect usage of forceps in a persistent occipitoposterior positioned fetus, delivery of aftercoming of breech, precipitate labour and delivery of macrosomic babies.

The best time for repair of a complete perineal tear is within 24 hours of the injury. If not done within 24hrs, it is preferably done 3-6 months after delivery. If the perineal tear is untreated for more than 6 months, dense scar tissue forms and making the surgery difficult. 

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history suggestive of a transient ischemic attack 5 hours ago. Which of the following can be used to determine the risk for future stroke?
questions.solution:
The risk of stroke following transient ischemic attacks (TIA) is determined by the ABCD2 score.

TIA is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke-like symptoms) lasting for less than 24 hours.

This occurs due to focal ischemia of the brain, retina, or cochlea. There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA. 

The components of the ABCD2 are shown in the table below

Age ≥60 years 1 point
<60 years 0 points
Blood pressure elevation when first assessed after TIA Systolic ≥ 140 mm Hg or Diastolic ≥90 mm Hg 1 point
Systolic <140 mm Hg and diastolic < 90 mm Hg 0 points
Clinical features Unilateral weakness 2 points
Isolated speech disturbance 1 point
Other  0 points
Duration of TIA symptoms   ≥60 minutes 2 points
10 to 59 minutes 1 point
<10 minutes 0 points
 Diabetes Present 1 point
Absent  0 points

 Interpretation of ABCD2 score:

  • Score 6 to 7: High two-day stroke risk
  • Score 4 to 5: Moderate two-day stroke risk
  • Score 0 to 3: Low two-day stroke risk

Other options:

Options B and C: BISAP (bedside index of severity in a/c pancreatitis) and APACHE II are used for assessing the severity of Acute pancreatitis.

Option D: CHADS2 score determines the risk of stroke in Atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with painless white eye with an intraocular pressure (IOP) of 60 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario, the diagnosis is suggestive of glaucomatocyclitic crisis.

Glaucomatocyclitic crisis (Posner–Schlossman Syndrome [PSS]):

  • Recurrent attacks of unilateral acute raised intraocular pressure (IOP) associated with mild anterior uveitis.
  • The mechanism is speculated to be acute trabeculitis, and there is evidence that infection, possibly cytomegalovirus (CMV) or Helicobacter pylori, may play a role.
  • PSS typically affects young to middle-aged adults. Males are affected more frequently than females.
  • Signs
    • Slit-lamp biomicroscopy typically shows a few anterior chamber cells and one to several fine white central keratic precipitates.
    • Mydriasis is common; posterior synechiae are not a feature.
    • IOP is typically raised to over 40 mmHg, out of proportion to iritis severity.
    • Gonioscopy shows an open-angle.
  • Treatment
    • Topical steroids are used to control inflammation, with aqueous suppressants to lower the IOP.
    • Topical or oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents may also be beneficial.

Other options : 

Option A: Chronic papilledema presents with a long history of recurrent transient blackouts, and visual blurring with normal IOP, and slit lamp examination.

Options B: Acute angle closure glaucoma presents with unilateral headache and dimension of vision with red eye due to massive congestion in the eye.

Option D: Acute anterior uveitis presents with photophobia, blurred vision, pain, ciliary congestion, tenderness, keratic precipitates, aqueous flare, and cells.

questions.text: A male child experienced acute scrotal pain while playing. He was taken to the emergency department and a USG doppler was performed, followed by immediate surgical exploration. The following finding was seen. What is the probable diagnosis?

choices.text: Torsion of testicular appendage with gangrene

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the intraoperative specimen is suggestive of testicular torsion with gangrene.

Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord and its contents such that the testicular blood supply becomes compromised. It is a surgical emergency and if left untreated, the testes may become gangrenous. Early surgery undertaken to untwist the testis gives a better outcome.

The following are anatomical predispositions to testicular torsion:

  • High investment in the tunica vaginalis causes the testis to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause in adolescents and is typically a bilateral abnormality
  • Inversion of the testis. The testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down.
  • Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis. This allows torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with the epididymis.

Males in the age group of 10-25 years present with acute scrotal or groin pain with associated nausea and vomiting. On examination, the scrotum appears swollen and tender.

Torsion Testis has to be differentiated from Acute epididymo-orchitis. This is done by Prehn's sign. In the case of acute epididymo-orchitis, the pain gets relieved on the elevation of the testis but not in the torsion of the testes.

Other Signs seen in torsion of the testis are: 

  • Deming’s sign: Spasm of the cremaster muscle and the twisting of the cord cause the affected testis to be positioned higher
  • Angell’s sign: The testis on the opposite side lies horizontally because of the bilaterality of the mesorchium between the testis and epididymis.
  • Cremastric reflex- absent on the side of the affected testis

The morphologic changes range from intense congestion to widespread hemorrhage to testicular infarction depending on the duration of torsion. In advanced stages, the testis is markedly enlarged and consists entirely of soft, necrotic, hemorrhagic tissue.

A Doppler ultrasound may be taken to assess the blood supply but surgical exploration is still indicated as a clinical decision. If the testis is infarcted after the cord is untwisted, an orchidectomy must be undertaken and the opposite testis must be fixed to the scrotum to preserve fertility and prevent torsion. If the affected testis is viable after the cord is untwisted, both the affected and the contralateral testes are fixed to the scrotum (bilateral orchiopexy) using non-absorbable sutures.

Other Options :

Option A: Testicular hematoma will usually be associated with trauma to the testis.

Option B: Strangulated hernia will have a history of inguinal swelling and the presence of cough impulse over the swelling. the following image shows ischemic and necrotic bowel herniated into the sack.

Option C: Testicular appendage torsion is torsion of vestigial appendage present along the testis. It has no function but torsion of appendage can be painful. It presents with a blue dot sign on clinical examination. It is a self-limiting condition and conservative management is done.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with lower urinary tract symptoms, including weak urinary stream, hesitancy, and nocturia. On digital rectal examination (DRE), a hard, irregular prostate is palpated. He has no significant past medical history but reports mild back pain over the past few weeks. The physician suspects prostate cancer. Which enzyme is elevated in prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP) is commonly increased in prostatic cancer. 

The form of acid phosphatase that is found in the prostate gland is called prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP). PAP is a glycoprotein that is synthesized by the epithelial cells of the prostate gland. It is secreted into the prostatic fluid, where it plays a role in the liquefaction of semen.

PAP is also a potential target for monoclonal antibody therapy. Sipuleucel-T is a cell-based approach to induce an immune response against prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP) that is commonly expressed in prostatic cancer.

Option A: Alkaline phosphatase is increased in primary liver cancers, such as hepatocellular carcinoma and cholangiocarcinoma.  Similarly, cancers that metastasize to the bones or primary bone cancers like osteosarcoma. 

Option C: Lactate dehydrogenase elevations can occur in a range of malignancies. It is often observed in hematological cancers like lymphomas and leukemias, reflecting the rapid cell turnover characteristic of these diseases. Lung cancers, both small cell and non-small cell types, can also lead to increased LDH levels. 

Option D: Alpha-fetoprotein is a protein that is produced by the liver and yolk sac during fetal development. Alpha-fetoprotein levels are typically elevated in certain types of cancer, such as liver cancer and testicular cancer, but not in prostate cancer.

questions.text: A type 1 diabetic mother is on magnesium sulfate infusion post-cesarean section for preeclampsia. She develops delirium and is drowsy. She has a respiratory rate of 10/min, random blood glucose level of 240 mg/dL, oliguria, and bilaterally absent knee reflex. What is the cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and examination finding of bilaterally absent knee reflex following magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) administration for preeclampsia suggest the cause of her condition to be magnesium sulfate toxicity. 

MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. It can also be used as a tocolytic to stop preterm labor. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4–7 mEq/L. 

Patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Decreased respiratory rate <12/min
  • Urine output <30 mL/h
  • Chest pain and heart block 
  • Visual changes, flushing, muscle paralysis, and drowsiness

Measurement of serum magnesium levels is indicated to monitor magnesium toxicity if serum creatinine >1.0 mg/dL.

Management of magnesium toxicity is as follows:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Intravenous injection of calcium gluconate 10 mL (10% solution) 

The two commonly used MgSO4 regimens are described below: 

Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Intramuscular (Pritchard)

4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 minutes, followed by 10 g (50%) deep IM (5 g in each buttock)

5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock

Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)

4 g IV slow over 15–20 minute

1–2 g/h IV infusion

Repeated/maintenance dose IM injections of magnesium sulfate are continued only under the following conditions:

  • The patellar reflex is present
  • Respiration is not depressed
  • Urine output >30 mL/h

Other options:

Option B: Pregnant women with diabetic ketoacidosis present with hyperventilation (Kussmaul breathing) and their blood glucose level is around 380 mg/dL.

Option C: Eclampsia patients present with generalized tonic-clonic convulsions.

Option D: Diabetes insipidus patients present with polyuria and polydipsia.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented with a continuous feeling of depressed mood that lasts most of the day. She has feelings of worthlessness, has no interest in doing anything and stays away from interacting with others. She has never experienced a manic episode and does not have any agitation, suicidal thoughts or any other medical history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of a persistent depressed mood that lasts most of the day, with feelings of worthlessness, withdrawal from society, and loss of interest without psychomotor agitation, suicidal thoughts or any other medical history is suggestive of dysthymia.

Dysthymia is a persis­tent depressive disorder that is characterised by the presence of:

  • Insidious onset
    • Early: <21 years, more common
    • Late: > 21 years
  • Depressed mood that lasts most of the day, almost continuously.
  • Associated feelings of inadequacy, guilt, irritability, and anger
  • Withdrawal from society
  • Loss of interest, inactiv­ity, lack of productivity
  • Inertia, lethargy, and anhedonia are characteristi­cally worse in the morning

The disorder is more common in women and young people. It frequently coexists with other mental disorders, like major depressive disorder, anxiety disorders, substance abuse, and borderline personality disorder. 

The DSM-5 diagnosis criteria for dysthymia includes:

  • Presence of a depressed mood most of the time for at least 2 years (or 1 year for children and adolescents)
  • Presence of 2 or more features of poor appetite/overeating, insomnia/hypersomnia, low energy, low self-esteem, feelings of hopelessness or poor concentration.
  • Should not have symptoms that are part of major depressive disorder like disturbances in appetite and libido, psychomotor agitation or suicidal thoughts
  • Absence of any other medical illness or substance use that can cause this condition.
 

Treatment includes:

  1. Cognitive therapy
  2. Behaviour therapy
  3. Insight oriented psychoanalytic therapy
  4. Interpersonal therapy
  5. Family and group therapies
  6. Pharmacotherapy with SSRIs, venlafaxine and bupropion

Other options:

Option A: Double Depression is a condition with the presence of major depressive disorder along with dysthymia.

Option C: Cyclothymia is a chronic, fluctuating mood disturbance with many periods of hypomania and depression.

Option D: Patients with minor depressive disorder have a euthymic mood in between the episodes, but patients with dysthymia have virtually no euthymic periods.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding adenomyosis?
questions.solution:
Patients with adenomyosis commonly present with symptoms of menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea.

Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of the endometrium directly into the myometrium. It usually occurs following vigorous curettage, repeated childbirth or in conditions with an excess of estrogen. Adenomyosis is more common in multiparous women aged 40 years and above. They commonly present with menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea. Other symptoms include pelvic discomfort, backache and dyspareunia.

On per-vaginal examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to 12-14 weeks size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination. This is known as Halban's sign. 

Other options:

Option A: Adenomyosis is more common in multiparous women aged 40 years and above. 

Option B: The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination.

Option D:  A diagnostic hysteroscopy combined with curettage is the initial step in the management because of menorrhagia. Total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localised excision and levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger patients.

The image below is an illustration of adenomyosis.

The image below shows adenomyosis as seen during laparoscopy. The uterus is soft and enlarged; the blue spots represent subserous endometriosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of numbness around the lips and a tingling sensation in her fingers. She underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism one year ago. An ECG was done and is given below. What will be your immediate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and ECG showing a prolonged QT interval (QT interval more than 0.43 seconds) is suggestive of hungry bone syndrome i.e. hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acute symptomatic presentation of hypocalcemia is treated with IV calcium gluconate.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

  • Mild circumoral or digital numbness
  • Paresthesia
  • Laryngeal spasms 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias 
  • Chvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.
  • Trousseau's sign: This is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position. (shown in the image below)

Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with:

  • 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate is given slowly through intravenous route
  • Calcium and vitamin D replacement is given orally
  • Magnesium supplementation may also be required due to the synergistic actions of calcium and magnesium

The continuous need for calcium or vitamin D, 1-year postoperatively is called permanent hypoparathyroidism.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with the following lesion on his face. He has a history of acne rosacea. The condition is:
questions.solution:
The image above shows an exophytic, pink, lobulated mass over the nose with superficial vascular dilation suggesting a diagnosis of phymatous rosacea or rhinophyma

Phymatous rosacea is a subtype of acne rosacea characterized by thickened skin and prominent follicular openings. There is marked nasal distortion with an increase in size and a bulbous tip. Rhinophyma is the most common type of phymatous rosacea.

Rhinophyma (potato tumour/elephantiasis of the nose) is due to hypertrophy of the sebaceous gland. It is associated with long-standing cases of acne rosacea.  It is mostly seen in middle-aged men involving the tip of the nose causing unsightly appearance and obstruction to breathing and vision.

Treatment of rhinophyma

  • First-line
    • Topical skin‐peeling agent if there are large occluded follicles
    • Electrocautery or laser for telangiectases
  • Second-line - Low‐dose isotretinoin therapy
  • Third line - Ablation of phymatous tissue with carbon dioxide laser • Surgical remodelling of the nose.

Other options:

Option B: Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by gram-negative bacillus Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It presents with chronic granulomatous inflammation of the nasal cavity, causing nasal obstruction, discharge, crusting, and eventual nasal deformity.

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. It presents with painless, friable, polypoidal masses in the nasal cavity, often causing nasal obstruction and bleeding.

Option D: Scleroderma causes rashes on the face but has no association with long-standing acne rosacea. It is characterized by skin thickening, tightening, Raynaud's phenomenon, and internal organ involvement such as the lungs, heart, and gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A construction worker was brought to the casualty following a fall from a height. He was found to have bleeding in the nose and ears. Bluish-black bruises were found under the eyes. The following finding was seen behind the ears. What is the most likely type of skull fracture associated?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of falling from a height causing bleeding through the nose and ears, with bluish-black bruises under the eyes and behind the ears, is highly suggestive of basilar skull fracture or ring fracture.

Signs in basilar skull fractures:

  • Hemotympanum: Pooling of blood behind the tympanic membrane, associated with fracture of the temporal bone. It is one of the earliest signs of basilar fracture.
  • Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa.
  • Retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis (Battle sign): Pooled blood behind the ears in the mastoid region is associated with fractures to the middle cranial fossa (petrous part of temporal bone).
  • CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: Double target sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containing bloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.

Battle sign and raccoon eyes are both typically not present during the initial evaluation and are delayed by 6 hrs up to 3 days after head injury.

CSF leaks may be delayed hours to days after the initial trauma. Fluid suspicious for CSF is confirmed by testing for β2 transferrin. Most CSF leaks are conservatively managed. Persistent leaks >7 days have a heightened risk of meningitis and are often surgically repaired.

Nasopharyngeal airways and nasogastric tube insertion are relatively contraindicated in basilar skull fractures due to the risk of intracranial placement. NIPPV is avoided due to the risk of pneumocephalus. 

The image below shows raccoon eyes and a battle sign.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture - Separation of sutures due to blow with blunt weapon or from cerebral edema. It is also called sutural fracture.

Fissured fracture/Linear fracture:

  • Linear skull fractures are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture - Occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. It is also known as indented fracture.

Depressed fracture - Caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced. So it is also called 'signature fracture'.

Comminuted fracture - It is also called spider web fracture and has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of fracture.

questions.text: A young patient presents with painless central loss of vision. On evaluation, the Arden’s index is reduced and fundus examination is as below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young patient presenting with painless central loss of vision (macular pathology) with reduced Arden’s index and egg-yolk appearance in the macular region suggests Best’s disease.

Best's disease also known as vitelliform macular dystrophy is an autosomal dominant macular dystrophy in which lipofuscin accumulates in the central macula, causing progressive central vision loss. It is primarily a cone dystrophy linked to bestrophin(VMD2) gene mutations. 

Clinical features are hemeralopia (day/bright light  blindness) and central scotoma. Ocular findings include vitelliform(yolk like) appearance of the fundus and abnormal electrooculogram(EOG) with relatively normal electroretinogram(ERG).

EOG reveals reduced Arden’s index. Arden index is the ratio of the light peak over the dark trough in EOG. An Arden index value of above 185 is considered normal and below 150 is abnormal. 

Other options:

Option A: Stargardt’s disease is an autosomal recessive disorder and it is the most common juvenile macular dystrophy. It is also a cone dystrophy characterised by lipofuscin accumulation within the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). Clinical features are hemeralopia and central scotoma as like Best disease.

Characteristic features include a fundus image of beaten-bronze macular atrophy surrounded by lipofuscin flecks and a silent choroid/dark choroid on fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA).

Option C: Retinitis pigmentosa is a pigmental retinal dystrophy where the photoreceptors, especially rods are affected. Most of them are hereditary and show autosomal dominant inheritance. Night blindness is a characteristic feature. Tubular vision is seen in advanced cases. 

Retinal pigmentary changes on fundus examination reveal jet-black spots resembling bone corpuscles.

Option D: Macular hole (MH) is a vitreoretinal interface disease characterized by a partial or full-thickness neurosensory retinal defect in the centre of the macula. Females are more commonly involved (F: M=3:1) in their sixth or seventh decade of life. 

Fundus showing a full-thickness macular hole with a surrounding cuff of subretinal fluid confirms the diagnosis. Other features include, FFA showing early foveal hyperfluorescence without a leak and the presence of full-thickness macular hole in optical coherence tomography (OCT).

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of hematuria and recurrent urinary tract infection. You notice the following finding in his CECT. Which of the following statements about the diagnosis is incorrect?

choices.text: Indications for operation evidence of parenchymal damage and infection
They are formed due to fusion of upper poles of both the kidneys
Isotope renography is the best test to confirm obstructive dilatation of the collecting system.
Common in pregnant women due to high circulating levels of progesterone

questions.solution:
The given image shows a horseshoe kidney. All the statements are correct except, that they are formed due to the fusion of the upper poles of both kidneys. Horseshoe kidneys are a type of renal fusion anomaly. They are formed when the lower poles of the two kidneys fuse during organogenesis to form an isthmus.

Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys. They are typically low-lying as the inferior mesenteric artery interferes with its ascent due to its size and the presence of an isthmus. It presents as a fixed, nonmobile, firm mass in the midline at the level of the 4th lumbar vertebra and is resonant on percussion.

It is associated with an increased risk of infection, stone formation, hydronephrosis, and tuberculosis. It has a 2:1 male preponderance. Individuals with horseshoe kidneys are prone to reflux, obstruction, and stone formation.

Isotope renography is the best test to confirm obstructive dilatation of the collecting system(Option C).

Other tests include:

  • Ultrasound scanning is the least invasive means of detecting hydronephrosis and is regularly used to diagnose PUJ obstruction in utero.
  • IVU helps to detect hydronephrosis only if there is a significant function in the obstructed kidney.
  • In the Whitaker test, percutaneous puncture of the kidney is made and fluid is infused at a constant rate with monitoring of intrapelvic pressure. An abnormal rise in pressure confirms obstruction.
  • Retrograde pyelography is rarely indicated but will confirm the site of obstruction immediately before corrective surgery. 

The indications for operation in a case of hydronephrosis are bouts of renal pain, increasing hydronephrosis, and evidence of parenchymal damage and infection (Option A). Both U/L and B/L Hydronephrosis are common in pregnant women(Option D) especially on the right side due to high circulating levels of progesterone and physiological dilation of ureters and renal pelvices occurring in early pregnancy.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient came with complaints of blurring of vision, photophobia, and pain in the eye. He also has congestion of the eyes and joint pain. All ocular complaints are unilateral. Which of the following major histocompatibility complexes (MHC) can be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis here is anterior uveitis seen in ankylosing spondylitis and the major histocompatibility complex associated with this condition is  HLA B27.

HLA B27 is positive in the following conditions:

  • Psoriatic spondylitis
  • Reactive arthritis due to Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, Chlamydia
  • Acute anterior uveitis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis

 Anterior uveitis: Involvement of Iris

  • Most common symptom: Photophobia
  • Most common sign: Cells in Anterior Chamber

Intermediate Uveitis: Involvement of Pars plana and peripheral part of the retina and the underlying choroid.

  • Most common symptom: Floaters
  • Sign: Snowball opacities & snow banking. Seen in pars plana > ora serrata (q)
  • Most Common complication of Pars planitis 
  • Posterior Subcapsular Cataract.

Posterior uveitis: Involvement of Choroid

  • Most Common Symptom: Floaters
  • Most Common cause of visual loss: Cystoid Macular edema

Other options:

HLA B51- Behcet disease

HLA B47- Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

HLA B57- Abacavir Hypersensitivity

questions.text: An 3-year old child is having amblyopia in right eye. What is the preferred treatment for this child?
questions.solution:
The treatment of amblyopia in this child is by occlusion of the normal eye, in this case, the left eye. 

Amblyopia or 'lazy eye' is a developmental defect of spatial visual processing that occurs in the central visual pathways of the eye. It is reversible if treated appropriately at the right time during the development phase(0-8 years of age) but is most commonly seen in the first 3 years of life. It is a condition with unilateral or bilateral subnormal vision without any local abnormality in the eye.

It is most commonly associated with comitant squint and can be due to retinal defects, strabismus, high anisometropia with aniseikonia(a difference in the retinal image size between the two eyes).

Amblyopic eyes have a characteristic vision which has:

  • The crowding phenomenon where single letter vision is better than when presented in a row.
  • A drop in visual acuity when viewed through grey neutral density filters
  • Decreased recognition, contrast sensitivity, spatial localization, saccadic amplitudes, and pursuit eye movements.

Treatment includes occluding the normal eye for 6-12 weeks.

If there is a vision problem with an underlying cause then that should be corrected initially. The brain uses the stronger eye to perceive images and hence the brain has to be trained and forced to use the amblyopic or lazy eye by occluding the normal eye.

By occluding the normal eye, the amblyopic eye gets stimulated and gets corrected. Occlusion should be total and should be changed when it is dirty or loose.

In children less than 8 years the occlusion has to be done in a way so that constant occlusion of the normal eye does not make it amblyopic too.

It is done corresponding to the child's age (x) at a ratio of x:1. e.g if the child is 5 years old then the normal eye is occluded for 5 days and removed while only the amblyopic eye is occluded on the 6th day. It is continued in a similar fashion for 6-12 weeks. 

In infants, part-time occlusion (a few hours a day) is done while in children above 8 years, constant occlusion is advised.

However, the underlying cause of amblyopia should also be corrected for complete resolution.

questions.text:
A patient underwent a TAPP repair for an incarcerated left inguinal hernia. During the procedure, while fixing the mesh, tacks were accidentally placed below the iliopubic tract. On follow-up visits, the patient complained of persistent pain in his lateral thigh. Injury to which of the following nerves has most likely caused the pain?

TAPP repair- Transabdominal preperitoneal repair
questions.solution:
Injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most likely cause of pain in the above scenario.

Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh lies in the anatomical landmark known as the triangle of pain (as described in the pearl) and can be injured in laparoscopic hernia repair. Any damage to the contents of this structure can lead to chronic pain following hernia repair. 


In laparoscopic TAPP repair, to reduce chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract (away from the triangle of pain which carries the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve, and the femoral nerve).

Other options:

Option A: Ilioinguinal nerve may be commonly injured during open hernia repair. It provides innervation to the groin and medial aspect of the thigh, the upper part of the scrotum, and the penile root.

Option B: Iliohypogastric nerve can be injured while making an incision in the right iliac fossa during hernia surgery. It mainly supplies the suprapubic skin.

Option C: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve (which supplies the skin over the upper anterior part of the thigh) lies in close relation to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. Injury to these also can cause loss of sensation over the thigh but these are less frequent.

 

 

Related Pearl: The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

questions.text: A 26-year-old actor came with complaints of being unable to focus on his work. He worked for a short while in various occupations, before deciding he wanted to be an actor. After attending several auditions, he discovered that he was easily distracted, needed help remembering his lines, and even drifted off during reading. Identify the disorder in the given scenario.
questions.solution:
The disorder in the given scenario can be identified as Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuropsychiatric condition affecting children, adolescents, and adults around the world, characterized by a pattern of diminished sustained attention, and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. They often have significant impairment in academic functioning as well as in social and interpersonal situations.

ADHD was historically believed to be a childhood condition resulting in delayed development of impulse control that would be generally outgrown by adolescence. Over the past few decades, a significant number of adults with ADHD have been found, diagnosed, and given effective treatment. Utah Criteria for Adult Attention-Deficit/ Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) include retrospective diagnosis of ADHD in childhood and evidence of current impairment from ADHD symptoms in adulthood. 

Adults with residual illness exhibit impulsivity and attention deficit symptoms, such as trouble focusing, difficulty organizing and finishing tasks, increased distractibility, and making snap decisions without considering the repercussions. Many individuals with the illness also suffer from a secondary depressive disorder, which is linked to low self-esteem as a result of their diminished performance, which has an impact on social and professional functioning.

A variety of medications and behavioural interventions are used to treat ADHD. The most widely used medications are methylphenidate and atomoxetine. A combination of medication and psychotherapy is more effective than either treatment alone.

Other options: 

Option A: Patients with chronic depression will usually have low mood and loss of interest in general and this does not fit into the given scenario.

Option B: Borderline personality disorder is characterized by extraordinarily unstable affect, mood, behaviour, object relations, and self-image. Instability in affect due to a marked reactivity of mood. It is characterized by repeated suicidal behaviour, unstable interpersonal relationships, prolonged feelings of emptiness, inappropriate, intense anger, or difficulty in controlling anger. 

Option C: Manic disorder is usually seen with grandiosity and other psychotic symptoms that do not fit into the given situation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient who is a known smoker presents with buttock claudication and impotence. On examination, distal lower limb pulses are absent. At which level is the pathology likely to be?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a male patient with buttock claudication and impotence is suggestive of Leriche Syndrome, which is an arterial occlussive disease occuring at the aorto-iliac junction (marked '1'). Given below is an image depicting the same.

Relationship of clinical findings to the site of disease
Aortoiliac obstruction Claudication in buttocks, thighs and calves. Femoral and distal pulses absent in both limbs.
Bruit over the aortoiliac region
Iliac obstruction

Unilateral claudication in the thigh and calf and sometimes the buttock. 
Unilateral absence of femoral and distal pulses. Bruit over the iliac region.
Femoropopliteal obstruction

Unilateral claudication in the calf.

Femoral pulse palpable with absent unilateral distal pulses
Distal obstruction Femoral and popliteal pulses are palpable. Ankle pulses absent
Claudication in calf and foot

Investigations that aid in the diagnosis of this condition include Doppler ultrasound, duplex scanning, ankle-brachial pressure index, and digital subtraction percutaneous angiography (DSA). 

Management is by exercise, smoking cessation, control of diabetes, and weight loss if obese. Drugs such as statins and clopidogrel or aspirin can be initated. Surgical management  options include transluminal angioplasty and stenting or bypass grafting.

questions.text: A woman is admitted to the hospital for the management of breast cancer. The tumor is 3 cm in size with ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes. There is no distant metastasis. The TNM staging of the tumor is:
questions.solution:
The TNM staging of the tumor is T2 N1 M0.

  • Tumor size 3 cm: T2 
  • Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes: N1
  • No distant metastasis: M0

Points to remember

  • In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 x 2 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm).
  • Skin involvement does not include nipple retraction and skin dimpling.
  • Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.
  • If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump.
  • If lumps are present in both breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

*Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IIIB) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

questions.text: An elderly man feels his intestines are dead and rotting, but nobody is bothered to remove them. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of nihilistic delusion disorder.

Nihilistic delusion: False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome

Other options:

Option A: In Fregoli Syndrome the patients have a delusion that the familiar person can assume the appearance of (or disguised as) strangers. 

Option B: In Capgras syndrome (illusion des sosies) the patients believe that their family members or other familiar people have been replaced by identical-looking imposters.

Option D: In Othello syndrome, the patient has delusions which are predominantly jealousy and infidelity involving the spouse. This syndrome is named after the character in Shakespeare's play. 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with carcinoma of the tongue has a defect of more than 2 cm. The patient is planned for hemiglossectomy and tongue reconstruction using a radial forearm flap. The surgeon plans to use the following approach. What is this procedure/ approach called?
questions.solution:
The picture shows the visor approach (like the visor of the helmet). It provides excellent access to the floor of the mouth and tongue. 

In the Visor approach, an incision is made in the cervical crease from the mastoid to the mastoid. Another incision is made in the lingual gingival sulcus from one posterior molar to the other side posterior molar. This frees the skin which is present over the chin and floor of the mouth. This flap is elevated like a visor of the helmet providing a wide exposure to remove larger lesions involving the anterior oral cavity that is not amenable to a peroral approach. This avoids a lip-splitting incision but has the disadvantage of anaesthesia of the chin/lower lip (due to the sacrifice of submental nerves).

Other options:

Option A: The lip-split and paramedian/ median mandibulotomy approaches are used for the treatment of oropharyngeal cancers. Lip-split mandibulotomy is the most commonly used access procedure. It provides better access to posterior oral cavity, the base of the tongue, and the oropharynx.

Option C: Trans-oral wedge resection is done for moderate-sized anterior oral tumours.

Option D: Commando operation is a combined mandibular resection and neck node dissection, and it is used mainly for carcinoma of the tongue.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the psychiatric OPD with complaints that he misidentifies strangers as a single persecutor wearing different disguises. What is this syndrome called?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, the man is brought to the psychiatric OPD with complaints of misidentifying strangers as a single persecutor appearing in different disguises. This condition is known as Fregoli syndrome.

The man is mistaking strangers as familiar persons/persecutors. He believes that a familiar person or stranger can take on the appearance of multiple individuals. Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people/strangers are a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Other options:

Option A: Cotard syndrome (delire de negation/ nihilistic delusion disorder) is a condition where the patient complains that they have lost all their possessions, status, entire being, and even their internal organs.

Option B: Capgras syndrome (illusion des sosies) is a condition where the individual believes that their family members or other familiar people have been replaced by look-alike imposters.

Option D: Magnan syndrome occurs in patients with cocaine addiction where they experience cocaine bugs /tactile hallucinations.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman came with complaints of abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and vomiting for a few hours. She is on ovulation induction therapy for infertility.  Her sonogram of both ovaries is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the sonogram showing enlarged ovaries meeting in the midline having large cysts are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is an iatrogenic complication seen during the luteal phase or early pregnancy. It is seen in patients taking ovulation induction therapies for infertility more common in FSH/LH therapy than clomiphene or pulsatile GnRH therapies. 

The pathogenesis in OHSS is the increased vascular permeability leading to a fluid shift from intravascular to extravascular space.

They often present with shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal disturbances like nausea, vomiting, and oliguria. Abdominal pain occurs due to ovarian enlargement and accumulation of peritoneal fluid. Increased vascular permeability and loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity cause ascites and result in hemoconcentration. Hemoconcentration causes hyperviscosity and leads to hypercoagulability. Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, leukocytosis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can be associated with OHSS. 

This condition can be prevented by

  • Withholding hCG in a cycle if there are more than 20 follicles on ultrasound and E2 level rises to 3000 pg/ mL.
  • Albumin 5% infusion in 500 mL lactated Ringer’s solution during and after oocyte retrieval
  • Dopamine agonist cabergoline 0.5 mg daily for 8 days starting on day 1 of hCG.

OHSS is primarily managed with general supportive care. Paracentesis is performed to ameliorate abdominal discomfort and relieve respiratory discomfort.

Other options:

Option B- Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is the most common endocrine disorder of the reproductive age group. Patients with PCOS present with menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, acne, infertility, etc.

The ultrasound examination image shown below is of PCOS showing enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts. 


Option C- Hyperreactio luteinalis is a condition in which one or both ovaries develop multiple large theca lutein cysts. They are commonly seen in gestational trophoblastic disease, multiple gestational pregnancies, and other high HCG states. Most of them resolve spontaneously after delivery. Surgical management is only required if it is complicated by torsion or hemorrhage. 

The below image shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple theca luteal cysts as in hyperreactio luteinalis.


Option D- Hematometra is a condition in which menstrual outflow obstruction traps the blood and distends the uterus.  A large uterus can compress the urinary bladder, and rectum causing urinary retention and constipation. blood may get infected and lead to pyometra causing fever and leukocytosis.

The below ultrasonographic image shows a smooth, symmetric hypoechoic enlargement of the uterine cavity suggestive of hematometra.

questions.text:
You are a medical officer on camp duty seeing patients who have come for the removal of contraceptive devices. You notice the following contraceptive devices being used. Which of the following is incorrect about these devices?

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease - PID

choices.text: Can be used as an emergency contraceptive
Can be used in patients with mennorrhagia
Functions by causing an inflammatory response within the uterus

questions.solution:
The image shows types of Copper T. The statement that it 'can be used in patients with menorrhagia' is incorrect about the copper T. Copper T's are contraindicated in patients with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and anemia as it can worsen the condition. 

Copper T is a type of intrauterine contraception device (IUCD). They provide long-term, reversible method of contraception.

Types:

  • Medicated IUCD's such as progestasert, levonova, and mirena which release hormones for contraception.
  • Unmedicated IUCD's such as the copper T, in order to induce contraception. 

The copper T functions by causing an inflammatory response (Option D) within the uterus which leads to spermicide. The same response also makes it difficult for blastocyst implantation. 

IUCDs can be placed in women who have a low risk of sexually transmitted diseases, are multiparous, monogamous, and want long-term contraception without permanent sterilization. These have the advantage of not having to take a daily oral contraceptive pill. 

The copper T can also be used as emergency contraception (Option A) and left inside the uterus long term for contraception. 

It is contraindicated in the following situations: 

  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Fibroid uterus (Option C) as there will be structural issues
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease or lower genital tract infections
  • Menorrhagia or dysmenorrhea
  • Anemia
  • Uncontrolled diabetes due to increased risk of infection
  • Previous ectopic pregnancy 
  • Scarred uterus
  • Abnormally shaped uterus

In addition, hormonal IUCDs should not be given in women with history of breast cancer. 

The following image shows the Nova T. It has silver in addition to the copper wire which makes its lifespan 5 years. 

The copper T 380A is also known as Paraguard. It has a lifespan of 10 years. It has 380 mm2 surface area spread out across the stem and the sleeves. 

The multiload 375 has 375 mm2 of copper wire wrapped around the stem. It has to be replaced every 5 years. It does not have an introducer or plunger. 

The copper T 200 has 215mm2 of copper around the stem. It has a polyethylene frame with monofilaments attached to the end of the stem. The threads are used for removal. Barium sulfate is added to the stem to increase radioopacity when performing xrays. It has a lifespan of 3 years. 

The following images represent the copper T 380A, multiload 375, and copper T 200. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness
