questions.text: A patient complains of visual blurring which is relieved on its own. Fundus examination showed papilledema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Visual blurring in papilledema is called amaurosis fugax

Amaurosis fugax is the transient loss of vision due to an interruption in the blood supply to the retina or brain by emboli or spasms. The onset is abrupt and may follow a falling curtain pattern. The symptoms are relieved upon removal of the insult or the emboli and they recover in the same pattern the vision loss occured.

In papilledema, amaurosis fugax lasts 30-60 seconds. It's usually bilateral but can be unilateral in asymmetric disc edema due to giant cell arteritis or raised intracranial pressure

Other systemic causes can present as amaurosis fugax. Notably, cardiovascular abnormalities like arrhythmias, mitral valve prolapse, venous stasis retinopathies, fibromuscular dysplasia, etc.

Treatment is based on the cause. It's often self-limiting in papilledema. Aspirine or persantine may be used in cases of platelet emboli-induced disease. Severe emboli may require dis-obliteration of the vessels.

Other options:

Option A: Retinal detachment is the separation of retinal epithelium. They may present as visual blurring but is not transient. Fundus examination will show a greyish or whitish tint to the detached portions with evident tears and holes in cases of larger detachments.

Option C: Blindness as per WHO is visual acuity less than 3/60 or corresponding visual field defects in the better eye with the best possible correction. 

Option D: Angle-closure glaucoma presents with painful loss of vision with redness. Fundus examination may show hyperemic disc or maybe even normal disc.

questions.text: A 56-year-old multiparous woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The type of urinary incontinence present in a patient with prolapse and cystocele experiencing urination on coughing and sneezing is stress incontinence.

Stress incontinence refers to the involuntary leakage of urine when there is increased intraabdominal pressure (eg, coughing, sneezing, laughing, Valsalva maneuver). There is an absence of detrusor muscle contraction, seen in urodynamic studies.

Causes:

  • Age and menopause - due to estrogen deficiency
  • Multiparity - due to loss of pelvic muscle tone
  • Obesity
  • Constipation, chronic cough
  • Pelvic organ prolapse
  • Pregnancy - due to the effect of progesterone and pressure of the gravid uterus on the bladder neck.
  • Puerperium - due to descent of the bladder neck, loss of urethro-vesical angle, and reduced pelvic muscle tone 
  • Surgical repair of vesicovaginal fistula

Grading of genuine stress incontinence (GSI) :

  • Grade I: Incontinence with only severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing, and jogging.
  • Grade II: Incontinence with moderate stress, such as fast walking, and going up and down the stairs.
  • Grade III: Incontinence with mild stress such as standing.

Investigations are only done prior to surgery to confirm the diagnosis. They include the stress test, cotton swab or Q tip test, Marshall and Bonney’s test, urethroscopy, and urodynamic studies. These are not required prior to conservative management.

Conservative management includes Kegel's pelvic exercises, electric nerve stimulation, devices like pessaries, vaginal cones, and artificial sphincters. Medical treatment with estrogen creams, anti-adrenergic, venlafaxine, and imipramine may be useful.

Other options:

Option A: Overflow incontinence is an old term that refers to the inability to empty the bladder, with involuntary, continuous urinary dribbling. Currently, it refers to another presentation of urge incontinence. 

Option B: Urge incontinence is the involuntary escape of urine when there is an imminent need to urinate. It occurs due to detrusor muscle overactivity or detrusor instability. It is seen more commonly in old women with decreased bladder capacity, decreased sensation, and central nervous system (CNS) inhibition. 

Option D: Neurogenic bladder occurs in patients with neurogenic dysfunction leading to detrusor hyperreflexia. Conditions such as multiple sclerosis, stroke, Parkinson's disease, and spinal injury give rise to this. They present with urgency or urge incontinence.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. He also complains of excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day which improves with rest. Placing an ice pack over his eyes significantly decreases the ptosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis. This patient has symptoms of ptosis, progressive weakness, and excessive fatiguability which improves with rest. 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness.

Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis include muscle weakness and fatigue increasing with repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Cranial muscles, particularly the lids and extraocular muscles, are involved early in the course causing diplopia and ptosis.

Myasthenic crisis is an acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse. Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Grave's disease, neuromyelitis optics, systemic lupus erythematosus, etc.

Diagnosis is with the ice-pack test, Anti-AChR antibodies, Anti-MuSK antibodies, and Anti-LRP4 antibodies. The repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response. Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test.

Treatment is with anticholinesterase drugs like pyridostigmine, thymectomy, immunosuppression therapy with glucocorticoids, azathioprine, tacrolimus, rituximab, etc and plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin.

Other options:

Option B: Huntington's disease (HD) also known as Huntington chorea is associated with CAG repeats and anticipation. It has an adult-onset and is associated with the degeneration of striatal neurons. Features such as chorea and dementia are commonly seen in these patients. The characteristic features of HD include involuntary movements, dementia, and behavioural changes.

Option C: ALS (Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis ) is the most common progressive motor neuron disease. The pathologic hallmark of ALS includes the involvement of lower motor neurons of the ventral/ anterior horn of the spinal cord, cranial nerves innervating the bulbar muscles, and the afferent corticospinal upper motor neurons in layer five of the motor cortex. Progressive upper motor neuron (UMN) palsy (exaggerated reflexes, extensor plantar), lower motor neuron (LMN) palsy (muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations), and pseudobulbar palsy (dysarthria, tongue spasticity), with normal bladder, bowel and sensory function are suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Option D: The classical presentation of ptosis with progressively declining ocular movement is characteristic of chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO). CPEO may occur in isolation, in association with Kearns-Sayre syndrome (mitochondrial myopathy associated with mitochondrial DNA deletions), or oculopharyngeal dystrophy.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the incus.

This is an image taken during mastoidectomy. The incus articulates with the malleus and has a short process and a long process. The long process articulates with the head of the stapes.

CT: chorda tympani; I: incus; JB: jugular bulb; LSC: lateral semicirular canal; M: malleus; PSC: posterior semicircular canal; S: stapes; SM: stapedius muscle; SSC: superior semicircular canal; VIIms: mastoid segment of VII cranial nerve; VIIts: tympanic segment of VII cranial nerve.

questions.text: A patient developed a lesion as shown below after 6 months of a heart surgery. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a keloid scar.

Keloid scars are associated with elevated levels of growth factors.

A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Its etiology is unknown, but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, deeply pigmented skin, and inherited tendency and certain areas of the body (triangle whose points are the xiphisternum and each shoulder tip).

The histology of keloid scars shows excess collagen with hypervascularity, and there is disorganized type 1 and type 3 collagen.

Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and excision of the keloid scar has a high rate of recurrence.

Treatment:

  • Pressure - local molds or elastic garments.
  • Silicone gel sheeting.
  • Intralesional triamcinolone injection
  • Excision and steroid injections
  • Excision and postoperative radiation (external beam or brachytherapy)
  • Intralesional excision.
  • Laser to reduce redness
  • Vitamin E and palm oil massage

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient came with complaints of lethargy, increased thirst, and increased frequency of urination for a few months. On examination, his BMI was 19 kg/m2 and laboratory investigation showed low levels of C-peptide, raised blood glucose, and absent ketone bodies. Anti-GAD antibodies were positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Anti-GAD: Antibodies to glutamic acid decarboxylase
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 32-year-old, thin-built male, presenting with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy with laboratory investigation showing low C-peptide, and positive anti-GAD antibodies are suggestive of latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA). 

LADA is adult-onset diabetes with features of both type1 and type2 diabetes mellitus (DM). They phenotypically appear as type 2 but have autoantibodies like anti-GAD as in favor of type 1.

General characteristics of LADA are:

  • Age of onset more than 30 years
  • Family history of autoimmunity
  • Low or normal body mass index
  • Low C-peptide levels
  • Anti-GAD antibodies positive
  • Do not present with ketoacidosis initially due to the slow progression of beta-cell destruction

The diagnosis can be made based on three criteria as given by The Immunology of Diabetes Society

  • Adult age of onset (>30 years of age),
  • Positive circulating autoantibodies, and
  • No need for insulin treatment initially for several months after diagnosis

Initially, they don't require insulin but are more likely to be in insulin treatment within 5 years of onset. 

Other options:

Option A - Ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes patients are usually middle-aged men who are overweight and have a positive family history of diabetes. They have features similar to classic type 2 diabetes but often present with severe hyperglycemia and severe ketosis as in type 1 diabetes. Autoantibodies against beta-cell are negative in these patients. 

Option B: MODY or maturity-onset diabetes of the young is an autosomal dominant monogenic form of diabetes that occurs in less than 25 years of age. This is due to beta-cell dysfunction that impairs insulin secretion. The patients are non-ketotic and do not have pancreatic autoantibodies.

Option C: Type 1 diabetes mellitus most commonly develops before 20 years of age with most of them having evidence of islet-directed autoimmunity. Most of the patients present with hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis. There is increased lipolysis and ketone body production which results in muscle wasting, polyphagia, fatigue, and weakness.

Related Pearl: Comparative Features between MODY and Type 2 DM

 

Type 2 DM

MODY

Age of onset

questions.text: A doctor tells a 31-year-old woman, who is 20 weeks pregnant, that her baby has a developmental defect. She has come to you for a second opinion. The following USG finding is seen. Identify the defect.
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows an open defect in the calvaria and skin leading to the exposure of the cranial neural tube. This is consistent with the diagnosis of anencephaly. 

Anencephaly results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects that can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.  Screening can also be done by serum estimation of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP). The following are the radiological signs seen in anencephaly. 

  • Frog eye sign - Absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits thereby resembling the face of a frog. 
  • Shower cap sign - The absence of the cranium could lead to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue. This resembles a shower cap giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance.

Neural-tube defects can be prevented with pre-conceptional supplementation of folic acid. A dose of 4 mg daily is recommended in subsequent pregnancies.  

Other options:

Option B: Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel may herniate. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. Given below is an ultrasound image of the fetus suggestive of an omphalocele (asterix).

Option C: Cystic hygroma is a congenital multiloculated lymphatic lesion that is classically found in the left posterior triangle of the neck. It occurs as a result of sequestration or obstruction of developing lymph vessels. This defect can be picked up in a first-trimester ultrasound. The images below show cystic hygroma on the neck of a newborn and in the fetus respectively.

Option D: Encephalocele is caused due to defects in the skull through which the meninges and/or neural tissue herniate. The squamous part of the occipital bone is the most frequently affected bone. 

The image shows a newborn with encephalocele.

questions.text: A patient on steroids as part of her psoriasis medication presents with mild fever which is present only during the night and weight loss. She had an ulcer on her neck which had undermined edges as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of immunosuppression, symptoms of fever at night, weight loss, and the neck finding of an ulcer with undermined edges is suggestive of tubercular lymphadenitis.

The image shows long-standing tubercular adenitis with a sinus. 

In tuberculous cervical lymphadenitis any group of lymph nodes can be involved. Symptoms include evening pyrexia, malaise, and cough (from pulmonary tuberculosis) while in children-failure to thrive can be seen. A matted lymph nodal mass is the typical clinical feature. In later stages the mass may be cystic, denoting an abscess.

The abscess denotes underlying caseation and does not show any features of inflammation hence it is called a 'cold abscess'. The pus is initially confined by the deep cervical fascia, but after weeks or months, this may become eroded at one point and the pus flows through the small opening into the space beneath the superficial fascia. The process has now reached the stage of a ‘collar stud abscess'. An abscess may burst through the skin to form an ulcer with undermined edges which is typical of a tubercular ulcer with undermined edges and can develop into a discharging sinus.

Diagnosis is by the culture of pus and biopsy of the lymph node. The involvement of other systems must be excluded. Treatment is with antitubercular drugs.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with a 1-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. He gives a history of viral infection 10 days ago which resolved 2 days back. There is a history of a similar episode of icterus 2 years back when the patient had long hours of basketball practice. The current serum bilirubin is 2.4 mg/dL, unconjugated bilirubin is 2.1mg/dl, and conjugated bilirubin is 0.3mg/dl. Serum AST and ALT levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gilbert syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

This patient's mild jaundice seen only during a period of stress along with an increase in unconjugated bilirubin and normal AST, and ALT levels strongly point towards a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, illnesses, or any other precipitating factors. There is no hemolysis or underlying liver disease. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production. UDP-Glucoronyltransferase is required for the conjugation of bilirubin.

Precipitating factors in Gilbert syndrome:

  • Dehydration
  • Fasting
  • Menstrual periods
  • Illness
  • Vigorous exercise.

Other options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and conspicuous brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver. The disease is caused due to mutation in multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment.

Option B: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is of two types with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Hence, type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in babies. Type 2 may also lead to kernicterus occasionally. Unconjugated bilirubin is elevated. Isolated unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in a 25-year-old male is less likely to be due to Criggler Najar type 1 syndrome. It is because patients usually die in infancy or early childhood despite the best treatment.

Option D: Rotor syndrome: similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but with a milder presentation. Increased conjugated bilirubin levels. Liver biopsy does not show black colored liver

Related Pearl: Hereditary Hyperbilirubinemias

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen revealed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child with a whitish pupillary reflex and Flexner-Winterstein rosettes on histopathological examination has retinoblastoma. Flexner Winterstein rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen, which is highly characteristic of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. It belongs to small round blue cell tumours because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.

White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision. Image below showing leukocoria of left eye

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumour include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific of retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

The histopathological image of retinoblastoma is shown below.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of Vincristine, Carboplatin, and Etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy.
Enucleation is done when
  • The tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • The optic nerve is involved
  • Glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

Other options:

Option B - Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Patients usually present with headaches, ataxia, and signs of brainstem involvement.

Histologically, the tumor is very densely cellular. Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and elongated or crescent-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei. Tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes. They express neuronal markers such as synaptophysin.

Option C - Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood. The child usually presents with rapidly progressive unilateral proptosis. There are 4 subtypes - embryonal, alveolar, botyroid, and pleomorphic. Cells show light microscopic features of striated muscle differentiation. Immunohistochemistry is positive for desmin.

Option D - Astrocytoma of the retina and optic nerve head is rare. It is usually asymptomatic and is most frequently seen in tuberous sclerosis. Fundus examination reveals a yellowish or white plaque, nodule, or mulberry-like lesion. These lesions are semitransparent peripherally and calcified centrally.

Image showing calcified astrocytoma:

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A young boxer receives a blow near the eye during a boxing match. He presents to the ER with hematoma around eye, CT scan is shown below. Identify the radiological sign shown below?
questions.solution:
The given CT image dipicts 'tear-drop' sign and suggests a blowout fracture.

Tear-drop/ hanging drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum. The most useful projection for detecting an orbital floor fracture is Water’s view.

An orbital blow-out fracture is an isolated fracture of the orbital floor when a large blunt object strikes the globe is called blow out fracture. The orbital contents herniate through the antrum. Clinical signs are periocular swelling (early stage), enophthalmos, ecchymosis and subconjunctival haemorrhage (later stages).

Initial treatment consists of observation, oral antibiotics, ice packs, and nasal decongestants. Indications for surgery in a blowout fracture include diplopia not resolving significantly in the early days after trauma, a fracture with a large herniation of tissues into the antrum, incarceration of tissues in the fracture, resulting in globe retraction and increased applanation tension on attempted upward gaze and enophthalmos. If any of these conditions are present, surgical correction is required within 2 weeks.

The below-given X-ray image in the Water's view shows a 'tear-drop' sign

The optimal time for surgery following a blow-out fracture is 10–14 days.

Indications for surgery in a "blow-out" fracture are as follows:

  • Diplopia not resolving significantly in the early days after trauma
  • A fracture with a large herniation of tissues into the antrum
  • Incarceration of tissues in the fracture, resulting in  globe  retraction and increased applanation tension on attempted upward gaze
  • Enophthalmos greater than 2 mm
     

Other options:

Option A: Panda sign: A radiological finding in sarcoidosis showing bilateral symmetrical uptake in the lacrimal and parotid glands on gallium scan, creating an appearance resembling a panda's face.

Option B: Dalrymple’s sign is the commonest and earliest sign of Grave's ophthalmopathy. It is due to overactivity of levator aponeurosis and Müller's muscle. Here the upper lid margin is at level with or above the superior limbus, causing the upper sclera to become visible (scleral show).

Option C: Munson's sign is seen in keratoconus. There is a localized bulging of the lower eyelid that can be seen in a downward-looking eye.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who has regular menstrual cycles presents with amenorrhea. A urine pregnancy test is done and found to be positive. She recalls that the first day of her last menstrual period was October 9 2022. What would her expected date of delivery be based on Naegele's rule?
questions.solution:
Based on Naegele’s rule, the expected date of delivery (EDD) of this patient is July 16th 2023.

Naegele’s rule is based on a 28-day regular cycle and states that the EDD is obtained by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the 1st day of the last menstrual period (LMP). Another method is adding 9 months and 7 days to the 1st day of the LMP.

questions.text: Which of the following group of drugs is not given for post-operative nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
H2 receptor antagonists are used to reduce the risk of aspiration pneumonia, not postoperative nausea and vomiting.

The drugs given for postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) act by 

  • 5-HT3 antagonism
  • NK-1 antagonism
  • D2 antagonism

The 5- HT3 receptor mediates vomiting and is found in the gastrointestinal tract and the brain (area postrema). 5-HT3 antagonists like ondansetron and granisetron selectively block the serotonin 5-HT3 receptors, with little or no effect on dopamine receptors.

Substance P is a neuropeptide that interacts with neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptors. NK1 antagonists inhibit substance P at central and peripheral receptors. Aprepitant, an NK1 antagonist, has been found to reduce PONV perioperatively and is additive with ondansetron for this indication. 

Dopamine receptors, particularly D2 and D3 receptors when activated cause nausea and vomiting. Dopamine antagonists like metoclopramide and droperidol block the dopamine receptors at the chemo-receptor trigger zone, thereby reducing PONV.

Risk factors for PONV:

  • Patient-specific: Female gender, non-smoking status, history of motion sickness/PONV
  • Anesthetic-specific: Nitrous oxide, volatile anesthetics, opioids
  • Surgery-specific: Increased duration of surgery, type of surgery

Drugs used in the prophylaxis and treatment of PONV:

  • 5-HT 3 antagonists - ondansetron, palonosetron
  • Butyrophenones- droperidol
  • Dexamethasone
  • Transdermal scopolamine
  • Aprepitant

Note: Propofol has antiemetic property and thus reduces the risk of PONV.

questions.text: What is the indication for the procedure shown below?
questions.solution:
The given procedure is McDonald's cerclage which is done for cervical incompetence. 

Cervical incompetence is the impairment of the retentive power of the cervix. It can be due to anatomical causes or functional causes. It leads to painless dilation of the cervix and painless expulsion of the products of conception in the mid-trimester.  Cervical incompetence is diagnosed by clinical examination and ultrasonography showing the presence of short cervix (<25 mm) with or without funnelling of the internal os.

Prophylactic cerclage is done around 14 weeks of pregnancy or 2 weeks earlier than the previous fetal loss. Rescue or emergency cerclage is done anytime within 24 weeks of gestation.

Removal of cerclage should be done by 37 weeks of gestation. It can be removed earlier in case of preterm labor or if signs of abortion are seen.

Commonly used types of procedures for cervical cerclage during pregnancy:

  • McDonald's procedure: purse-string suture
  • Modified Shirodkar's procedure:

questions.text: A 30-year-old female was brought to the hospital with complaints of recurrent episodes of acute onset breathlessness, palpitations, sweating and dizziness for the past 2 months. Physical examination and laboratory investigations were normal. Which of the following is the drug of choice in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a panic attack. Benzodiazepines such as alprazolam are used to treat panic attacks.

A panic attack is a sudden period of intense fear or apprehen­sion that may last from minutes to hours. Panic attacks can occur in panic disorders, specific phobias, social phobias and post-traumatic stress disorder. They may occur at any time and are not associated with any identifiable stimulus. Some habits predispose a patient to panic attacks. These include the use of caffeine, alcohol, nicotine, or other substances, and unusual patterns of sleeping or eating. 

The first panic attack is often spontaneous, although panic attacks occasionally follow excitement, physical exertion, sexual activity, or moderate emotional trauma. The major symptoms are extreme fear and a sense of impending death and doom. Physi­cal signs often include tachycardia, palpitations, dyspnea or hyperventilation, and sweating. Patients often try to leave whatever situation they are in to seek help. The attack generally lasts 20 to 30 minutes and rarely more than an hour. Hyperventilation can produce respiratory alkalosis and other symptoms.

For rapid control of symptoms, alprazolam (0.25-0.5 mg/day) is the drug of choice. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as paroxetine (5-10 mg/day) are started concurrently and alprazolam is slowly tapered. Fluoxetine (2-5 mg/day) is used for panic attacks with co-morbid depression.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.
Occur spontaneously without overt precipitants.
 
They often avoid situations/ places in which panic attacks have occurred.

Treatment is with benzodiazepines or SSRI/ SNRI and cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific to social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone
 

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

questions.text: A patient complains that he feels like the room is spinning when he gets up from lying down or when he turns his head. He has no history of loss of consciousness. Which of the following could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the symptoms the most probable diagnosis is Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo(BPPV).

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo(BPPV) is characterized by vertigo when the head is placed in one certain critical position. It is not associated with hearing loss or neurological symptoms. It is caused due to the disorder of the posterior semicircular canal.

They are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals, usually dislodged from the posterior canal. It is due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle. The patient complains of vertigo when moving or tilting the head to the affected side. 

A positive Dix-Hallpike manoeuvre confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. In this manoeuvre, the patient begins sitting up with their head turned 45 degrees toward the ear to be tested. Then, the patient is made to lie down quickly with their head past the end of the bed. Then, the patient's neck is extended 20 degrees below the horizontal. The clinician then watches the patient's eyes for torsional and up-beating nystagmus, which should persist for no more than one minute. This would indicate a positive test.

The findings seen in the Dix-Hallpike manoeuvre are due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle.

Epley's manoeuvre is performed to reposition the crystals into the macula from the posterior semicircular canals. This is only a temporary cure, and there is a high rate of recurrence.

The illustration given below shows the different positions used in Epley's manoeuvre:

Other options:

Option B: Meniere's disease arises due to the distension of the endolymphatic system. Clinical features include episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. It is generally unilateral. 

Option C: Labyrinthitis causes symptoms of hearing loss along with unilateral vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo and associated nausea and vomiting. Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component, and the latter denotes the direction of nystagmus. 

Option D: Vestibular neuritis (VN) presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and imbalance. Unlike benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, continuous vertigo persists even when the head remains still. Spontaneous unidirectional nystagmus is present, occurring without head movement.

questions.text: The contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen of a 75-year-old woman shows the following findings. Which Bosniak class does the cyst belong to?
questions.solution:
The presence of a simple renal cyst without any septations, calcifications, or enhancing soft tissue components is classified as Bosniak class I. They do not require treatment or follow-up imaging.

Bosniak classification:

Depending on the CT characteristics the renal cysts are classified mainly into four classes:

Class I: It is a simple benign cyst, without any septations.

Class II: The cyst consists of one or more thin (<1 mm) septa running through them. Class II lesions are benign.

The subcategory class IIF includes lesions with multiple class II features, large hyperdense cysts (>3cm), or hyperdense cysts that are totally intrarenal. These cysts are more complex and do not fit into categories II or III. They require follow-up for up to 5 years to exclude malignancy.

Class III: These are complicated cysts having thickened septa with nodular areas of calcification. The walls of the cyst or septae show enhancement. The class III lesions should be surgically explored or biopsied. <50% will turn out to be malignant.

Class IV: These are malignant lesions with solid enhancing nodules. Surgical removal to be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute indication for a cesarean section?
questions.solution:
Among the following, vaginal stenosis is an absolute indication of a cesarean section(CS).

Cesarean is needed even with a dead fetus when vaginal delivery is not possible.
The following are the absolute indication:

  • Central placenta previa 
  • Contracted pelvis or cephalopelvic disproportion (absolute)
  • Pelvic mass causing an obstruction (cervical or broad ligament fibroid)
  • Advanced carcinoma cervix 
  • Vaginal atresia or stenosis

Relative indications for cesarean section are those where vaginal delivery may be possible but risks to the mother and/or baby are high. They are as follows:

  • Nonreassuring FHR
  • Dystocia- It may be due to a relatively large fetus (passenger), small pelvis (passage), or inefficient uterine contractions (power)
  • Antepartum hemorrhage: Placenta previa and abruptio placenta
  • Malpresentation: Breech, shoulder (transverse lie), brow
  • Previous cesarean delivery-a) When primary CS was due to recurrent indication (contracted pelvis), (b) Previous two CS,(c) Features of scar dehiscence, (d) Previous classical CS
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion (relative)
  • Failure to progress in labor
  • Hypertensive disorders: Severe pre-eclampsia, eclampsia— uncontrolled fits even with antiseizure therapy.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with the following finding. What is the WHO clinical stage of HIV?
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis (thrush) is categorized as WHO clinical stage 3.

Oral Candidiasis (Thrush), and oral hairy leukoplakia, are oral lesions characterized in WHO clinical Stage 3. They generally occur in patients with CD4+ T cell counts of <300/μL.

Differentiating oral candidiasis and oral hairy leukoplakia:

  • Oral Candidiasis (Thrush) appears as a white, cheesy exudate, on an erythematous mucosa in the posterior oropharynx. The diagnosis is made by direct examination of pseudohyphal elements.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia presents as white, frondlike lesions, generally along the lateral borders of the tongue and sometimes on the adjacent buccal mucosa(image below). Despite its name, oral hairy leukoplakia is not considered premalignant. Lesions are associated with the Ebstein-Barr virus (EBV).

Related Pearl: Clinical stages of HIV in children/ infants

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly
  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Extensive wart virus infection
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum
  • Recurrent oral ulcerations
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement
  • Linear gingival erythema
  • Herpes zoster
  • Recurrent or chronic upper respiratory infections (otitis media, otorrhoea, sinusitis, tonsilitis)
  • Fungal nail infections

Stage 3

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis
  • Lymph node TB
  • Pulmonary TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

Stage 4

  • Unexplained severe wasting, stunting or malnutrition not responding to standard therapy
  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Recurrent severe bacterial infections (e.g., empyema, pyomyositis, bone or joint infection, meningitis, but excluding pneumonia)
  • Chronic Herpes Simplex infection; (oro-labial or cutaneous of more than one month's duration or visceral at any site)
  • Extrapulmonary TB and disseminated non-tuberculosis mycobacterial infection
  • Kaposi Sarcoma
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Central nervous system toxoplasmosis (after one month of life)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Cytomegalovirus infection; retinitis or CMV infection affecting another organ, with onset at age over 1 month)
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (including meningitis)
  • Disseminated endemic mycosis (extrapulmonary histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis and isosporiasis
  • Cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and occasional blood-stained nasal discharge. His CT and endoscopy findings are shown in the below image. What could be the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
In an elderly patient, unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and pale polypoidal mass arising from the lateral wall of the nose are suggestive of inverted papilloma (Ringertz tumour).

Inverted papilloma (transitional cell papilloma) is a tumour originating from the nonolfactory mucosa of the nose (Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses. The most common site of origin is the lateral wall of the nose in the middle meatus. The unilateral growth of hyperplastic papillomatous tissue into the stroma characterizes this condition. Human papillomavirus (HPV) is believed to be the cause.

It primarily affects men aged 40-70 and presents unilaterally with symptoms such as nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. Invasive growth into the sinuses or orbit can lead to proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation.

On nasal endoscopy, it appears as a pale polypoidal mass resembling a nasal polyp. Computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) are used to determine the location and extent of the lesion. MRI can also help differentiate between associated sinus secretions and the tumour mass. The biopsy is essential for diagnosis, as it is important to differentiate it from simple nasal polyps, which may be associated with or mistaken for the tumour.

The treatment of choice is medial maxillectomy, which can be performed through lateral rhinotomy, sublabial degloving approach, or preferably, an endoscopic approach. In 10%-15% of cases, the tumour is associated with malignancy. Recurrence is possible, and radiotherapy is generally not recommended due to the potential risk of inducing malignancy.

Other options: 

Option B: Carcinoma maxilla arises from the lining of the maxillary sinus and its early features include additional symptoms like facial paraesthesias, pain, or epiphora and depending on the direction of spread of the growth, would cause additional symptoms.

Option C: Esthesioneuroblastoma (olfactory neuroblastoma) arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of the nose. It has bimodal peaks of incidence at 10–20 years and 50–60 years. Unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis are the most common symptoms. The tumour also invades the orbit and the surrounding structures, which results in other symptoms like proptosis, headache, epiphora, diplopia, and blurred vision.

Option D: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is seen almost exclusively in males in the age group of 10–20 years and is very rarely seen in older people and females. Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis are the most common presentations.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination, she has normal breast and pubic hair development, but her vagina ends in a blind pouch, and her uterus is not palpable. What is the next step in the investigation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a girl with primary amenorrhea, normal breasts, and pubic hair, with a blind-ending vagina and non-palpable uterus, is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis. The next step would be to do an ultrasound to look for uterine anomalies.

Absent uterus and vagina in a person with female genotype and phenotype are features of Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome. In this condition, the ovaries are normal and secondary sexual characters are well-developed with normal external genitalia. This condition is associated with anomalies of the spine/skeleton and the kidneys along with the urinary tract.

Diagnosis is made with the help of pelvic sonography, MRI or laparoscopy. Patients may have rudimentary Mullerian bulbs without an endometrial cavity. These should be surgically excised if they are symptomatic.

Given below is an algorithm for the diagnosis of primary amenorrhea with secondary sexual characteristics:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male diagnosed with carcinoma of the larynx is scheduled for treatment and has undergone the procedure shown in the image below. At what level is the incision made for this procedure?

choices.text: At the level of the 2nd tracheal ring
At the level of the 1st tracheal ring

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a 50-year-old male with carcinoma of the larynx undergoing a tracheostomy, as shown in the image. The incision is made at the level of the first tracheal ring, above the isthmus, in a patient with laryngeal carcinoma, and this procedure is referred to as a high tracheostomy.

Laryngeal carcinoma is an indication of high tracheostomy. It is done at the level of the 1st tracheal ring and an opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. High tracheostomy is performed above the level of the thyroid isthmus (the Isthmus lies against the II, III, and IV tracheal rings). The only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx.

It provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
It uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood.

Indications of tracheostomy:

  • Respiratory obstruction due to infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis, diphtheria).
  • Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures.
  • Neoplasms.
  • Foreign bodies or edema.
  • Retained secretionsInability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles.
  • Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions.
  • Painful cough.
  • Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

Steps of Tracheostomy:

  • Incision: Make a vertical incision in the midline from the cricoid cartilage to above the sternal notch. For a better cosmetic outcome for elective procedures, a 5 cm transverse incision two fingers' breadth above the sternal notch can be used.
  • Dissection: Dissect tissues in the midline. Displace or ligate any dilated veins encountered to control bleeding.
  • Muscle separation: Separate and retract the strap muscles of the neck laterally to expose underlying structures.
  • Thyroid isthmus management: Displace the thyroid isthmus upwards or divide and ligate it with sutures.
  • Local anaesthesia: Inject a few drops of 4% lignocaine into the trachea to suppress coughing.
  • Tracheal incision: Fix the trachea with a hook and make a vertical incision between the third and fourth tracheal rings(Option D), converting it into a circular opening. Avoid dividing the first tracheal ring to prevent perichondritis and stenosis.
  • Inserting the tube: Insert a tracheostomy tube of appropriate size into the tracheal opening and secure it with tapes.
  • Avoid tight suturing: Avoid tightly suturing or packing the skin incision to prevent subcutaneous emphysema.
  • Dressing: Place a gauze dressing between the skin and the flange of the tracheostomy tube around the stoma to absorb secretions, provide a barrier against infection, and allow air to escape, promoting proper healing.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination, she is found to have normally developed breasts and normal external genitalia. She has swelling in the right inguinal region. Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis did not reveal the uterus or cervix. The karyotype is XY. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings in the question are seen in complete androgen insensitivity syndrome/ testicular feminizing syndrome. In this syndrome, the response of the androgen receptors to androgens is defective.

The findings of the given case can be explained as follows:

  • Primary amenorrhea → Due to the absence of a uterus and cervix.
  • Normally developed breasts → Due to the conversion of the excessive androgens into estrogen.
  • Swelling in the inguinal region → Suggestive of an underdeveloped ectopic testis, caused by loss of action of testosterone on its receptor.
  • Female type external genitalia → In the absence of testosterone's action on genitalia, the genital tubercle enlarges to form the clitoris.
  • Absence of uterus and cervix → Due to the production of Mullerian inhibiting substance from the Sertoli cells of the testis.
  • And finally, the XY karyotype indicates that the patient is a genotypic male.

Other options:

Option A: Swyer's syndrome or pure gonadal dysgenesis occurs as a result of a mutation in the SRY gene or another gene with a testis-determining effect such as DAX1, SF-1, or CBX2. This leads to underdeveloped, dysgenetic gonads that fail to produce androgens or anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH).

Option C:  21-hydroxylase deficiency causes Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia with virilization in females and ambiguous genitalia. It leads to low cortisol and aldosterone levels, resulting in hypotension and hyperkalemia.

Option D: Noonan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition found in both males and females. It is associated with low IQ, delayed puberty, low fertility, pulmonary stenosis and HOCM.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old patient presents with nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever for a week and developed jaundice yesterday. On abdominal examination, he has tenderness in the right upper quadrant. His laboratory evaluation is given below. What is the management for his condition?
IgM Anti-HAV positive
HBsAg negative
HBeAg negative
Anti-HBs positive
S.aminotransferases elevated
questions.solution:
This patient with gastrointestinal symptoms and positive IgM- HAV is likely to have acute hepatitis A infection and requires supportive treatment. 

Since most patients recover spontaneously, only supportive treatment is required. 

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is an icosahedral, non enveloped virus that causes hepatitis A infection. HAV is transmitted by the fecal-oral route. Usually, it is due to contamination of food or water. It may transmit from person to person due to poor hygiene. It mostly is of mild nature, with only 0.1% of patients developing fulminant hepatitis.

It has an incubation period of 15 - 45 days. It may present with constitutional symptoms of nausea, vomiting, anorexia, malaise, myalgia, arthralgia, headache, and photophobia. 1-2 weeks after the constitutional symptoms, patients present with jaundice and tender hepatomegaly. Low-grade fever may also be present. 

This is followed by a recovery phase where the constitutional symptoms disappear but the hepatomegaly and elevated transaminases are still present. Full recovery is expected 1-2 months after the onset. 

Diagnosis of HAV is confirmed by IgM anti-HAV during acute illness. 

It can be prevented by HAV vaccination.

Other options:

Option B - Antivirals are not needed in HAV. They may be used in hepatitis B or C. 

Option C - Physical isolation is done in hepatitis A patients with fecal incontinence. This patient does not have fecal incontinence. Even then, HAV is excreted in feces in very small amounts. Using gloves to handle fecal matter is sufficient.

Option D - Interferon therapy is useful in the treatment of chronic HCV and HBV infections. They are cytokines that have antiviral, immunomodulatory, and antiproliferative activity.

questions.text:
An elderly male presented with painless, gross hematuria and was evaluated accordingly. A cystoprostatectomy was performed, and the gross specimen, shown below, reveals a tumor invading the detrusor muscle. What is the appropriate management?

BCG-Bacille Calmette-Guerin

choices.text: Radical cystectomy and lymph node dissection
Endoscopic resection followed by intravesical mitomycin C

questions.solution:
The given image of the cystoprostatectomy specimen shows a large, fungating growth from the bladder wall involving the entire bladder and invading the detrusor muscle with the two lobes of the prostate not being much affected. The most likely diagnosis of muscle-invasive bladder carcinoma and appropriate management include radical cystectomy and lymph node dissection.

Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. Subsequent clots and urinary retention can occur. Increased frequency and discomfort during urination may be seen. It can lead to pelvic pain due to extravesical spread, loin pain due to hydronephrosis, and suprapubic pain if the nerve is involved.

Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma is divided into 3 groups:

  • Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ (CIS).
  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - does not invade detrusor muscle but can invade lamina propria. It accounts for 70% of cases.
  • Muscle-invasive bladder cancer - invades the detrusor muscle.

Diagnosis and staging are done by cystoscopy and resection of the tumour. A bimanual examination should be performed after the resection of the tumour. Complete urinary tract imaging is required using contrast computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance (MR) urography.

Management:

  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - Endoscopic resection and intravesical instillations of mitomycin C(Option C)/ epirubicin, immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)(Option A).
  • Muscle invasive bladder cancer - Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Etiological Factors for Bladder Carcinoma

Cigarette smoking
Exposure to aryl amines, particularly 2-
naphthylamine and related compounds (e.g., in diesel exhaust, in paint products)
Schistosoma haematobium infestation
Long-term use of analgesics (phenacetin)
Heavy-dose long-term use of cyclophosphamide
Radiotherapy
Congenital bladder exstrophy

Inherited cancer syndromes:

  • Lynch syndrome
  • Heriditary retinoblastoma
  • Costello syndrome

Acquired genetic mutations in FGFR3, HRAS, P53, RB genes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity is set to undergo reconstruction surgery of the oral cavity. The following flap is used. All of the following are signs of arterial compromise in the flap except:
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, a patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity is undergoing reconstructive surgery. The flap shown in the image is a radial forearm free flap and increasing warmth is not indicative of arterial compromise in a free flap.

The tissue becoming cooler and not warm is a sign of arterial compromise in a flap.

Clinical signs of arterial and venous compromise in a free-flap:

Clinical Sign Arterial Compromise Venous Compromise
Colour Becoming paler Increasingly reddish or purplish
Temperature Becoming cooler Becoming warmer
Tissue turgor Reducing (OptionA) Increasing
Capillary refill time Becoming slower (Option B) Becoming faster
Pinprick bleeding Increasingly sluggish (Option D) Quickening (and darkening)

Note: Venous and arterial compromise may coexist, and one may lead to the other.

Types of flaps are described in the image given below.

questions.text: An elderly man is brought to the hospital after he complained of sudden jerky movements of his hands, which persist even when he is asleep. There is also a history of impaired memory. He underwent a corneal transplant 3 years ago. His electroencephalogram showed periodic slow sharp waves. His MRI scan is shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The MRI shows the presence of cortical ribboning. This finding, along with the presence of dementia, periodic slow sharp waves on the electroencephalogram, and myoclonic jerks are suggestive of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a prion disease that causes higher cortical function deficits. This infection can be acquired by corneal transplantation, contaminated electroencephalogram (EEG) electrode implantation, dura mater grafts, and contaminated human growth hormone (HGH) preparations.

Patients commonly present with myoclonus and dementia. EEG shows characteristic periodic electrical bursts. MRI shows increased intensity in the basal ganglia and cortical ribboning (ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri). On light microscopy, the pathologic hallmarks of CJD are spongiform degeneration and astrocytic gliosis.

The image below shows the presence of periodic electrical bursts of triphasic sharp waves on the electroencephalogram of a patient with CJD:

The given image shows increased intensity in the basal ganglia and cortical ribboning in a CJD patient:

 Other options:

Option A- Sturge Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angiomas of the leptomeninges and in the ophthalmic and maxillary nerve areas of distribution. Affected patients might have developmental delays, learning difficulties, and seizures. CT shows the presence of a tram track appearance.

Option C- Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a progressive demyelinating disease of the brain that occurs due to a previous infection with the measles virus. Most patients have a history of measles infection from many years ago. SSPE presents with intellectual disability, poor school performance, and mood and personality changes. EEG shows high voltage slow sharp waves that occur every 3-8 seconds followed by a flat background.

Option D- Patients with tuberous sclerosis present with seizures, mental retardation, adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas), shagreen patch, hypomelanotic macules, periungual fibromas, renal angiomyolipomas, cardiac rhabdomyomas. Imaging may show the presence of subependymal nodules, cortical tubers, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas.

questions.text: This patient developed a severe cough while performing the following procedure on him. Which of the following nerve can be attributed to this?
questions.solution:
The image shows syringing which is a procedure done for impacted wax. Reflex cough due to stimulation of the auricular branch of the vagus can occur during this procedure.

Wax is made up of sebaceous and ceruminous gland secretions, hair, desquamated epithelial debris, keratin, and dirt. Factors contributing to the accumulation and impaction of excess wax may be a narrow, tortuous external canal, stiff ear, or obstructive lesions in the canal.

Patients with impacted wax may present with impaired hearing, tinnitus or giddiness. Long-standing impacted wax may ulcerate meatal skin and result in the formation of a wax granuloma.

Wax removal is achieved through syringing or other instrumental manipulation. The hard impacted mass may require prior softening with wax solvents in some cases.

The patient is seated, with the ear to be syringed facing the examiner. The patient wears a kidney tray over his or her shoulder and to collect the return fluid, the patient's head is tilted over the tray. A stream of water from the syringe is directed along the posterosuperior wall of the meatus as the pinna is pulled upwards and backwards. The ear canal and tympanic membrane must be inspected and dried with a pledget of cotton at the end of the procedure.

Complications of syringing:

  • Vertigo– caloric stimulation of lateral semicircular canal if water is too hot or too cold.
  • Rupture of the tympanic membrane.
  • Reactivation of quiescent otitis media, if there is pre-existing perforation.

Contraindications for syringing include the presence of ear infection, tympanic membrane perforation and the presence of a grommet or history of ear surgery.

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman presents with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements in a hypertensive pregnant woman points to the diagnosis of placental abruption.  

Premature separation of a normally implanted placenta is placental abruption. Hypertension is a very important etiological factor in abruption. 

The hemorrhage into decidua basalis causes separation and compression of the placenta. This leads to a compromise of circulation to fetus, leading to fetal distress. The bleeding may escape through the cervix to cause external hemorrhage.

Clinical classification of placental abruption:

Grade 1 Grade 2 Grade 3
Vaginal bleeding is slight Vaginal bleeding mild to moderate Bleeding is moderate to severe or concealed.

Uterus irritable, minimal tenderness

 Uterine tenderness is always present Uterine tenderness is marked.
Maternal BP and fibrinogen unaffected Maternal pulse increased, BP maintained Shock is pronounced
FHS good Fetal distress present Fetal death is the rule
Maternal shock absent Maternal shock absent Associated coagulation defect or anuria may complicate

Other options:

Option B: Placenta previa presents with painless vaginal bleeding. Hypertension is not a predisposing factor. High-risk factors include multiparty, previous cesarean, or myomectomy scar in the uterus.

Option C: In preterm labor, fetal movements are not compromised.

Option D: Hydramnios does not present with bleeding PV.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with an ovarian tumor. Histopathological examination of tumor specimen reveals sheets of mucin-producing signet ring cells as seen below.  Identify the true statement regarding this ovarian tumor.

choices.text: Normal shape of ovary is retained
Ovary is attached to nearby viscera and becomes immobile

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histopathology showing signet ring cells is suggestive of Krukenberg tumor and in this ovarian tumor, the normal shape of the ovary is retained.

Krukenberg tumor: These are secondary growth in the ovary and most often arise from a primary carcinoma of the stomach (70%), large bowel (15%), and breast (6%).

Features:

  • Usually bilateral (Option D)
  • Have a smooth surface
  • They retain the shape of the normal ovary.
  • There is no tendency to form adhesions with neighboring viscera and they are freely movable in the pelvis (Option C)
  • There is no infiltration through the capsule (Option A)
  • Have a waxy consistency

Histologically, Numerous signet-ring cells with pale cytoplasm are seen.

questions.text: A 25-year-old G2A1 at 18 weeks of gestation came with complaints of leaking PV for the past 4 hours. On examination, membranes are ruptured and uterine contractions present. Which of the following sonographic findings is indicative of cervical incompetence in this patient _______

choices.text: Short cervix <25 mm and funelling of internal os >1cm
Short cervix >25 mm and funelling of internal os <1cm
Short cervix <35 mm and funelling of internal os <1cm
Short cervix >35mm and funelling of internal os >1cm

questions.solution:
Transvaginal ultrasound is the ideal method to follow up and detect cervical incompetence. Features of short cervix <25 mm and funnelling of internal os >1 cm is seen in cervical incompetence.

Cervical incompetence or insufficiency is a functional or anatomical impairment in the retentive power of the cervix (or internal os). It is characterized by repeated, mid-trimester painless cervical dilatation. It leads to the escape of amniotic fluid followed by painless expulsion of the products of conception.

In the inter-conceptional period, diagnosis is made with the passage of number 6-8 Hegar's dilator beyond the internal os without resistance or pain. Investigations for cervical incompetence during pregnancy include:

  • Per speculum examination - shows cervical dilatation with herniation of membranes
  • Transvaginal ultrasound - funneling of internal os >1 cm and cervical length <25 mm
Prophylactic cervical cerclage is done between 12-14 weeks of gestation. Rescue or emergency cerclage is done when there is bulging or prolapse of membranes through a dilated cervix.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented previous history of chlamydia infection now presents with low-grade fever and non-specific lower abdominal pain. Examination reveals mild diffuse lower abdominal tenderness on deep palpation, cervical motion tenderness, and a mucopurulent vaginal discharge. What is the long-term sequelae of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a pelvic inflammatory disease and the most important complication of it is infertility.

Pelvic Inflammatory disease involves inflammation of the upper genital tract including the fallopian tubes as well as the ovaries. The most common cause of PID in sexually active young females is sexually transmitted infections involving gonococci and chlamydia.

Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility. Other complications are tubo-ovarian abscesses (hydrosalpinx or pyosalpinx), chronic interstitial salpingitis, tubo ovarian cyst and ectopic pregnancies. Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome). The patient presents with right upper quadrant pain and tenderness with abnormal liver function tests.

Risk factors of PID:

  • Menstrual teenagers
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Absence of contraceptive pills
  • Previous history of PID
  • IUCD users

Protective factors of PID:

  • Barrier methods (condoms, diaphragm)
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Pregnancy
  • Menopause

Criteria to diagnose PID:

Any one of the minimum criteria + 1 or more additional criteria are required for the clinical diagnosis of PID.

Minimum criteria

  • Lower abdominal tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness.

Additional criteria

  • Oral temperature >38.3 oC
  • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability
  • Presence of abundant WBC on saline microscopy of vaginal fluid
  • Raised ESR or CRP
  • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or C.trachomatis.

The definitive diagnosis of PID is through:

  • Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy.
  • Imaging (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes i.e., tubo-ovarian abscess.
  • Laparoscopic evidence of PID.

Treatment

  • OPD management of PID:
    • Inj.Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + Doxycycline 100 mg BD x 14 days + Metronidazole 500 mg BD x 14 days.
  • Parenteral treatment for PID (in hospitalised:
    • Inj Cefotetan 2g IV BD + Doxycycline 100 mg BD or
    • Inj Cefoxitin 2g IV QID + Doxycycline 100 mg BD.

To minimize disease transmission, women should be instructed to abstain from sexual intercourse until therapy is completed, symptoms have resolved, and partners have been adequately treated.

Related Pearl: Organisms Responsible for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

Sexually transmitted: Gonococcus, Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Trichomonas 
Aerobes: Staphylococci , Streptococci ,E. coli
Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis, Peptococcus, Clostridium, Actinomyces (IUD)
Others: Tubercular salpingitis
 

Related Pearl: Treatment of choice in chronic PID

Patient characteristics

Choice of surgery

Young woman

Conservative surgery or Salpingectomy or Salpingo-oophorectomy

When extensive damage precludes conservative management

and

When the patient is multiparous and of an older age group

Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

Mild case of PID adequately treated

and

Minimal damage but the infection may lead to infertility

Tuboplasty

questions.text: A 55 year old patient presented with chronic projectile vomiting and weight loss. What is the expected metabolic abnormality to be seen here ?

choices.text: Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypernatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypercalcemia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic acidosis with hyponatremia

questions.solution:
The expected metabolic abnormality to be seen in this patient is hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

The persistent vomiting results in these abnormalities along with paradoxical aciduria. 

  • Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).
  • Kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3- causing hyponatremia. However, loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway.
  • The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions.
  • Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia.
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to the loss of HCl, and instead of compensating for that loss, the body loses more H+ ions through urine.

Related Pearl: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders

Metabolic acidosis

Metabolic alkalosis

Respiratory acidosis

Respiratory alkalosis

Ketoacidosis

Lactic acidosis

Chronic renal failure

Salicylate intoxication

Methanol/formaldehyde intoxication

Loop or thiazide diuretics

Opiates, sedatives, anesthesia

High altitude
