questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows a triple bubble sign which is seen in jejunal atresia. 

Jejunal atresia is a congenital anomaly which presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension soon after birth. A small amount of meconium may be passed despite the atresia. Plain X-ray abdomen shows multiple air-fluid levels, known as the triple bubble sign. Contrast study is the next best investigation to exclude other large bowel anomalies. In most cases, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is done. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis

Other options:

Option A: Duodenal atresia occurs due to failure of vacuolization of the solid duodenum. Neonates with duodenal atresia usually present with bilious vomiting and abdominal distention. Plain X-ray shows two foci of gas, one in the stomach and the other in the duodenum, known as the double bubble sign.

Option C: Small bowel obstruction shows dilated bowel loops with multiple air fluid levels. Supine X-ray shows a row of gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae coniventes, within fluid-filled dilated small bowels, resembling a string of beads.
 
Option D: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis presents between 2 and 6 weeks of age with projectile, non-bilious vomiting, and abdominal distension. The hypertrophied pylorus may present as an olive-shaped mass. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm in ultrasound.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

questions.text: Diagnose the respiratory condition based on the CT given below?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this patient is bronchiectasis. The CT scan shows the signet ring sign which is specific for bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis refers to the irreversible dilatation of one or more bronchi, which occurs due to recurrent cycles of infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Development of the disease requires an infectious insult in combination with impaired bacterial clearance (eg, impaired immune defenses, structural airway defect).

The clinical scenario observed in bronchiectasis is: 

  • Repeated chest infections 
  • Presence of large amounts of yellow sputum 
  • Non-smoker 

Bronchiectasis is commonly associated with

  • Kartagener syndrome
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

Radiological findings - Chest X-ray shows tram track appearance due to the dilated airways. 

CT findings include:

  • Tram track appearance
  • Signet ring sign
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Tree-in-bud pattern - It occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.
  • Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

Note: High-Resolution CT (HRCT) is the best method for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. 

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients often present with chronic cough and hemoptysis. Low-grade fever, anorexia, and weight loss are the commonly associated symptoms. CT findings of pulmonary tuberculosis are Ghon focus, Ranke complex, nodal calcifications, cavities, and hilar/paratracheal lymphadenopathy.

Option B: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease[COPD], is inflammation-induced destruction of lung parenchyma resulting from cigarette smoke or other pollutants. Patients typically will be smokers with exertional dyspnea, and cough with productive sputum. Lung hyperinflation (emphysema) and airflow obstruction are characteristic of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. 

Option C: Bronchial asthma is an airway hyperresponsiveness disease characterized by reversible airway narrowing and obstruction by mucus plugging. Patients typically present with symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough usually on exposure to triggering agents. CT findings in bronchial asthma are bronchial wall thickening, mucus plugging, decreased lung attenuation, and gas trapping.

questions.text: Mr. Abert presents to the casualty with a history of severe colicky abdominal pain for the past 5 hours. He says that it starts from the right loin and radiates to the right groin. The doctor suspects ureteric stone. Which among the following is the investigation of choice to assess these stones?
questions.solution:
Non-contrast CT abdomen (NCCT) is the investigation of choice for the clinical evaluation of ureteric stones.

NCCT is the preferred investigation for evaluation of:

  • Renal stones, except for indinavir stones.
  • Ureteric stones.
  • Head injury.
  • Salivary gland stones.

Ureterolithiasis is associated with flank and lower back pain radiating to the groin. 

For the management of a patient with an impacted renal stone, first, the size of the stone should be ascertained.

  • If it is <6mm, then it can pass through the ureters and the bladders. Patients should be given adequate pain control with NSAIDs and if required, opioids.
  • Alpha-blockers like tamsulosin and nifedipine, which is a calcium channel blocker, cause relaxation of the ureteric smooth muscles and allow the stone to pass easily.
  • Percutaneous nephrolithotomy is the preferred treatment for large renal stones of a diameter of  >1.5-2.5 cm, in the presence of multiple stones.

Related Pearl: Management of renal and ureteric calculi

ESWL: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy

PCNL: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy

URS: Ureteroscopic retrieval of stones

questions.text: Interpret the given audiogram:
questions.solution:
The given audiogram suggests Right-sided sensorineural deafness.

Interpretation:

  • Red indicates the right ear.
  • "O" indicates Air conduction(AC). The threshold here is >15 dB indicating abnormal AC.
  • "< "indicates Bone conduction(BC). The threshold is >25 dB indicating abnormal BC.
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal sensorineural hearing loss.
  • There is no Air-Bone gap.
  • Hence, it is right-side sensorineural hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient who has been diagnosed with aggressive pancreatic cancer presents with intractable abdominal pain unresponsive to opioids. The anesthetist decides to opt for a regional block. Which of the following would he choose?
questions.solution:
The block he would choose in the case of pancreatic cancer is celiac plexus block.

The celiac plexus block is indicated in patients with pain arising from the abdominal viscera, specifically intraabdominal cancers. 

The celiac ganglia are generally clustered at the level of the body of the L1 vertebra, posterior to the inferior vena cava on the right and lateral to the aorta on the left. It is posterior to the pancreas. 

The patient is placed in a prone position and 15-20 ml of local anesthetic is injected under fluoroscopic, CT, or ultrasound guidance. The needed should be inserted 7-8cm from the midline at the inferior edge of the spinous process of L1. 

The approaches that can be taken for this block include the posterior retrocrural approach, posterior anterocrural approach, posterior transaortic approach, an anterior approach. 

The most common complication is postural hypotension. This occurs due to blocking of visceral sympathetic innervation which results in vasodilation. To prevent this, the patient should be adequately hydrated intravenously. 

Other options: 

Option A: The stellate block is indicated in patients with head, neck, arm, and upper chest pain. 

Option B: The lumbar sympathetic block is indicated in painful conditions involving the pelvis and lower extremities like a peripheral vascular disease. 

Option D: The superior hypogastric plexus block is indicated in pelvic pain that is unresponsive to lumbar or caudal epidural blocks. It is used in patients with cancer of the pelvic organs or non-cancer pelvic pain.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with resting tremors, difficulty in initiating movements, poor balance, and frequent falls. What is the site of the lesion of this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is Parkinson's disease, and the site of the lesion is substantia nigra.

Parkinson's disease is a degenerative condition of the dopamine-secreting neurons of the substantia nigra. Patients present with muscular rigidity, involuntary resting tremors of the hands, akinesia - difficulty in initiating movement - and postural instability. On examination, cog-wheel rigidity and a shuffling gait are seen. Dysphagia, speech disorders, sleep disturbances and cognitive impairment are also seen. 

The substantia nigra is a part of the basal ganglia of the brain. It is a part of the ancillary putamen circuit. Neurons from the substantia nigra project to the caudate nucleus and putamen, known as the nigrostriatal pathway. They secrete dopamine, which is inhibitory. Thus, the caudate nucleus and putamen send continuous excitatory signals to the corticospinal tract. This contributes to the rigidity seen in Parkinsonism.  

The primary treatment for Parkinson's disease is L-dopa. It is converted to dopamine in the brain and reduces the motor symptoms. 

Other options:

Option B: Thalamus plays a role in memory, emotions, the sleep-wake cycle, and in the processing of sensory information and relaying it to the cortex. Lesions in the thalamus are seen in a multitude of disorders including vascular diseases, metabolic disorders, inflammatory diseases, and infections.

Option C: A lesion in the globus pallidus can give rise to athetosis. This involves spontaneous and continuous writhing movements of the hand, arm, neck, or face.

Option D: A lesion in the subthalamic nucleus causes sudden violent involuntary, and flinging movements confined to one side of the body, commonly affecting the proximal muscles of the limbs, a condition called hemiballismus. The movements are seen contralateral to the side of the lesion.

Related Pearl: Abnormal movements

 

 Movement Site Discription Cause
Intentional tremor Cerebellum Only on activity 
  • Trauma
  • Stroke
  • Alcohol
  • Drugs
Resting tremor

Substantia nigra

Red nucleus

 Disappear on movement
  •  Parkinsonism
Hyperkinetic tremor Sympathetic overactivity  Precipitated by emotion , stress
  • Anxiety 
  • Hyperthyroidism 
Asterixis Cortex Inability to sustain a muscle contraction while performing a complex motor movement
  • Hepatic encephalopathy 
Chorea Caudate nucleus  Rapid jerky movement
  • Rheumatic chorea
  • Huntington chorea
  • Drug induced 
Hemibalismus Subthalamic nucleus Unilateral wild flinging violent movement of large proximal joints
  • Vascular>degenerative 
Athetosis Basal ganglia- Globus Pallidum Slow rything movement involving distal joints

  • Degenerative 
  • Infiltrative

questions.text: Which of the following  treatment modalities  is used in symptomatic parathyroid hyperplasia involving all four glands?

choices.text: Removal of all the affected glands with lifelong calcium supplementation
Complete removal of three glands with partial resection of the less affected gland
Partial resection of the affected glands with autotransplantation of the less affected gland
Complete removal of three glands with ligation of inferior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
Hyperplasia involving all four parathyroid glands is treated by complete removal of three glands with partial resection of the less affected gland (~30 mg left as a remnant)

Modes of treatment: 

  • Subtotal parathyroidectomy 
  • Total cervical parathyroidectomy with immediate heterotopic transplantation of parathyroid tissue (usually the forearm

Subtotal Parathyroidectomy: 

Remnant left behind should be of the least affected parathyroid gland, and ideally be 30 mg (size of 1 parathyroid gland). A lower gland is preferred because its location reduces the risk of injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve. 

Total Parathyroidectomy with heterotopic transplantation : 

When multiple parathyroids are resected, parathyroid tissue is transplanted to the non-dominant forearm. Pockets are made in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and one to two pieces of parathyroid tissue measuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady presented with vomiting, abdominal distention, and postprandial epigastric pain.  A barium meal follow-through of the patient is given below. Which of the given statements regarding the patient's likely condition is false?

choices.text: Third part of the duodenum is compressed
Angle between superior mesenteric artery and aorta is more obtuse (>100)
This condition is also called as Wilkie’s syndrome

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium follow-through demonstrating dilation of the duodenum with an abrupt cut-off at its third part, coinciding with the line of the superior mesenteric artery is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome/Wilkie syndrome. In this condition, the angle between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta is more acute (<20 degrees).

Wilkie syndrome is usually seen in young women who are physically weak. It is a rare condition in which the SMA compresses the third portion of the duodenum. The normal aortomesenteric angle is between 38-65 degrees. This is reduced to 20 degrees (according to some texts it is 15.2 degrees and in some, it is 18 degrees) in SMA syndrome. The SMA obstructs the third part of the duodenum by compressing it against fixed retroperitoneal structures. 

Symptoms include epigastric pain which is episodic and postprandial in nature, nausea, vomiting, abdominal distention, and weight loss.

SMA syndrome is associated with:

  • Rapid childhood growth
  • Profound weight loss
  • Abdominal surgery
  • Inflammatory diseases of the abdomen
  • Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis and accentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta (cast syndrome)

Upper gastrointestinal barium studies are used for diagnosis. CT is also useful in some cases.

Treatment includes:

  • Medical therapy- frequent small feedings, lying on prone or left side postprandially, weight gain, or removal of a body cast improves symptoms.
  • Laparoscopic lysis of the ligament of Treitz is beneficial in a few cases.
  • The following surgical procedures can be done- duodenojejunostomy, gastrojejunostomy, and duodenal derotation (Strong procedure).

The given image shows compressed angle between SMA and the abdominal aorta in CT angiography.

questions.text: Identify the finding in the given ultrasound image.
questions.solution:
The ultrasound examination of the gallbladder shows a Phrygian cap. It is a normal anatomical variant.

Phrygian cap refers to an anatomical variant of the gallbladder, where, the fundus of the gallbladder folds on itself, or is separated from the body by a partial or complete septum. A true septum is uncommon and is usually an apparent septum due to the gallbladder wall folding. It is an incidental finding that may be seen on CT, MRI, or ultrasound. It causes no symptoms.

The Phrygian cap is named so, due to the resemblance of the ultrasonographic appearance to a hat or cap that is worn by the inhabitants of ancient Phrygia circa 1200 BC.

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling of the right knee joint for one week with the following lesions on his soles. He also complains of pain in his ankle and feet for the past 2 days. He gives a history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows keratoderma blennorrhagica. The clinical scenario describes acute arthritis following a recent infection with an additive pattern (involvement of new joints within a few days). These features suggest the diagnosis of reactive arthritis or Reiter's syndrome. 

Reactive arthritis (ReA) is a condition included in the spectrum of seronegative spondyloarthropathies. It is an acute asymmetric nonpurulent oligoarthritis precipitated by an antecedent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection. It is characterized by a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. It occurs most commonly in the age group 18-40 years and is associated with HLA-B27.

Bacterial triggers for ReA are caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, Chlamydia trachomatis, Clostridium difficile, certain toxigenic Escherichia coli, Ureaplasma urealyticum, and Mycoplasma genitalium.

The clinical features of reactive arthritis include constitutional symptoms like fever, malaise, fatigue, weight loss. Patients develop arthritis which is asymmetric and additive involving large weight-bearing joints like the knee and ankle. Sacroiliitis and spondylitis occur as late sequelae and are more commonly asymmetric. Non-marginal syndesmophytes which are comma-shaped arising from the middle of the vertebral body are seen. Dactylitis or sausage digit and enthesitis are also seen.

Extraarticular manifestation of reactive arthritis:

  • Keratoderma blennorrhagica presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions/crusting on the palms and soles.
  • Oral ulcers: Superficial, transient, and often asymptomatic.
  • Circinate balanitis: consists of vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis.
  • Anterior uveitis
  • Conjunctivitis

Laboratory investigations reveal elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. Synovial fluid analysis shows inflammatory changes with negative culture. Joint radiograph shows juxta-articular osteoporosis, marginal erosions, loss of joint space, and periostitis with new bone formation.

Treatment includes NSAIDs, intralesional glucocorticoids, and antibiotics during the antecedent infection.

Other options:

Option A: Ankylosing spondylitis commonly involves young male adults. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker. 

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for >3 months 

Radiographic findings in ankylosing spondylitis:

Sacro-iliac joints show cardinal sign/earliest sign– erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints

Vertebral changes: Earliest change is the flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’). Bamboo spine appearance occurs due to bridging at several vertebral levels.

X-ray showing the characteristic bamboo-spine appearance:

Option B: Psoriatic arthritis is an asymmetrical oligoarthritis. It is associated with nail pitting/ onycholysis, or dactylitis, enthesitis. The inflammation is prominent in the distal interphalangeal joints. There is dactylitis with pronounced telescoping. Nail dystrophy (hyperkeratosis and onycholysis) affects each of the fingers. Axial involvement may occur.

Radiological features:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of distal interphalangeal joint
  • marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation "whiskering"

X-ray shows 'pencil-in-cup' involving metacarpophalangeal joints:

Option C: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease. Its incidence increases between 25 and 55 years of age. The patient usually presents with swelling and pain in the small joints of the hands. Metacarpophalangeal(MCP) and proximal interphalangeal(PIP) joints are commonly involved. The patient also has morning stiffness in the affected joints.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss, not associated with tinnitus. The following image shows the otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The otoscopic picture of both tympanic membranes exhibits a reddish blush, known as Schwartz sign, due to increased vascularity. This finding, combined with a history of bilateral conductive hearing loss, is indicative of active otosclerosis.

Otosclerosis is caused by bony overgrowth involving the enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. It presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and can worsen with stress and hormonal changes like during pregnancy and menopause. Patients present with a bilateral conductive type of hearing loss, tinnitus (commonly in cochlear type and active stage), paracusis Willisii (better hearing in noisy surroundings than in a quiet place), vertigo, and a monotonous, well-modulated soft speech.

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile. Eustachian tube function is also normal. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve known as the Carhart's notch. Tympanometry shows an As type of tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure.

On examination, Schwartz sign/flamingo flush showing a red blush of the tympanic membrane can be seen. This appearance is due to hypervascularization in the region of the cochlear promontory, which occurs in the active phase of otosclerosis as new blood vessels form around the focus of bone remodelling.

Treatment includes medical, surgical management, and hearing aids. Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage to speed up the maturity of the active focus and halt further cochlear loss. The treatment of choice is surgical management which includes stapedotomy/stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis. Hearing aids are used in patients who refuse or are unfit for the surgery.

The image shown below shows Carhart's notch.

Other options:

Option A: A rising sun sign is seen in the glomus tumour.

Option C: The setting sun sign is an eye sign seen in hydrocephalus.

Option D: Cartwheel appearance is seen in acute suppurative otitis media.

questions.text: Two weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection, a 5-year-old presents with ecchymosis and petechiae all over the body with no  hepatosplenomegaly. Platelet count = 15,000/microL and coagulation profile was normal. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy shows increased megakaryocytes
Bleeding into the joints is a common manifestation
The condition resolves spontaneously in 80% patients

questions.solution:
Mucocutaneous bleeding and reduced platelet count two weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection is suggestive of acute idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. Bleeding into the joints is not a common manifestation of this condition.

Deep tissue bleeding (joints and muscles) such as muscle hematomas and hemarthrosis is seen in coagulation disorders or clotting factor deficiencies. 

Superficial mucocutaneous bleeding such as epistaxis, petechiae, ecchymosis is seen in bleeding disorders or platelet disorders.

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura or idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder in which there is an immune-mediated destruction of platelets.

Acute ITP:

  • Acute presentation with a self-limited course in children and resolves spontaneously in 80% patients.
  • Presenting features
    • Preceded by viral infection
    • Mucocutaneous bleeding
    • Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever and jaundice are absent.
    • Resolves spontaneously in 80% of the cases in 4-6 weeks(Option D).
  • Laboratory features
    • Thrombocytopenia (commonly <20,000 / μL)
    • Normal/Increased megakaryocytes in bone marrow(Option B).
    • Prolonged bleeding time.
    • Normal tests for coagulation (PT/PTT/INR).
    • Peripheral smear is normal(Option A).
  • Treatment 
    • Detailed below

Related Pearl: Differences between Bleeding Disorders and Coagulation disorders

Finding Bleeding disorders Coagulation disorders
Cause Quantitative/Qualitative platelet abnormality Deficiency of clotting factors
Sex More common in females (commonly autoimmune) More common in males (commonly X-linked)
Family history Rare (except in VWD) Common
Petechiae Characteristic  Rare
Superficial ecchymosis Small and Multiple Large and Solitary
Bleeding from superficial cuts  Profuse Minimal persistent
Hemarthrosis Rare Characteristic (most common-knee)
Deep dissecting hematomas Rare Characteristic (most common-iliopsoas)
Laboratory tests Bleeding time is prolonged PT and/or PTT are prolonged
Most common Inherited: VWD

Inherited: Hemophilia A

Acquired: Hemorrhagic diathesis of liver disease

VWD: von Willebrand disease

PT: Prothrombin time

PTT: Partial thromboplastin time

Related Pearl: Idiopathic/Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

It is characterized by

  • Isolated thrombocytopenia—the presence of antibody against platelet membrane glycoprotein and subsequent destruction in reticuloendothelial system
  • Normal bone marrow—normal or even increased number of megakaryocytes
  • Absence of other causes of thrombocytopenia. 

Types:

Acute (<6 months) and chronic (>6 months) idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

questions.text: A man who sustained a crush injury during an earthquake was rescued. His blood pressure was stable and no internal bleeding was detected. A significant reduction in his urine output was noted after some time. Investigations showed urine/plasma creatinine ratio < 20 and urinary sodium of 50 mEq/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette given is intrinsic acute kidney injury (AKI). The history of crush injury is suggestive of rhabdomyolysis leading to AKI.

AKI is defined as a decline in kidney function within 7 days, resulting in the accumulation of nitrogenous waste and other toxic metabolites usually excreted in the urine. It includes a variety of conditions that share some common features such as elevated creatinine levels and reduced urine output. It is broadly divided into three categories:

  • Prerenal azotemia 
  • Intrinsic parenchymal disease
  • Postrenal obstruction

Intrinsic causes can further be divided into acute tubular necrosis, acute glomerulonephritis, and acute interstitial nephritis. Ischemia and nephrotoxins are the main causes of acute tubular necrosis. Nephrotoxins can be exogeneous such as vancomycin, cisplatin, and iodinated contrast agents used for CT imaging. Endogenous toxins include myoglobin, uric acid, and hemoglobin. Crush injuries, heat stroke, and myopathies can result in rhabdomyolysis releasing large amounts of myoglobin. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is usually ≤ 40.

In acute tubular necrosis, urinary sodium is >20 mEq/L. 

Prerenal azotemia arises due to a reduced renal plasma flow. Common causes include hypovolemia, liver failure, and congestive heart failure. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is ≥ 40 and urinary sodium is usually <20mEq/L.

Bladder outlet obstruction, urethral obstruction, and benign prostatic hyperplasia lead to postrenal azotemia. Urinary sodium can be variable.

More causes of AKI are given below:

questions.text: The anaesthetist plans to give the following block for a patient posted for carpel tunnel release. The block with this procedure will be at which of the following levels?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is an infraclavicular block of the brachial plexus at the level of cords.

The infraclavicular block provides anaesthesia at and distal to the elbow including the musculocutaneous nerve making it suitable for surgeries of the forearm and hand. The block spares the intercostobrachial nerve.

Below the clavicle, the fibres of the brachial plexus form three cords with respect to their relation with the axillary artery as lateral, medial and posterior cords. 

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus Blocks

 

Name of Block Level of Block Adequate Analgesia Seen at Limitations

Supraclavicular Distal trunk and proximal division Elbow, forearm and hand Axillary and suprascapular nerve sparing; Pneumothorax, phrenic nerve palsy
Infraclavicular Cords Elbow, forearm and hand Intercostobrachial nerve sparing
Axillary Terminal nerves

Forearm and hand.

  • Most intense block in C7-T1 (Ulnar nerve) distribution
  • Least intense in C5-C6 dermatome
  • Most optimal for procedures from elbow to hand

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presents with generalised weakness and recurrent epistaxis. On examination, the spleen is not palpable. Blood investigations reveal Hb of 5 g/dL, platelet count of 15,000/μL, and WBC count of 3000/μL. What findings are expected to be seen in a bone marrow biopsy of this patient?

choices.text: Macrophages with characteristic crumbled tissue paper appearance.
Numerous needle-like azurophilic granules in the cytoplasm of the promyelocytes.
Erythroid hyperplasia with pathognomonic ring sideroblasts

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of generalised weakness, recurrent epistaxis, impalpable spleen and blood investigations showing pancytopenia, are suggestive of Aplastic anemia. Bone marrow biopsy reveals hypocellularity with fatty infiltration.

Aplastic anemia is a syndrome of chronic primary hematopoietic failure. This results in pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia). The patient will have

  • Decreased red blood cells leading to anemia
  • Decreased white blood cells leading to recurrent infections
  • Decreased platelets leading to petechiae and ecchymoses.

Many other leukemias and lymphomas may have a similar presentation. However, splenomegaly is characteristically absent in these patients. 

The bone marrow is markedly hypocellular. It is largely devoid of hematopoietic cells. Marrow aspirates yield a dry tap having only fat cells, fibrous stroma, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. Aplasia is best appreciated in marrow biopsies. 

The images given below show the normal and hypocellular bone marrow.

Treatment includes:

  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation - best method of management in young patients.
  • Antithymocyte globulin with cyclosporine - elderly patients and patients without HLA-matched donors.
  • Eltrombopag - a thrombopoietin analog used as an add-on therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Bone marrow examination showing macrophages with characteristic crumbled tissue paper appearance is seen in Gaucher disease, due to glucocerebrosidase deficiency. The patients present with haematological abnormalities, organomegaly, and pathological fractures. 

Option B: Acute myeloid leukaemia is most commonly seen in elderly people. Histopathology from bone marrow aspirate reveals Auer rods (needle-like azurophilic granules) in the cytoplasm of the promyelocytes (black arrow) along with a large, uniform population of cells (myeloblasts) with prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow).

Option D: Bone marrow examination showing erythroid hyperplasia with pathognomonic ring sideroblasts is seen in sideroblastic anemia. Sideroblastic anemia are a group of disorders characterized by the presence of nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing non-heme siderotic granules and stain prussian blue positive (sideroblasts). They can be also seen in myelodysplastic syndrome and lead poisoning.

questions.text: The CTG tracing of a woman in labor at 38 weeks gestation is shown in the image below. Which among the following is commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows late decelerations. The fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Causes of late decelerations:

  • Placental pathologies like- post maturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

Other options:

Option A: The CTG given below shows early decelerations. The deceleration coincides with the uterine contractions. It seen in fetal head compression.

Option B: The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

Option D: The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia.

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression.

questions.text: A 45-year-old paraplegic patient was started on the following technique. Which of the following is the indication for this technique?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) or Negative Pressure Wound Therapy(NPWT) which is a therapeutic technique using a vacuum dressing to promote healing in acute and chronic wounds. It can be used to improve wound healing in stage IV pressure sores.

Principle and uses: 

  • An intermittent negative pressure of -125 mmHg hastens debridement and formation of granulation tissue in chronic wounds such as (diabetic foot ulcers as well as stage III and IV pressure ulcers). 
  • It is also used in traumatic wounds, flaps and grafts, and dehisced incisions.

Contraindications:

  • Exposed vital structures (organs, blood vessels, or vascular grafts) can increase the risk of tissue erosion leading to the possible formation of enteric fistulae or haemorrhages.
  • Ongoing infection should be treated before the administration of NPWT.
  • Inadequate debridement of devitalized soft tissue or bone increases the risk of infection.
  • The presence of malignancy in a pre-existing wound (Marjolin’s ulcer). Due to two reasons:
    • The growth of malignant tissue can be promoted in the presence of subatmospheric pressure.
    • Malignant tissue is friable and more prone to bleeding.
  • Fragile skin
  • An allergic reaction towards the adhesive used to maintain the vacuum seal.
  • Though not an absolute contraindication, there is no appreciable benefit in using NPWT for ischemic wounds.

Other options: 

Option B: The management of Marjolin's ulcer involves wide local excision with clear margins to prevent recurrence, often followed by reconstructive surgery. In advanced cases, lymph node dissection and adjuvant therapy like radiotherapy may be required.

Option C: The management of an infected ulcer includes wound debridement to remove necrotic tissue, antibiotic therapy to treat infection, and proper wound care with dressings to promote healing. Addressing underlying conditions, such as diabetes, is also essential.

Option D: The management of an ischemic ulcer involves restoring blood flow through revascularization procedures like angioplasty or bypass surgery. Additionally, wound care, pain control, and addressing risk factors such as smoking and diabetes are essential for healing.

questions.text: A 50 year old patient, has come with sudden onset of chest pain and his CT scan shows the following picture. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is of an aortic dissection, showing an intimal flap, a double lumen, a beak sign and the dilatation of the aorta.

Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of the aorta. Predisposing factors include mainly age, hypertension, Marfan syndrome, and pregnancy. The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain. The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left haemothorax).

Contrast-enhanced CT is currently the most preferred imaging modality for aortic dissection. Double-lumen aorta is seen on CECT. Transesophageal echocardiography is preferred for patients who are unstable for transportation.

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system which uses the location of the proximal tear alone.

The below image is a CECT finding showing a double lumen sign.

The image given below shows aortic dissection in the thoracic aorta with the true lumen as well as the false lumen. The true lumen is often the smaller of the two because of being compressed by the false lumen.

The beak sign is the acute angle formed at the edge of the false lumen in aortic dissection in axial cross-section. It is formed by the borders of the outer aortic wall and the intimal flap and may be partially thrombosed (blunted beak). It is a reliable characteristic that helps in distinguishing from the true lumen.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the casualty following a fall on an outstretched hand. She complains of pain in her left elbow. Examination reveals tenderness and swelling over her left elbow. Her pulse is feeble. An X-ray of this patient is given below. What is the most common vessel injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and X-ray showing posterior fat pad sign are suggestive of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus where vascular injury commonly involves the brachial artery.

Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

It is most commonly seen in children of 5-7 years. The extension type is seen in 98% of the cases while the rest are flexion type. The mechanism of injury involved is usually a fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension. Gartland classification is used for the classification of supracondylar fractures and is of four types.

On examination:

There may be an S-shaped deformity at the elbow. If the proximal fracture fragment is sharp and has penetrated the muscles and fascia, a dimple may be seen on the skin above the elbow (dimple sign). The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture.

Radiology:  

  • An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by the hematoma.
  • Baumann’s angle is the angle between the horizontal line of the elbow and the line drawn through the lateral epiphysis and long axis of the arm. It is normally less than 5 degrees and is checked with the other arm.

The most common nerve to be injured in the extension type is the anterior interosseous nerve while the ulnar nerve is injured in the flexion type. The brachial artery is most likely involved when there is blood vessel involvement.

Cubitus varus or gunstock deformity is the most common angular deformity that results from supracondylar fractures in children. The static deformities of cubitus varus with respect to the distal fragment are :

  • Posterior displacement
  • Horizontal rotation
  • Coronal tilt.

Treatment: 

Conservative management is attempted with closed reduction using traction and counter-traction. Successful reduction is when the long axis of the arm and forearm lie in parallel. If conservative management fails, skin or skeletal traction is employed but is not used anymore due to better treatment modalities.

Surgery is by either closed reduction and percutaneous internal fixation with K-wires or open reduction and internal fixation with wires or plates

questions.text: A  woman presents with a 6-month history of cough, dyspnea, and fatigue. Investigations reveal hypercalcemia. She has hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray. Which of the following parameters are likely to be elevated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above symptoms, along with hypercalcemia and chest X-ray findings raise suspicion for Sarcoidosis. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels are elevated in this condition as sarcoid granulomas secrete it.

Significant elevation of ACE levels is seen in Sarcoidosis, Silicosis, Leprosy, Gaucher’s disease, Hyperthyroidism and Disseminated granulomatous infections such as miliary tuberculosis.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition with multisystem involvement. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eye, and skin. The most widely accepted etiological hypothesis is an inflammatory response to an infectious or non-infectious trigger in a susceptible host.

Two syndromes are associated with the condition.

  • Lofgren's syndrome is characterized by erythema nodosum and hilar adenopathy. Periarticular arthritis can also be seen.
  • Mikulicz syndrome characterised by bilateral involvement of parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands. 

The hallmarks of sarcoidosis include:

  • B/L hilar lymphadenopathy
  • Non-caseating granulomas
  • Lupus pernio
  • Erythema nodosum (acute sarcoidosis)

Lupus pernio is seen in cutaneous sarcoidosis and presents as infiltrated erythematoviolaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, telangiectasia is characteristic. It is usually painless. As it does not ulcerate, it is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris.

Diagnosis may be established based on clinical features and biopsy findings. Chest X-ray findings include:

  • The parenchymal infiltrates are mostly seen in the upper lobe and appear as diffuse reticular infiltrates.
  • Garland triad is a lymph node enlargement pattern seen on the chest radiographs in sarcoidosis.
  • It involves the right paratracheal nodes, right hilar nodes, and left hilar nodes. It is also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign.
  • Gallium-67 scan:
    • Panda sign- It is due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis, superimposed on the normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.
    • Lambda sign- It is seen in thoracic sarcoidosis. Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes are typically involved which can resemble the lambda symbol (λ).
  • Elevated serum ACE levels: Granulomas in sarcoidosis are known to produce ACE.
  • Hypercalcemia may be seen, due to increased synthesis of calcitriol – 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, by alveolar macrophages. More commonly, there may be hypercalciuria, which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Increased CD4/CD8 ratio of these increased lymphocytes in the BAL fluid. A ratio of >3.5 is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.
  • Bronchoscopy shows the typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa.
  • Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.

The mainstay of treatment is corticosteroids. Systemic therapy is indicated if multiple organs are affected. Immunosuppressants such as mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine, and infliximab can be used in patients who are refractory to steroids. 

Other options: 

Option B: Serum amylase levels are elevated in conditions that affect the pancreas or salivary glands, such as pancreatitis, cancer, sialolithiasis or in the case of Mickulicz syndrome with involvement of the parotid glands.

Option C: Serum calcitonin levels are elevated in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Option D: Serum PTH levels are elevated in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Related Pearl: Types of granulomas

GRANULOMA SEEN IN
Noncaseating granuloma

Crohn’s disease

Leprosy

Sarcoidosis

Hodgkin’s lymphoma
Caseating granuloma

Tuberculosis

Histoplasmosis

Syphilis

Coccidiomycosis
Foreign body granuloma

Silicosis

Berylliosis
Immune granuloma

Wegener’s granulomatosis

Giant cell arteritis
Durk’s granuloma Cerebral malaria
Stellate granuloma Cat scratch disease

questions.text: Risk of tubal pregnancy is increased by all except?
questions.solution:
Oral combined pill use does not increase the risk of ectopic pregnancy. In fact, combined pills reduce the risk of ectopic pregnancy.

An ectopic pregnancy is one in which the fertilized ovum is implanted and develops outside the normal endometrial cavity, with the Fallopian tubes being the most common site. The outcomes of such a pregnancy are varied with tubal rupture and massive intraperitoneal hemorrhage being one of them.

Risk factors of ectopic pregnancy:

  • Previous ectopic pregnancy
  • Tubal corrective surgery, tubectomy
  • IUCD
  • Assisted reproductive technology
  • Documented tubal pathology
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (Chlamydia infection and salpingitis isthmica nodosa)
  • Genital tuberculosis
  • Endometriosis
  • Pelvic adhesions
  • Congenital elongation, accessory ostia, diverticula
  • Transmigration
  • Smoking
  • Prior abortion
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Prior Caesarean delivery
  • Progesterone-only pills (POPs)

questions.text: Identify this sign in pregnancy.
questions.solution:
The image dipicts Hegar's sign.

Hegar's sign: the examiner performs a bimanual examination. Two fingers of one hand are placed in the anterior fornix of the vagina and the fingers of the other hand are placed, over the abdomen and behind the uterus. The abdominal fingers and the vaginal fingers appear to oppose each other below the body of the uterus. This can be elicited between 6-10 weeks.

This sign is based on the fact that the lower part of the body of the uterus is empty and extremely soft, and the upper part is enlarged by the growing fetus.

Other options :

Option A- Palmer's sign is regular rhythmic uterine contraction during the bimanual examination, which is seen as early as 4-8 weeks.

Option C- Osiander's sign is increased pulsation felt through lateral fornix by 8 weeks.

Option D- Goodell's sign is softening of the cervix by the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Clinical Signs in Obstetrics

  • Chadwick’s Sign: Bluish hue to the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall. Seen in the first trimester of pregnancy. The cause is increased blood flow to the pelvic organs. Also known as Jacquemier’s Sign. /
  • Cullen Sign: Bluish discoloration of the skin around the umbilicus. Occurs due to intraperitoneal hemorrhage. Seen in ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Goodell Sign: Marked softening of the cervix in contrast to a non-pregnant state. Also due to increased blood flow
  • Hegar Sign: An indication of Pregnancy. The softening of the lower parts of the uterus enables the approximation of vaginal and abdominal fingers on bimanual pelvic examination.
  • Kustner’s Sign: Sign of placental separation. On pushing the uterus upwards does not move the cord with it due to the separation.
  • Ladin’s Sign: Softening in the midline of the uterus anteriorly at the junction of the uterus and cervix. It occurs at about 6 weeks gestation
  • Osiander’s Sign: Pulsations in the lateral fornix due to the increased vascularity.
  • Palmer’s Sign: Regular rhythmic contractions of uterus felt as early as 6-8 weeks. It is a sign of pregnancy
  • Piskacek’s Sign: Asymmetric growth occurs to the uterus in the initial stages of pregnancy due to the lateral implantation of the blastocyst. The area of implantation feels soft compared to the other parts.
  • Schroeder’s Sign: A sign of placental separation. Uterus rises up when the separated placenta is passed downwards
  • Stallworthy’s Sign: Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis and prompt recovery on the release of pressure is termed Stallworthy’s sign. This sign is suggestive of posterior placenta praevia.
  • Turtle Sign: This is when the fetal head suddenly retracts back against the mother's perineum after it has emerged from the vagina. This retraction of the fetal head is caused by the baby's anterior shoulder being caught on the back of the maternal pubic bone, preventing delivery of the remainder of the baby.
  • Von Braun-Fernwald's Sign: Irregular softening and enlargement of the uterine fundus during early pregnancy. It occurs at 5-8 weeks gestation.

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures in order of aqueous flow :
  1. Episcleral vein
  2. Trabecular meshwork
  3. Aqueous vein
  4. Schlemm’s canal
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of structures through which aqueous flows is: Trabecular meshwork (2) → Schlemm’s canal (4) → Aqueous veins (3) → Episcleral veins (1).

Circulation of aqueous humor is necessary both for metabolic purposes and to regulate intraocular pressure. There are two pathways of aqueous outflow :

  • Trabecular/conventional outflow – Main outlet draining 90% of aqueous via trabeculae.
    • Greater part of the fluid is formed in the ciliary region, it flows from the posterior chamber through the pupil into the anterior chamber and escapes through the drainage channels at the angle, i.e. Trabecular meshwork → Schlemm’s canal→ Aqueous veins→Episcleral veins→ Superior ophthalmic vein→Cavernous sinus.
  • Uveoscleral outflow – Drains around 10% of aqueous via ciliary body into the suprachoroidal space, and is drained by the venous circulation in the ciliary body, choroid and sclera.

The rate of formation of aqueous humor is 2-3 μL/min. Formation of aqueous humor involves the following:

  • Ultrafiltration
  • Secretion- Na/K ATPase of non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary process
  • Diffusion

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: What is the accommodative amplitude of a patient with a near point at 20 cm and a far point at infinity?
questions.solution:
The amplitude of accommodation for the above patient would be 5 dioptres.

Near point of accommodation (NPA) is the closest distance at which the near object is clearly focussed without blur.

Amplitude of accommodation is the maximum power of the lens that permits clear near vision without blur. Its unit is dioptre (D). The amplitude of accommodation is the reciprocal of near point of accommodation (NPA) in meters.

20 cm is 1/5th of a metre. Therefore, the accommodative amplitude is its inverse, that is, 5D.

Note:

The NPA is measured clinically using a scale device such as the Prince, Berens, or Royal Air Force (RAF) ruler.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument used in mastoidectomy:
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mollison’s mastoid retractor. It is used in mastoidectomy procedures to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.

Other options:

Option B: Lempert’s endaural retractor is used for an endaural approach to ear surgery. It has two lateral blades that retract the flaps and a third central blade with holes. The central blade retracts the temporalis muscle and can be fixed to the body of the retractor by its holes.

The image of Lempert’s endaural retractor is given below.

Option C:  A myringotome is a sharp surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum during myringotomy. The image is given below.

 

Option D: Jansen’s self-retaining mastoid retractor(shown below) is used in mastoidectomy and is similar to Mollison’s retractor.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presents with pain around the knee joint. His radiographic image is given below. Which among the following is the management for the condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the x-ray image showing the sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle, in the proximal tibia are suggestive of osteosarcoma, and the management for this patient would be wide excision.

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone with bimodal age of distribution peaking in adolescence and during the 7th decade. The most common site involved is the distal femoral metaphysis which mainly presents with pain and swelling. Other sites commonly involved are the proximal tibia, proximal femur, and humerus.

X-rays are diagnostic showing Codman’s triangle (new bone formation in response to periosteal elevation) and a ‘sunburst’ appearance when the periosteum does not have enough time to lay down a new layer. 

Wide excision and reconstruction are preferred if the tumor is resectable and there are no skip lesions. It is done after starting neoadjuvant chemotherapy for 8-12 weeks. Chemotherapeutic agents used are doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate.

Other options:

Option A: Curettage is mainly used for the management of giant cell tumors. It is a benign, locally aggressive tumor presenting in the 2nd-4th decade with distal femoral metaphysis or epiphysis as the most common site. Radiographic findings include solitary lytic lesions and soap bubble appearance shown below.

Option B: Radiofrequency ablation is the preferred treatment for osteoid osteoma. It is a benign tumor formed of osteoid and woven bone. It is common in men and most commonly occurs in the diaphysis of the femur.

Option D: Intralesional steroids are used in the management of simple bone cysts that occur most commonly in males near the metaphyseal areas.
