questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The above image depicts Ritgen’s manoeuvre, a technique used during the second stage of labor to assist in the controlled delivery of the fetal head, reducing the risk of perineal tears and trauma.

Steps in Ritgen’s Maneuver:

  • The right hand is draped with a sterile towel.
  • The fingers of the right hand pressing posterior to the rectum exerts upward pressure to the chin and extends the head. The extension of the head prevents the head from slipping back in between the contractions.
  • The left hand placed over the occiput exerts a downward counterpressure to prevent the rapid extension of the head
  • The ritgen’s manoeuvre thus helps in the controlled delivery of the head of the fetus.

Other options:

Option B: Pinard’s manoeuvre is used to facilitate the delivery of legs in case of frank breech presentation.

Option C: Lovset’s manoeuvre is used to facilitate the delivery of arms in breech presentation.

Option D: In Zavanelli maneuver is an obstetric procedure used as a last-resort technique during shoulder dystocia when other manoeuvres fail to deliver the baby vaginally. The fetal head is rotated to the pre-restitution position and pushed back into the pelvis to perform an emergency cesarean section.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was seen by the optometrist for complaints of blurred vision.  While examining for refractive error, he noticed that the child's corneas were unusually small for his age and referred him for further evaluation. Below what horizontal diameter can a diagnosis of microcornea be made in this child?
questions.solution:
To make a diagnosis of microcornea, in this child, the diameter of the cornea should be less than 10 mm.

Micro-cornea

  • Horizontal corneal diameter is 10 mm or less (over 2 years of age) or less than 9 mm (in the newborn).
  • There may be hypermetropia and a shallow anterior chamber but other dimensions are normal.

Megalocornea

  • Horizontal corneal diameter is 12 mm or more (up to 2 years of age) or 13 mm or more (if age >2 years)
  • There is typically high myopia and astigmatism, but normal corrected visual acuity.
  • Usually X-linked recessive; 90% of affected individuals are male.

Cornea plana

  • The cornea is flatter than normal, i.e., the radius of curvature is larger.
  • There is a corresponding reduction in refractive power, resulting in high hypermetropia.

Keratectasia

  • It is characterized by a protuberance between the eyelids caused by a severely opacified, and sometimes vascularized, cornea.
  • It is often associated with raised intraocular pressure as well as intrauterine keratitis.
  • Usually unilateral

Microphthalmos

  • Microphthalmia is a condition in which the entire eye is small, with an axial length at least two standard deviations below the mean for age.
  • It may or may not be associated with ocular dysgenesis.

Nanophthalmos

  • In nanophthalmos (simple microphthalmos), the entire eye is small, but is structurally normal; 
  • It is usually associated with hypermetropia and strabismus

Anophthalmos: Anophthalmos (anophthalmia) refers to the complete absence of any visible globe structure.

questions.text: A patient presented with midline swelling in the neck. Biopsy revealing orphan Annie eye nuclei as shown in the image below is suggestive of ________:
questions.solution:
The presence of empty appearing nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei as seen in the above image is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma:

  • The carcinoma shows branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk covered with simple or stratified cuboidal epithelium.
  • On high power, the nuclei appear optically clear or empty as the chromatin is dispersed. These empty appearing nuclei are called Orphan Annie eye nuclei.
  • Concentric calcified structures called psammoma bodies are usually seen.
  • Foci of lymphatic invasion by the tumour are usually present.

Note : 

The presence of Orphan Annie-eye nuclei or psammoma bodies is diagnostic of papillary thyroid cancer, regardless of the presence of papillary architecture.

The image below shows papillary thyroid carcinoma with characteristic orphan Annie eye nuclei:

The image below shows psammoma bodies in papillary thyroid cancer.

questions.text: The false statement regarding the modified WHO partograph is?

choices.text: Right side of alert line indicates immediate referral to First Referral Unit (FRU)
Alert and action line are separated by a difference of 4 hours
Each small square in the partograph is equal 1 hour
Partograph recording should be started once the cervical dilatation reaches 4 cm

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is each small square in partograph is equal to 1 hour. It is equal to 30 minutes. 

Partograph is a composite graphical record of key data (maternal and fetal) during labor, entered against time. The alert line starts at 4 cm of cervical dilatation and ends at 10 cm dilatation (at the rate of 1 cm/hr). The action line is drawn 4 hours to the right and parallel to the alert line. In normal labor, the graph should be either on the alert line or to the left of it.

When it falls on the right of the alert line(zone-2), it is abnormal and needs to be critically assessed. When it falls to the right of the action line (zone 3) case should be reassessed by a senior person and specific management decisions (for example- referral to a higher centre or performing an intervention like cesarean section) should be made.

Clinically, the active phase of labour is considered from ≥6 cm of cervical dilatation. However, we begin plotting the partograph from 4 cm of cervical dilatation (in accordance with the modified WHO Partograph).

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A female patient presented with painful swelling and watering in her left eye for a few weeks. Examination revealed the following finding. Which of the following treatment is not preferred for her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of painful swelling and watering of eyes along with the image showing a reddish swelling in the lid with edema is suggestive of hordeolum externum or stye. Intralesional injection of triamcinolone is not effective in its management. Instead, triamcinolone injections are used for the treatment of chalazion, injected directly into and around the lesion.

Hordeolum externum or stye is the staphylococcal infection of the Zeis gland or Moll gland. It presents as a collection of pus usually pointing at the base of a single cilium. The entire lid may be edamatous. Treatment is with systemic antibiotics and a warm compress. The abscess may also be drained by pulling out the affected cilia. Incision and drainage may also be done. 

A chalazion is a sterile chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland due to retained sebaceous secretion. It is also called a tarsal or meibomian cyst. Complete spontaneous resolution occurs rarely. Oral antibiotics are only required for lesions with significant bacterial infections. Daily hot compression can help in the resolution of early lesions. Treatment includes incision and curettage, which is conventional and effective. Intralesional injection of steroid into and around the lesions give a similar resolution to incision and curettage.

An image of chalazion is shown below.

questions.text: A female presents to the clinic at 12 weeks of gestational age with a history of a lump in her right breast for the past 2 months. On examination, you find a lump of 2 X 1 cm in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast. Which of the following investigations would you initially advise her for the assessment of the breast lump?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in pregnant women who present with a breast lump. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and is able to detect abnormal axillary lymph nodes.

USG is preferred in pregnant women, lactating women, and young women (less than 40 years) since breast tissue is dense in these populations.

Other options:

Option A: Mammography is less useful in pregnant women due to the increased density of breast tissue.

Option C: MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used in cases where metastasis or spread to other breasts is suspected.

Option D: Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not recommended in pregnant women. It is difficult to distinguish breast cancer from the normal cellular proliferation in the breast tissue due to hormonal changes.

questions.text: A 3-day old male neonate who has not yet passed meconium developed abdominal distension. There is no history of fever. On rectal examination, forceful expulsion of stool was observed. A barium enema is performed and the findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the gold standard for the diagnosis of the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a newborn presenting with failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, forceful expulsion of stools on rectal examination, and barium enema showing dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. The gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschprung's disease is a rectal biopsy.

Hirschsprung disease or congenital aganglionic colon is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus of the distal intestinal segment. This is because of the premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum.

 

They are predominantly seen in boys and are associated with Down syndrome. Most cases present during the neonatal period with abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and failure to pass meconium. Later they may also have poor feeding and severe constipation. Forceful expulsion of stools is observed on rectal examination as the stools accumulate in the distal colon.

A barium enema is obtained on all suspected cases. This demonstrates the location of the transition zone between the dilated ganglionic colon and the distal aganglionic rectal segment.  In older children, anorectal manometry shows a high internal sphincter pressure due to the absence of normal inhibitory reflex.

 Rectal biopsy is the gold standard investigation shows the following:

  • Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing (superior to acetylcholinesterase staining)

The definitive surgeries are the Swenson procedure, Duhamel procedure, and Soave's procedure

The most common cause of death in uncorrected Hirschprung's disease is enterocolitis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of alcohol abuse causes reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor?
questions.solution:
Naltrexone causes reduced reward response to drinking and reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor.

Before prescribing: Evaluate for possible current opioid use; consider a urine toxicology screen for opioids, including synthetic opioids. Obtain liver function tests and follow up periodically.

Acamprosate, naltrexone, and disulfiram are used in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

Other options:

Option A: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine used in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal.

Option B: Acamprosate affects glutamate and GABA neurotransmitter systems, but its alcohol-related action is unclear.

Option D: Disulfiram inhibits the intermediate metabolism of alcohol which causes a build-up of acetaldehyde and a reaction of flushing, sweating, nausea, and tachycardia if a patient drinks alcohol.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient presents with retrosternal chest pain. On auscultation, a pericardial friction rub is present. Echocardiography reveals a small amount of pericardial fluid. The ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient with widespread ST elevation is acute pericarditis.

Acute pericarditis is an inflammation of the pericardium characterized by retrosternal chest pain that is aggravated by deep inspiration and supine position and relieved by sitting and leaning forward. It can be attributed to various causes like infections or inflammatory conditions like RA and SLE, or miscellaneous causes like iatrogenic, neoplasms, drugs, etc.

On auscultation, 85% of patients have a pericardial friction rub. This appears as a rough scratching sound at end of expiration when the patient is sitting and leaning forward. 

ECG findings of acute pericarditis need to be differentiated from those of myocardial infarction as they are similar.

There are four stages in the development of acute pericarditis ECG changes.

  • Stage 1: Widespread elevation of ST segments; depression of PR segment below the TP segment
  • Stage 2: ST segments return to normal after a few days
  • Stage 3: T waves become inverted
  • Stage 4: ECG returns to normal after weeks or months. 

Echocardiography is diagnostic for acute pericarditis. It would reveal a small amount of pericardial fluid. It can also be confirmed by CT or MRI. 

Treatment of acute pericarditis is nonspecific. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are recommended, along with bed rest.

Other options:

Option A - Myocardial infarction would not have a pericardial friction rub. In addition, the ST changes would be localized to a specific area but in pericarditis, there are widespread changes. They would also be more prominent elevations.

Option C - Cardiac tamponade is characterized by Beck's triad of hypotension, jugulo-venous distension, and muffled heart sounds. None of these are present in this patient. 

Option D - Pulmonary embolism would be characterized by tachycardia, inverted T waves (right ventricular overload) in leads V1 - V4, and S1Q3T3 pattern would be seen.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with pain and redness in the right eye following an injury during welding. On examination, the image as seen below is observed. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A history of injury to the eye while welding along with the the given image is suggestive of a superficial foreign body in the eye. Removal of the foreign body using a 26G needle is the next step in the management of this patient.

Foreign bodies, which are usually small particles of dust, iron, steel, etc., may impinge upon the conjunctiva or cornea and cause sudden discomfort and reflex blinking. The foreign body sticks to the palpebral conjunctiva and is liable to be dragged across the cornea, causing excoriation. Particles of steel and iron fly straight onto the cornea and penetrate the epithelium or substantia propria.

Fluorescein or oblique illumination of the anesthetized eye with a slit lamp can be used to determine the position of a foreign body. If not removed, they expose the cornea to organisms in the conjunctival sac causing ulceration and extrusion of the foreign body in the slough. The ulcer thus formed may heal, but if virulent organisms are present, a spreading ulcer, with or without hypopyon, may develop.

Foreign bodies are managed by removal as soon as possible. 

  • If the foreign body is found lying loose in either fornix, it can be removed with a clean swab after everting the eyelids.
  • Double-eversion of the upper eyelid with a Desmarres retractor can be done if required.
  • If embedded in the bulbar conjunctiva or cornea, it can be removed by a foreign body spud or fine forceps under topical anesthesia.
  • A disposable hypodermic (26 or 27 gauge) needle can be used.

Following removal in all cases, an antibiotic ointment should be applied and the eye kept bandaged for a day. Foreign bodies in the eye are extremely common in industrial workers, especially in those working with grinding tools, lathe work, or hammering on a chisel, and thus eye must be protected by educative notices, lectures, and the provision of comfortable goggles.

Cases of ferruginous intraocular foreign bodies (IOFB) may give rise to anterior capsular cataracts and reddish-brown staining of the iris leading to heterochromia iridis. MRI is contraindicated here and instead, CT with axial and coronal cuts is used to localize a metallic IOFB. Magnetic removal is done for the removal of ferrous foreign bodies.

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presented with pain abdomen. The resident examines the child and found that vitals were stable and tenderness was present in the left lumbar region. Which is the best investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following a road traffic accident is suggestive of blunt renal trauma. The investigation of choice is CECT in a hemodynamically stable patient.

Blunt trauma is the main cause of renal injuries and is generally self-limiting. Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross haematuria, shock in combination with microscopic haematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.

CECT is the investigation of choice. It assesses the extent of the injury, showing laceration, extravasation, surrounding haemorrhage, and vessel injury. It also shows non-renal injuries and effectively stages renal pedicle injuries. Arterial occlusion will manifest as rim enhancement of the normal renal contour.

Blunt trauma is mostly treated conservatively. Most of the penetrating injuries require surgical renal exploration.

Absolute indications for surgical intervention in renal trauma are massive haemorrhage, renal pedicle avulsion (grade 5 injury) and expanding, pulsatile, or uncontained retroperitoneal hematoma.

Relative indications are large laceration of the renal pelvis or avulsion of the ureteropelvic junction, bowel or pancreatic injuries, persistent urinary leakage, postinjury urinoma, or perinephric abscess, complete renal artery thrombosis of both kidneys and renal hypertension.

Exploratory laparotomy (Option D) is recommended in unstable patients and those with penetrating renal injuries.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) kidney Injury Scale

GRADE  

 INJURY DESCRIPTION
I

Contusion

Microscopic or gross hematuria, urologic studies normal
  Hematoma

Subcapsular, nonexpanding, without parenchymal laceration
II

Hematoma

Nonexpanding perirenal hematoma confined to renal retroperitoneum
  Laceration

 <1 cm parenchymal depth of renal cortex without urinary extravasation
III

Laceration 

>1 cm depth of renal cortex, without collecting system rupture or urinary extravasation
IV Laceration

Parenchymal laceration extending through the renal cortex, medulla, and collecting system
  Vascular

Main renal artery or vein injury, with contained hemorrhage
V Laceration Completely shattered kidney
  Laceration   Avulsion of renal hilum, which devascularizes kidney

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with pruritic hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest as seen in the image. Which of the following color would you expect on Wood's lamp examination?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pruritic lesion over the trunk and image showing sharply demarcated multiple hypopigmented macules and coalescing into patches with fine scales is suggestive of pityriasis versicolor or tinea versicolor. On Wood's lamp examination these lesions show pale yellow fluorescence. 

Wood's lamp is a source of ultraviolet rays. All visible rays from this source are excluded by Wood's filter. In fungal infections like pityriasis versicolor, it shows the pale yellow fluorescence as given below.

Pityriasis versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales. Azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species competitively inhibits tyrosinase and results in hypopigmentation.

The most commonly affected site is the upper trunk, but there is often spread to the upper arms, neck, and abdomen. Occasionaly it presents as pruritic lesion. The color of the scales may vary from pale ochre to medium brown, and so the term versicolor. Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur.

The image below shows the scales seen in Tinea versicolor.

The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes’. 

Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail) is an important diagnostic clue when the scales are not visible. Here the barely perceptible scales are made to stand out by scratching the lesion with fingernails.

Patients are treated with topical azoles or 1% terbinafine cream twice daily for 2 to 3 weeks or ketoconazole shampoo twice weekly for the same duration. Relapse is very common. 

Other options:

Option A- Coral pink fluorescence is seen in erythrasma.

Option B- Red fluorescence is seen in squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

Option D- Green fluorescence is seen in tinea capitis infections associated with Microspora species and favus.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's Lamp Examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp. Black light is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: blue-green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum); 

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue.

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

 

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text: A man was working in a field and he suddenly collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration but radial pulse was present.  His serum electrolytes level was normal. The doctor found that the body temperature was 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Which of the following should be given as first aid in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette in a patient with no signs of dehydration and body temperature of 106oF is highly suggestive of heatstroke. The first step among the following options is to cover the patient with a cool damp sheet to reduce body temperature. 

The following are the first aid measures to be done for heatstroke:

  • Move the person to a cool environment.
  • Remove any restricting clothes to dissipate the heat.
  • Try cooling the patient by blowing air using a fan, spraying water using a hose or sponge, using cool damp sheets or blankets, immersing the patient in a tub of water or shower, ice bath, etc. 
  • Place ice packs on the groin, neck, back, and armpits where the blood vessels are seen close to the skin, which reduces temperature fast. 
  • If the patient is not breathing or with no pulse then CPR has to be initiated.

Heatstroke/ thermic fever/ heat hyperpyrexia is due to the failure of the heat regulation center of the hypothalamus. It is caused by failure of cutaneous circulation and sweating. The predisposing factors include high temperature, increased humidity, minor infections, old age, lack of acclimatization, alcoholism.

Heatstroke can be:

  • Exertion-induced heat stroke is seen in people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures, usually without adequate training.
  • Sedentary heatstroke is a disease of elderly or infirm people whose cardiovascular systems are unable to adapt to the stress of a hot environment and release sufficient heat such that body temperature rises.

All the signs of shock are present. Patients usually present with a sudden collapse accompanied by loss of consciousness. Typical vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, tachycardias, hypotension, and a widened pulse pressure. Other specific signs include rapid Kussmaul type of breathing, the absence of sweating with dry, hot skin, delirium, coma, convulsions, rhabdomyolysis, multiorgan failure.

Although there is no single specific diagnostic test, clinical features of exposure to heat stress, CNS dysfunction, and core temperature >104.9-degree Fahrenheit (> 40.5 degrees Celsius) help establish the preliminary diagnosis. The body temperature must be measured rectally.

Treatment includes rapidly cooling the body with ice water till the rectal temperature falls below 1020F.

Autopsy findings include the presence of edema and reduction of Purkinje's cells in the cerebellum.

There is no role of antipyretics in the control of environmentally induced hyperthermia. They also exacerbate the complications (acute kidney injury, hepatic failure, DIC).

questions.text: While examining a patient with a right forearm fracture, you ask him to make a fist. The following finding is noted during this procedure. What is the sign called as ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the pointing index sign and is associated with median nerve injury at the forearm or elbow.

The pointing index sign is seen in supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

This finding occurs as a result of injury to the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. It results in the loss of function of both flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS). Hence, the index finger sticks out when the patient is asked to clasp their hand. 

Other options:

Option A:  In Froment's sign, due to the weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle, the adduction of the thumb is lost. When asked to hold an object, the patient tries to hold the object by using the flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at the interphalangeal joint while holding the book.

Option C:  Paralysis of flexor pollicis brevis can occur in median nerve injury at the arm and elbow. Benediction hand sign (attempt to make a fist gives pointed index and middle finger) and Ochsner's clasping test (attempt to clasp both hands show pointing index finger) are used to test such injuries.

Option D:  Policeman tip deformity, also known as waiter's tip hand or porter's tip hand, is a finding of Erb's palsy due to injury of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus involving C5 and C6. The hand is adducted, medially rotated, and hangs by the side with the elbow extended and pronated.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old lady underwent copper-T IUCD insertion 2 months after the delivery of her baby. A few weeks after the procedure, she presented with pain abdomen. The tail of the IUCD is not visible. Her radiograph is shown in the image below. The most appropriate step in the management of this patient is?

IUCD: Intrauterine contraceptive device
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows the IUCD outside the uterine cavity, most likely due to perforation. The most appropriate step in the management of this patient is the removal of the IUCD by laparotomy. 

The tail of the IUCD is not visible when the IUCD is misplaced. The reasons for misplaced IUCD include:

  • Enlargement of the uterus due to pregnancy
  • Curling of the threads inside the uterus
  • Perforation of the uterus
  • IUCD buried in the myometrium
  • Spontaneous expulsion

A plain X-ray or pelvic ultrasound is used in the localization of the IUCD when the IUCD threads cannot be visualized. In this patient, the misplaced IUCD is seen laterally displaced in the pelvic cavity. An abnormal location or abnormal shape of IUCD indicates likely perforation of the uterus. 

Perforation can occur either at the time of insertion (immediate traumatic perforation) or due to gradual erosion of the myometrium (secondary perforation). The risk factors for uterine perforation include:

  • Insertion by less experienced clinicians
  • Post-partum insertion (<6 months since delivery)
  • A higher number of previous abortions
  • Lower parity
  • Lactation

Management:

If the location of the IUCD is inside the uterine cavity, it can be removed using Shirodkar's hook (Option A), a curette, or a hysteroscope (option B) and ultrasound guidance.

In perforation of the uterus, a laparotomy is done as copper-T gets adhered to the omentum or gut and will be difficult to be removed using a laparoscope.

Other options:

Option A- Spontaneous expulsion is one of the reasons for misplaced IUCD. It is not a management approach. The factors that are associated with an increased risk of spontaneous expulsion of the IUCD are age <20 years and nulliparity. Expulsion tends to occur at the time of menstruation and is associated with cramping, bleeding, and vaginal discharge.

Here the IUCD has caused perforation of the uterus and is lodged outside the uterus, hence, spontaneous expulsion will not be possible.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. The microscopic examination of urine is shown below. What is the type of stone seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows a hexagonal crystal, suggesting cystine stones. These stones are a recurrent feature in patients with cystinuria.

Crystals in urine are usually associated with kidney stones. Crystals form in the urine depends upon a variety of factors including:

  • The degree of concentration of constituent molecules
  • The urine pH
  • The presence of inhibitors of crystallization

Calcium oxalate and uric acid crystals can sometimes be found in normal urine that has been left to stand, due to crystal formation ex vivo.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida delivered a baby at term with a birth weight of 2.5 kg via normal vaginal delivery. The placenta delivered appears as shown in the image below. Which of the following complications is less likely to be associated with this placental variant?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bilobed placenta also known as placenta bilobate or bipartite placenta or placenta duplex. Fetal growth restriction is not a complication likely to be associated with this placental variant.

A bilobed placenta is described as the presence of two, almost equally sized placental lobes separated by a membrane, without significant vasculature present in between them. The umbilical cord may be inserted between the two placental lobes into the chorionic bridge, or into the intervening membranes, or in a velamentous fashion. The presence of more than two lobes is termed as multilobate placenta and is rare.

The complications associated with this placental variant are:

  • First-trimester bleeding
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Abruption
  • Retained placenta

The types of placental variants are:

  • Placenta succenturiata: One or more unequally sized smaller placental lobes at distant sites from the bulk of the placenta. Vessels are present in the intervening membranes that connect the two lobes.   
  • Placenta membranacea: Unduly large and thin placenta that develops from both the chorionic frondosum and the chorion leave.  
  • Ring-shaped placenta: This is a variant of placenta membranacea where a partial or complete ring of the placenta is present.  
  • Placenta fenestrata: In this, the central portion of a placental disc is missing.
  • Battledore placenta: In this, the umbilical cord is inserted at or near the placental margin rather than at the center.  
  • Extrachorial placentation: the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation:
    • Circummarginate placenta - In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage with a smooth margin.
    • Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female who is on antitubercular therapy (ATT) experiences red-green color discrimination issues. Which of the following ATT drugs is most likely responsible for this side effect?
questions.solution:
The most likely ATT drug responsible for the red-green color discrimination issue in this case is ethambutol. It is important to monitor patients on this drug for visual side effects and, if necessary, consider dosage adjustments or discontinuation under medical supervision.

Ethambutol inhibits arabinose transferase III, thereby decreasing arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This results in, disruption in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis. It is primarily excreted unchanged by kidneys and accumulation occurs in renal failure. Ethambutol does not undergo hepatic metabolism and can be safely prescribed for the treatment of TB in patients with hepatitis.

Optic neuritis resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of ability to differentiate red from green is the most serious adverse effect of ethambutol. It is a dose-dependent adverse effect that can be unilateral or bilateral.

Tests of visual acuity and red-green discrimination before the start of therapy and periodically thereafter are recommended.

Other options:

Option A:Isoniazid is known for causing peripheral neuropathy and hepatotoxicity as potential side effects.

Option C: Pyrazinamide is more commonly associated with hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia. 

Option D: Rifampicinis known for causing orange discoloration of body fluids.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action Blocks mycolic acid synthesis. Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis. Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane. Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration.  However, on ​administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the following conditions is likely in this patient?

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of hypothyroidism and the TSH levels are low due to low levels of TRH. This is based on the fact that the administration of TRH increased the TSH levels. Hence, the patient has hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus.

Normally, the thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH) is released by the hypothalamus. It stimulates the pituitary gland to release the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which in turn stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T3 and T4 hormones. 

Low TSH levels may be seen in the following cases:

Disease Pathogenesis Presentation
Hyperthyroidism Feedback inhibition of TSH release Symptoms of hyperthyroidism
Primary disease of the pituitary Decreased release of TSH, thereby causing a decreased release of thyroid hormones

Symptoms of hypothyroidism.

Administration of TRH does not elevate the TSH levels in this case since the pituitary gland is abnormal
Primary disease of the hypothalamus Decreased release of TRH leading to decreased TSH and hypothyroidism Administration of TRH causes elevation of TSH levels since the pituitary gland is normal.

questions.text: An elderly woman with hypothyroidism presents to the ER with decreased consciousness, sinus bradycardia, and hypotension. Her family members reveal that she has not been taking her thyroid medications recently. Investigations reveal elevated TSH levels and reduced T3 and T4 levels. Blood gases show hypercapnia, hyponatremia and hypoglycemia. Which of the following can be used in the treatment spectrum of this condition?

choices.text: Insulin bolus followed by IV fluids

questions.solution:
The given clinical history suggests a case of hypothyroidism presenting in myxedema coma. Hypertonic saline is used in its treatment spectrum.

Myxedema coma refers to severe, life-threatening manifestations of hypothyroidism. It is mostly seen in the elderly. It is often precipitated by drugs (sedatives, antidepressants, anaesthetics), infections like pneumonia, congestive heart failure, myocardial ischemia, cerebrovascular accidents, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patients present with impaired consciousness, profound hypothermia (which can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension. It is associated with a high mortality rate.

Management of myxedema coma is with levothyroxine (T4) or liothyronine (T3). Levothyroxine is given intravenously, while liothyronine can be given via nasogastric or intravenous route. Parenteral hydrocortisone is used to correct the impaired levels of corticoid hormones. And the precipitating factors are treated symptomatically. Supportive therapy is by correcting the associated metabolic imbalance, external warming (if body temperature is <30 degrees) to prevent circulatory collapse by using space blankets, and ventilatory support if hypercapnia is present.

Other options:

Option A: IV diazepam is used in emergency management of status epilepticus. Hence, it is not used in the management spectrum of this condition.

Option B: Insulin bolus followed by IV fluids is not used since the patient already has hypoglycemia and there is no point in using insulin here in this state.

Option D: Stoppage of all steroid agents is not needed. But stoppage of known precipitating drugs can be stopped. On the other hand, parenteral steroids are used in the treatment of this condition.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with headaches for 6 months. She has been taking analgesics regularly. The headache recently increased in severity for 3 days but was reduced on stopping the analgesic. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of medication overuse headache.

Medication overuse headache: 

It is also known as analgesic rebound headache, drug-induced headache, or medication-misuse headache. In this condition medications that are used for the treatment of headache becomes the cause for headaches. It usually resolves when the overuse is stopped.

Diagnostic criteria: According to ICHD-3(International Classification of Headache Disorders-3)

  • Headache occurring on ≥15 days/month in a patient with a pre-existing headache disorder
  • Regular overuse for >3 months of one or more drugs that can be taken for acute and/or symptomatic treatment of headache.
  • Not better accounted for by another ICHD-3 diagnosis.

Management: It includes the following steps:

  • Withdrawal of the overused medication
  • Rescue therapy or the treatment of withdrawal symptoms
  • Initiation of preventative therapy if required
  • Alternative symptomatic medication for future headaches

Other options:

Option B: Tension headache: It is a chronic headache syndrome characterized by bilateral, tight band-like discomfort. It can be episodic or chronic in nature. It is usually not associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, photophobia, etc.

Option C: Chronic migraine: Diagnostic criteria for migraine headache is as follows: Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 hours in patients with normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for headache, and

At least 2 of the following features Plus at least 1 of the following features
Unilateral pain Nausea or vomiting
Throbbing pain Photophobia and phonophobia
Aggravation by movement  
Moderate or severe intensity  

Option D: Cluster headache: It is characterized by deep, excruciating, nonfluctuating pain which is usually retroorbital. The classical feature of this condition is its periodicity.  At least one of the daily attacks of pain recurs at almost the same hour every day.
Typically the patient has daily bouts of one or two attacks of relatively short-duration unilateral pain for 8–10 weeks a year. In between the clusters, there is a pain-free interval.

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after he consumed some locally produced spirit. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of methanol toxicity. Ethanol and fomepizole is used for the treatment of this condition.

Methanol poisoning is caused due to ingestion of illicit liquor which contains ethanol adulterated with methanol. Methanol is metabolized to formaldehyde and formic acid by alcohol and aldehyde dehydrogenases, respectively. The metabolites of methanol are responsible for the toxic effects.

Clinically, patients present with headache, vomiting, abdomen pain, uneasiness, confusion, delirium, and coma. Formic acid specifically damages the retina and optic nerve and results in blurring of vision and blindness.

Elevated levels of formic acid and other organic acids result in metabolic acidosis in arterial blood gas analysis(ABG).

Treatment of methanol poisoning includes gastric lavage with sodium bicarbonate if the patient is brought within 2 hours of ingesting methanol to combat acidosis. Ethanol infusion since ethanol is preferentially metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase over methanol and helps by reducing the rate of generation of formaldehyde and formic acid.

Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase and the drug of choice for methanol poisoning. Folate therapy with calcium leucovorin reduces blood formate levels by enhancing its oxidation. Hemodialysis is used in severe cases of methanol toxicity.

Other options: 

Option B: Flumazenil is the inverse agonist of benzodiazepine receptors and is used for the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose.

Option C: Diazepam can be used to manage delirium tremens, or seizures due to alcohol withdrawal.

Option D: Naloxone is a competitive opioid antagonist used for the treatment of opioid overdose.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, who is a known hypertensive, not on treatment, presents to the OPD for a regular checkup. On examination, his blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. The presence of which of the following in him will help us diagnose metabolic syndrome, as per NCEP- ATP III?

choices.text: Triglycerides of 100 mg/dL and waist circumference of 105 cm
Waist circumference of 105 cm and fasting glucose of 110 mg/dL
Fasting glucose of 110 mg/dL and HDL cholesterol of 60 mg/dL
HDL Cholesterol of 60 mg/dL and triglycerides of 100 mg/dL

questions.solution:
In this patient with the blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg, waist circumference of 105 cm and fasting glucose of 110 mg/dL helps diagnose metabolic syndrome. 

Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, which is given by NCEP-ATP III (National Cholesterol Education program and adult treatment panel III). It includes-

  • Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (males), >88 cm (females)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level ≥ 150 mg/dL
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively.
  • Hypertension: blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥ 85 mmHg diastolic.
  • Fasting plasma glucose level ≥100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below :
questions.solution:
The image showing grape-like projections, involving the anterior part of the vocal cords depicts a laryngeal papilloma.

Laryngeal papilloma is a benign tumour of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11). They can occur in children, most commonly around 3 -5 years of age (juvenile papillomatosis), as well as in adults. They involve the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. Seeding of the lesions can occur during invasive laryngeal procedures, such as intubation. They have a high recurrence rate and very low potential for malignancy. 

Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis is less common and usually seen in males aged 30-50 years. It is less aggressive and involves the anterior part of the vocal cords. The treatment is the same as juvenile papillomatosis.

Patients present with hoarseness, aphonia, dyspnea, or stridor. Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white grape-like projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core. The diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro-laryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision.

The image below depicts laryngeal papillomatosis on laryngoscopy:

Other options:

Option A: Reinke's oedema is a condition of bilateral diffuse polyposis due to the collection of fluid in Reinke's space mainly due to vocal abuse and smoking. On bronchoscopy, bilateral diffusely swollen vocal cords can be seen.

The image of Renke's oedema is given below.

Option B: Malignancy is characterized by symptoms of hoarseness and pain during swallowing. Patients are typically male who smokes tobacco or with a history of smoking in the past. On bronchoscopy, growth can be seen and a biopsy of the lesion or fine-needle aspiration of metastatized nodes may help to confirm the diagnosis.

Option C: Tracheomalacia is an anatomical defect of the trachea characterized by increased trachea collapsibility due to the trachea's structural abnormality. The symptoms of primary tracheomalacia first develop between 4-6 weeks. It presents with high-pitched expiratory stridor, which develops when the airflow in the trachea increases due to crying, feeding, or physical activity. Bronchoscopy shows narrowing of the tracheal lumen with loss of semicircular shape and bulging of the posterior membranous wall. It can be treated conservatively with medical and surgical methods, based on the extent of the disease and other associated conditions.
